description: The Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) Cloud Fundamentals course is for anyone looking to learn foundational cloud computing knowledge as well as basic skills inside of Office 365 and Microsoft Intune. This is a great course for someone wanting to learn basic Office 365, Exchange Online, SharePoint Online and Skype for Business tasks. Content wise, one will hear about the different technologies one would use when it comes to utilizing the cloud, securing the data in the cloud, and even connect different services to things like the Office 365 interface as well as focus on the knowledge required for the 98-369: MTA Cloud Fundamental Exam. To gain an MTA certification, you must pass only one MTA exam.
name: MTA - Cloud Fundamentals - 98-369
subtitle: Cloud Fundamentals

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel go over some of the basic principals and concepts with regards to Cloud Services. They start by defining traditional, on-premise service models and then contrast those from their cloud-based counterparts. They also touch upon the financial aspect of both on-premise and cloud-based environments, specifically explaining CapEx and OpEx models.
episodes.title: Cloud Principles and Delivery

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel continue explaining some basic principals and concepts of cloud services, here providing specific details for Infrastructure as a Service(IaaS), Platform as a Service(PaaS), and Software as a Service(SaaS). They describe what encompasses each service type and the when/where/why you might take advantage of them. They also talk a bit about a hybrid environment where you blend cloud-based and on-premise services.
episodes.title: Cloud Principles and Delivery Part 2

ongoing support for the vendor,
operating system that you need.

00:27:45.310 --> 00:27:48.150
So that's the other thing that we need
to think about is the operating systems

547
00:27:48.150 --> 00:27:48.930
themselves as well.

548
00:27:48.930 --> 00:27:51.080
>> Again, we're just paying for
what we're using.

549
00:27:51.080 --> 00:27:52.760
If we're not using it,
we don't pay for it.

550
00:27:52.760 --> 00:27:53.750
It doesn't make sense.

551
00:27:53.750 --> 00:27:55.120
They're letting somebody else use that,

and they are hoofing that cost,

If I want this, I want this,

I pay a little less.

When you have multi-sites like this and

00:30:05.875 --> 00:30:09.135
Well, with the cloud applications,

It could be in the main office, it could

You know that when they launch

It also helps you to do something,

Rather than having to deploy

But the hybrid model just means portions

One of the things I might say is that

Microsoft does a good job at having

00:32:24.737 --> 00:32:30.820

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel tackle some of the privacy policies that are in effect when using Microsoft as a cloud service provider. Some of those policies include concepts like data ownership, data custodial responsibilities, and customer privacy measures, which is accomplished through customer controls and configuration, hardware/software design elements that prevent "fence hopping" through shared storage or resources, and extensive security auditing. They also explain compliance standards like HIPPA for cloud services.
episodes.title: Cloud Security

And do they hit them?

Well, they do.
And these are just,

00:31:19.020 --> 00:31:23.890
this is just the top of the stack,
top ten compliance standards.

00:31:23.890 --> 00:31:25.550
There are a bunch of them, guys.

00:31:25.550 --> 00:31:28.060
And I don't wanna bore you with

588
00:31:28.060 --> 00:31:30.430
I will put these links so

589
00:31:30.430 --> 00:31:34.420
So if that's something that you have

Can I use this to keep

If you are developing an app and it's

00:31:46.450 --> 00:31:47.330
Well it says there.

00:31:47.330 --> 00:31:50.340
DOPs, data processing agreements.

The other thing that I didn't mention

00:31:54.310 --> 00:31:59.620

599
00:32:03.770 --> 00:32:06.020
And then some, what was that

00:32:06.020 --> 00:32:08.350
>> Sarbanes-Oxley
>> Okay, okay.

601
00:32:08.350 --> 00:32:08.925
God bless you.

602
00:32:08.925 --> 00:32:11.090
[LAUGH] But you can see,

00:32:11.090 --> 00:32:13.230
you could see that it's not

00:32:13.230 --> 00:32:16.780
There's the two right that I was talking

you could see it's one of the best, Dave

00:32:19.970 --> 00:32:23.710
benchmark for standards internationally

00:32:23.710 --> 00:32:27.370
So we do have, and there's,
here's one for Canada as well.

00:32:27.370 --> 00:32:29.480
So you know,
if your own Canadian soil too.

00:32:29.480 --> 00:32:32.010
Or maybe you've got a company

610
00:32:32.010 --> 00:32:33.440
maybe it's some here in the states.

00:32:33.440 --> 00:32:37.110
European nations and in Canada,
you're gonna be protected.

612

So when it comes down to it,
with all the acronyms and

all the standards, Dan,
your data should meet the compliance.

614

Now that doesn't mean that your

When you set an internal policy you might

keep a portion of the data on site.

00:32:53.830 --> 00:32:55.270
And that's gonna be up to you but

on Microsoft's end they do

Well obviously Microsoft is,

They're trying to make sure that their

624
00:33:13.620 --> 00:33:16.140
And keeping your data

625

>> [LAUGHS]
>> All right, Wes,

we've got a bunch more so, unfortunately,

I think we're going to have to go

I do have more, but

Microsoft has compliant standards

Check them out at

00:33:42.600 --> 00:33:45.640

Thank you for watching, we're going

00:33:50.100 --> 00:33:51.900

00:33:51.900 --> 00:33:52.690

640
00:33:52.690 --> 00:33:54.367

641
00:33:54.367 --> 00:33:59.550
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel continue looking at cloud security requirements and policies. They start by explaining what level of trust you can have with Microsoft as your cloud service provider; maintaining the integrity of your data when in the hands of a third party and transparency of operations with said party. They also describe some of the security tactics used to protect your data when it is either sitting at rest on a server or traveling across the internet.
episodes.title: Cloud Security Part 2

So you can kind of see
this all coming together.

627
00:33:16.180 --> 00:33:17.760
We've talked about the availability,
right?

628
00:33:17.760 --> 00:33:20.801
For the data centers themselves,
maintaining a fault tolerance

629
00:33:20.801 --> 00:33:23.940
copy of information across
the data centers if they need to.

630
00:33:23.940 --> 00:33:26.990
Integrity, meaning we're constantly
monitoring your information,

631
00:33:26.990 --> 00:33:30.650
making sure that it hasn't
been tampered with and

632
00:33:30.650 --> 00:33:34.225
then finally we're using TLF so
I kinda did that backwards.

633
00:33:34.225 --> 00:33:37.900
[LAUGH] AIC but that's the CIA,
Confidentiality, Integrity,

634
00:33:37.900 --> 00:33:38.490
and Availability.

635
00:33:38.490 --> 00:33:40.490
And then they also have things, like for

636
00:33:40.490 --> 00:33:43.646
instance, the exchange
online threat protection.

637
00:33:43.646 --> 00:33:47.357
We think about emails,
we think about spam protection,

638
00:33:47.357 --> 00:33:52.540
we think about malicious attachments,
you know it's just things like this.

639
00:33:52.540 --> 00:33:57.230
The Exchange Online threat management or
threat protection

640
00:33:57.230 --> 00:34:02.360
does help protect things like your email
from spam and just all types of malware.

641
00:34:02.360 --> 00:34:05.160
I was gonna say adware, but
that falls under the umbrella of malware.

642
00:34:05.160 --> 00:34:10.650
So we can see a layered
defense system as well.

643
00:34:10.650 --> 00:34:12.578
You can go as far as user controls.

644
00:34:12.578 --> 00:34:17.470
They implement S/MIME as your rights
management, so if you're doing DRM,

645
00:34:17.470 --> 00:34:19.950
Digital Rights Management,
you can implement that as well, and

646
00:34:19.950 --> 00:34:23.720
you can maintain what happens to your
information once it leaves their networks.

647
00:34:23.720 --> 00:34:26.830
In fact, we had a great
discussion off camera about that.

648
00:34:26.830 --> 00:34:30.700
Is that you know okay, now the encryption
has happened between myself,

649
00:34:30.700 --> 00:34:32.700
the web browser, and Microsoft,

650
00:34:32.700 --> 00:34:36.450
what happens when it leaves Microsoft's
networks and goes to somebody else?

651
00:34:36.450 --> 00:34:39.350
Do you lose your ability to maintain
security on your information

652
00:34:39.350 --> 00:34:40.450
after the fact?

653
00:34:40.450 --> 00:34:41.570
And the answer is no.

654
00:34:41.570 --> 00:34:46.410
They do implement the secure
multimedia Internet mail extensions

655
00:34:46.410 --> 00:34:50.510
as well as some additional technology so
that you can make sure the information is

656
00:34:50.510 --> 00:34:53.770
still secure and
maintained after it leaves their networks.

657
00:34:53.770 --> 00:34:56.980
And then they also have admin controls,
and we've already really covered that, so

658
00:34:56.980 --> 00:34:58.840
I'm not gonna to go too much over that,

659
00:34:58.840 --> 00:35:00.930
that's back to that
physical security as well.

660
00:35:00.930 --> 00:35:04.590
You know, making sure those strict
auditing processes, strong passwords,

661
00:35:04.590 --> 00:35:08.000
biometrics and
even mobile management capabilities too.

662
00:35:08.000 --> 00:35:11.560
So they do, I think,
a really good job in this.

663
00:35:11.560 --> 00:35:16.170
Remember it's a five layer approach and

664
00:35:16.170 --> 00:35:21.080
if you want more information on that five
layered approach, not as it relates maybe

665
00:35:21.080 --> 00:35:24.120
specifically to this example, but for
your own benefit cuz it's good to know,

666
00:35:24.120 --> 00:35:27.710
you can always go to Microsoft's tech net
and just type into the tech net search

667
00:35:27.710 --> 00:35:31.130
engine, defense in depth and
you'll get a whole entire,

668
00:35:31.130 --> 00:35:34.400
probably more information than you really
want but you can really check it out.

669
00:35:34.400 --> 00:35:36.050
>> Awesome.
Well it sounds like Microsoft

670
00:35:36.050 --> 00:35:40.090
is giving us a reasonable assurance of
security for the data that we are storing

671
00:35:40.090 --> 00:35:45.030
with them as we enter into a contract
with them really, to store our data.

672
00:35:45.030 --> 00:35:48.690
That's a good thing,
that's what we want and that allows us

673
00:35:48.690 --> 00:35:53.900
to be a little more inclined maybe to
move to some sort of cloud services.

674
00:35:53.900 --> 00:35:57.070
I know that I actually really like
cloud services, it's awesome stuff.

675
00:35:57.070 --> 00:35:58.980
>> You know, and Dan,
I'm glad you mentioned that.

676
00:35:58.980 --> 00:36:03.630
On that note, just one more thing
is that you know there is a big

677
00:36:03.630 --> 00:36:07.460
scare in corporate environments as,
hey, is the cloud safe?

678
00:36:07.460 --> 00:36:11.850
Do we have these safety mechanisms and
measures in place?

679
00:36:11.850 --> 00:36:15.730
Can I trust the provider that I'm using?

680
00:36:15.730 --> 00:36:18.430
Well, I can't speak for
the other providers, I'm not sure, but

681
00:36:18.430 --> 00:36:21.640
I can tell you what,
Microsoft has done a really good job and

682
00:36:21.640 --> 00:36:26.000
they've got thorough documentation that
if you do have, you know maybe you're

683
00:36:26.000 --> 00:36:30.220
using the MTA cloud fundamentals to
maybe get a foothold into the team.

684
00:36:30.220 --> 00:36:32.070
Maybe you already have IT experience,
right?

685
00:36:32.070 --> 00:36:34.450
And you want to get a foothold
into the cloud team.

686
00:36:34.450 --> 00:36:37.830
Well, you've got enough documentation
right here that you can present it to

687
00:36:37.830 --> 00:36:39.900
somebody that maybe does
make those decisions, and

688
00:36:39.900 --> 00:36:43.350
say look, here's the documentation,
and yes, you can trust it.

689
00:36:43.350 --> 00:36:43.870
>> Awesome.

690
00:36:43.870 --> 00:36:47.765
Well, Wes, thank you so much for
for joining us today and showing us

691
00:36:47.765 --> 00:36:51.735
what we can do as far as security wise
when it comes to Microsoft Cloud services.

692
00:36:51.735 --> 00:36:54.425
That being said it looks like we've
wrapped up yet another episode.

693
00:36:54.425 --> 00:36:56.725
Thank you again and
thank you for watching.

694
00:36:56.725 --> 00:36:57.915
We always enjoy our viewers.

695
00:36:57.915 --> 00:36:59.865
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for IT Pro TV.

696
00:36:59.865 --> 00:37:01.735
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

697
00:37:01.735 --> 00:37:02.435
>> And I'm Wes Ryan.

698
00:37:02.435 --> 00:37:03.777
>> We'll see you next time.

699
00:37:03.777 --> 00:37:08.003
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel go over the benefits of using cloud services. Topics covered include, Scalability, or the ability to grow or shrink the scale of the service when necessary, Redundancy which increases fault tolerance, and Availability of services and data. They also explain the difference between what is meant by customizable vs. configurable.
episodes.title: Using Cloud Services
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.089 --> 00:00:10.089
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.838 --> 00:00:16.563
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.563 --> 00:00:18.140
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:18.140 --> 00:00:19.280
And in today's episode, well,

5
00:00:19.280 --> 00:00:22.420
we're continuing on with our
MTA Cloud Fundamentals series.

6
00:00:22.420 --> 00:00:24.950
Joining me in the studio today,
well, it's my good friend and

7
00:00:24.950 --> 00:00:27.810
master of all that is cloud,
Mr. Wes Bryan.

8
00:00:27.810 --> 00:00:29.030
Welcome to the show, Wes.

9
00:00:29.030 --> 00:00:29.700
>> Hey, how you doing?

10
00:00:29.700 --> 00:00:30.670
It's great to be here.

11
00:00:30.670 --> 00:00:34.330
And that's right, today we're gonna be
talking about using cloud services.

12
00:00:34.330 --> 00:00:36.460
We've got a little bit more
theory to throw at you guys here,

13
00:00:36.460 --> 00:00:39.350
because you do have to understand
some of the basic principles and

14
00:00:39.350 --> 00:00:43.930
concepts when you are going to make
a choice of using certain cloud services.

15
00:00:43.930 --> 00:00:48.320
One of the first things we are going
to talk about is capacity.

16
00:00:48.320 --> 00:00:52.306
That's one of the thing on the exam
you're gonna have to be aware of,

17
00:00:52.306 --> 00:00:55.284
is what does compassablity,
er compassability.

18
00:00:55.284 --> 00:00:56.620
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's two words there.

19
00:00:56.620 --> 00:01:01.130
That's the combination of capacity and
elasticity, capacity.

20
00:01:01.130 --> 00:01:01.908
>> I like that.

21
00:01:01.908 --> 00:01:02.557
>> We'll get it right, yeah?

22
00:01:02.557 --> 00:01:03.374
[LAUGH]
>> Good save there, Wes.

23
00:01:03.374 --> 00:01:03.954
Good save.

24
00:01:03.954 --> 00:01:04.907
>> [LAUGH] Yes, thank you.

25
00:01:04.907 --> 00:01:07.790
>> [LAUGH]
>> So capacity is about storage, right?

26
00:01:07.790 --> 00:01:11.430
When we talk about elasticity of
the cloud, what are we talking about?

27
00:01:11.430 --> 00:01:15.870
Well, we're talking about the ability
to add more storage as you need it.

28
00:01:15.870 --> 00:01:18.940
Now, remember in some of the previous
episodes we set the stage for

29
00:01:18.940 --> 00:01:19.950
on premise, right?

30
00:01:19.950 --> 00:01:25.050
When we talk about capacity on premise, we
have to add additional hard drives every

31
00:01:25.050 --> 00:01:29.470
time we accrue too much storage space or
we don't have enough storage space.

32
00:01:29.470 --> 00:01:31.410
And that's going to be
a sizable investment.

33
00:01:31.410 --> 00:01:34.560
And it's not only just a sizable
investment, it takes time, right?

34
00:01:34.560 --> 00:01:37.160
It's not going be something
that's gonna happen immediately.

35
00:01:37.160 --> 00:01:41.410
And that is one of the benefits when it
comes to using the Cloud, is the ability,

36
00:01:41.410 --> 00:01:43.830
for instance, inside of OneDrive.

37
00:01:43.830 --> 00:01:48.890
If I add additional users to my
infrastructure inside of the Cloud,

38
00:01:48.890 --> 00:01:55.510
then OneDrive automatically scales up
to ensure that I have plenty of access.

39
00:01:55.510 --> 00:01:57.150
And let me go ahead and
show you that here.

40
00:01:57.150 --> 00:02:00.910
I'm actually logged into the Office
365 Administration Center.

41
00:02:00.910 --> 00:02:04.880
If I was to add additional users here,
and I've got, let's see.

42
00:02:04.880 --> 00:02:07.360
I think I've got just
myself in here right now.

43
00:02:07.360 --> 00:02:10.390
And we'll add some users
coming up as well.

44
00:02:10.390 --> 00:02:15.050
If I needed to add, to scale out, right?

45
00:02:15.050 --> 00:02:20.150
Maybe I've got 500 users that
are coming in across my entire company.

46
00:02:20.150 --> 00:02:23.100
Well, I'm gonna have to
make sure that beforehand

47
00:02:23.100 --> 00:02:26.100
I made the plans to make sure that
I have enough hard drive space,

48
00:02:26.100 --> 00:02:31.180
we have enough computers, we have
to expand and be prepared for that.

49
00:02:31.180 --> 00:02:36.090
Here in the cloud, capacity is just
as easy as adding an end user.

50
00:02:36.090 --> 00:02:39.360
And as you add the end user, it provisions

51
00:02:39.360 --> 00:02:43.370
their location in OneDrive to ensure
that they can store their data as well.

52
00:02:43.370 --> 00:02:45.550
So when it comes to capacity,
Dan, I tell you,

53
00:02:45.550 --> 00:02:47.590
it's a really good thing
inside of the cloud.

54
00:02:47.590 --> 00:02:51.940
Because you can scale out,
right, you can increase

55
00:02:51.940 --> 00:02:56.850
the storage capacity that you need just
by simply adding an additional user.

56
00:02:56.850 --> 00:02:57.657
>> Yeah, it's awesome.

57
00:02:57.657 --> 00:03:00.800
When you're thinking of capacity,
you've gotta think of it as a container.

58
00:03:00.800 --> 00:03:02.970
What does this container hold?

59
00:03:02.970 --> 00:03:05.240
And Wes is making that
point very succinctly.

60
00:03:05.240 --> 00:03:08.160
That okay, I've got 500 users, right.

61
00:03:08.160 --> 00:03:09.827
That's my capacity right now.

62
00:03:09.827 --> 00:03:13.080
And then he started talking
about that old scalability.

63
00:03:13.080 --> 00:03:14.690
What happens when I go beyond 500 users?

64
00:03:14.690 --> 00:03:18.690
What happens when I need more than that
two terabyte drive that I've got in there?

65
00:03:18.690 --> 00:03:19.990
How do I scale it up?

66
00:03:19.990 --> 00:03:22.370
And that really begs a good question, Wes.

67
00:03:22.370 --> 00:03:23.270
How does,

68
00:03:23.270 --> 00:03:26.010
inside of the cloud, what are we talking
about when it comes to scalability?

69
00:03:26.010 --> 00:03:30.090
How well does this scale, what can I
think of when it comes to scalability?

70
00:03:30.090 --> 00:03:33.880
>> Well, one of the big things that
that's really contingent on is

71
00:03:33.880 --> 00:03:37.280
what size company do you have,
versus what subscription plan do you have.

72
00:03:37.280 --> 00:03:41.390
Now we're going to look really in depth
at the subscription plans, coming up.

73
00:03:41.390 --> 00:03:43.584
But you have to know that
when it comes to scalability,

74
00:03:43.584 --> 00:03:44.710
that's really what it's based on.

75
00:03:44.710 --> 00:03:46.690
And let me show you what I mean here.

76
00:03:46.690 --> 00:03:51.650
Now, when you need to consider,
how many users do I need?

77
00:03:51.650 --> 00:03:53.600
How big is my company gonna be?

78
00:03:53.600 --> 00:03:56.950
Well, that's really gonna be based
on whatever plan you choose here.

79
00:03:56.950 --> 00:03:57.690
So for instance,

80
00:03:57.690 --> 00:04:01.579
let me show you just small business,
the small business plan options.

81
00:04:02.600 --> 00:04:06.110
And like I said, we'll be taking
a look at this a little bit more.

82
00:04:06.110 --> 00:04:09.260
If I scroll all the way
down here to the bottom,

83
00:04:09.260 --> 00:04:12.400
I can see that if I have this service,
if I'm using it,

84
00:04:12.400 --> 00:04:17.700
subscribed to this service and paying that
monthly fee, then I only have 300 users.

85
00:04:17.700 --> 00:04:20.810
So now, in the scenario that I set and
threw at you, I said well,

86
00:04:20.810 --> 00:04:22.150
we've got 500 new users.

87
00:04:22.150 --> 00:04:26.080
Maybe we got 50 users across 10 different
locations that are now starting,

88
00:04:26.080 --> 00:04:27.270
cuz we're expanding our business.

89
00:04:27.270 --> 00:04:30.790
Well, the problem is this plan
isn't gonna be good for you, right.

90
00:04:30.790 --> 00:04:32.890
It's gonna scale up to around 300 users.

91
00:04:32.890 --> 00:04:35.920
And then anything after that,
well, it's just not gonna work.

92
00:04:35.920 --> 00:04:39.580
So the good thing is,
if that's not what you need, well,

93
00:04:39.580 --> 00:04:41.170
they've got other options here for you.

94
00:04:41.170 --> 00:04:43.990
And on one of the main pages here,
they talk about the Enterprise level.

95
00:04:43.990 --> 00:04:48.707
And if we scroll all the way down to the
bottom, one of the things that I should

96
00:04:48.707 --> 00:04:53.277
see somewhere in here is the fact that
the users are, I'll tell you what,

97
00:04:53.277 --> 00:04:55.732
let me go ahead and select the E1 here.

98
00:04:55.732 --> 00:04:58.798
And at the bottom of the E1 plan,
I believe,

99
00:04:58.798 --> 00:05:02.930
is where you'll see that there
is unlimited users, right.

100
00:05:02.930 --> 00:05:04.580
You don't have a limit.

101
00:05:04.580 --> 00:05:10.020
And I'm lying to you there, it doesn't
seem to show it right there at the top.

102
00:05:10.020 --> 00:05:15.167
So, let me go ahead and
just back up here just a second.

103
00:05:15.167 --> 00:05:16.620
And it's probably right at the top.

104
00:05:18.470 --> 00:05:20.870
Yep, it is, so they switched it around.

105
00:05:20.870 --> 00:05:23.900
It's on the bottom of the first page,
it's on the top of the second page here.

106
00:05:23.900 --> 00:05:26.010
And notice, users maximum.

107
00:05:26.010 --> 00:05:27.000
Unlimited, right?

108
00:05:27.000 --> 00:05:30.640
So when you get into things
like Enterprise level plans,

109
00:05:30.640 --> 00:05:32.710
you don't have a limit on how many users.

110
00:05:32.710 --> 00:05:38.660
So by association too, you don't really
have a limit on storage capacity.

111
00:05:38.660 --> 00:05:41.060
Now pay attention to the plan
that you're gonna use,

112
00:05:41.060 --> 00:05:44.430
because that will dictate exactly
how much storage you can use.

113
00:05:44.430 --> 00:05:47.720
But the good thing here is
when it comes to scalability,

114
00:05:47.720 --> 00:05:51.200
if I need to add those 500 users,
I need to add 1000 users,

115
00:05:51.200 --> 00:05:55.810
I need to add beyond 3000 users,
I can do that very easy.

116
00:05:55.810 --> 00:06:00.830
And it's just that simple as making sure
that you purchase the plan that you need.

117
00:06:00.830 --> 00:06:05.120
>> Now, Wes, if I find out, let's say
that for whatever reasons my comany has

118
00:06:05.120 --> 00:06:08.390
hit hard times and
I've had to lay off half of my staff.

119
00:06:08.390 --> 00:06:11.670
And hopefully that never happens, but
sometimes that kind of thing does.

120
00:06:11.670 --> 00:06:13.250
Am I able to scale the other way as well?

121
00:06:13.250 --> 00:06:17.290
Can I change my plan to go to
something smaller, reduce my costs?

122
00:06:17.290 --> 00:06:19.130
>> Unfortunately, you can't do that.

123
00:06:19.130 --> 00:06:24.140
One of the things, and that's why
they say when you purchase a plan,

124
00:06:24.140 --> 00:06:27.120
know exactly what plan you're gonna
be purchasing based on your needs.

125
00:06:27.120 --> 00:06:32.950
Because once you set your tenant,
you can't change it, right.

126
00:06:32.950 --> 00:06:34.420
You're gonna turn around, and

127
00:06:34.420 --> 00:06:36.755
what's gonna happen here is you're
gonna have to start all over again.

128
00:06:36.755 --> 00:06:38.615
You're gonna have to rename a new tenant.

129
00:06:38.615 --> 00:06:42.915
So that's why it's very important that you
need to still do some planning, right.

130
00:06:42.915 --> 00:06:45.577
I say scalability, we're not moving
to the Cloud and all of the sudden,

131
00:06:45.577 --> 00:06:47.815
we moved to the Cloud here and
we don't have to plan anymore.

132
00:06:47.815 --> 00:06:51.395
It is not that way, you still have
to plan just like on premise.

133
00:06:51.395 --> 00:06:54.825
And you have to plan to what you
think you're company is gonna do.

134
00:06:54.825 --> 00:06:56.315
Maybe you are gonna be a small business,

135
00:06:56.315 --> 00:07:00.360
maybe you don't think you're
gonna ever grow passed 300 users.

136
00:07:00.360 --> 00:07:01.500
Well, then you're okay.

137
00:07:01.500 --> 00:07:04.150
But if you know, and you have planned and

138
00:07:04.150 --> 00:07:08.250
you've the foresight that you're
gonna go beyond 300 users,

139
00:07:08.250 --> 00:07:12.980
then what's gonna happen here is you're
gonna have to rename that tenant.

140
00:07:12.980 --> 00:07:17.280
Now the other thing to keep mind is
that if you do delete those users,

141
00:07:17.280 --> 00:07:19.220
one of the things you'll
have to just understand is,

142
00:07:19.220 --> 00:07:21.120
you just don't get charged anymore for
them.

143
00:07:21.120 --> 00:07:23.312
All right?
So even if you do scale down like that,

144
00:07:23.312 --> 00:07:24.776
you can scale down like that.

145
00:07:24.776 --> 00:07:28.115
If you do have to, and
hopefully it doesn't happen that way, but

146
00:07:28.115 --> 00:07:30.110
you do have to lay off some people.

147
00:07:30.110 --> 00:07:32.140
Well, you just don't get charged anymore,
right.

148
00:07:32.140 --> 00:07:35.980
You can do things like soft deletes too,
where they're still in your database, but

149
00:07:35.980 --> 00:07:37.440

underlying in the way and

598
00:32:42.900 --> 00:32:43.960
the nature of it.

599
00:32:43.960 --> 00:32:47.840
It's where configuration is
there is an option inside

600
00:32:47.840 --> 00:32:53.050
of the service that's already there and
I can just modify it to my liking.

601
00:32:53.050 --> 00:32:56.280
And that's the difference too, I'm not
making an actual change to the service

602
00:32:56.280 --> 00:33:01.200
itself, just a, a more like, and
Wes has red and I have blue.

603
00:33:01.200 --> 00:33:02.738
>> Yep.
>> The service is still the same,

604
00:33:02.738 --> 00:33:07.040
it's just Wes' is red and
mine is blue, that's configuration.

605
00:33:07.040 --> 00:33:09.650
It's a custom configuration
because Wes chose red,

606
00:33:09.650 --> 00:33:12.120
I chose blue, great that's nice.

607
00:33:12.120 --> 00:33:13.920
But we're not changing
the underlying service.

608
00:33:13.920 --> 00:33:15.080
>> That's exactly it.

609
00:33:15.080 --> 00:33:19.220
You don't have access to change something
that ultimately will affect everybody,

610
00:33:19.220 --> 00:33:21.230
every customer that has
an Office 365 account.

611
00:33:21.230 --> 00:33:22.060
>> All right.

612
00:33:22.060 --> 00:33:22.860
Well, Wes, this is.

613
00:33:22.860 --> 00:33:25.085
I know it can sound a little confusing.

614
00:33:25.085 --> 00:33:26.060
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's a little daunting.

615
00:33:26.060 --> 00:33:27.820
Don't let it overwhelm you.

616
00:33:27.820 --> 00:33:28.790
Just take in.

617
00:33:28.790 --> 00:33:30.670
As long as you understand
the basic concepts.

618
00:33:30.670 --> 00:33:33.980
You don't need to know how to change
tiles or colors or anything like that.

619
00:33:33.980 --> 00:33:37.150
We just want you to make sure that
you know what the difference between

620
00:33:37.150 --> 00:33:42.260
customization and configuration
is when it comes to exam time.

621
00:33:42.260 --> 00:33:44.640
Want to make sure you have
that differentiation down.

622
00:33:44.640 --> 00:33:46.750
Wes is there anything
else we need to go over?

623
00:33:46.750 --> 00:33:47.710
>> No.
>> Before we close the show.

624
00:33:47.710 --> 00:33:49.500
>> No,
I think we've covered it on that one.

625
00:33:49.500 --> 00:33:52.170
>> All right, well thank you so
much for explaining this to us.

626
00:33:52.170 --> 00:33:53.720
Cloud concepts can be very,

627
00:33:53.720 --> 00:33:56.680
very difficult to understand and
I think you did a really good job.

628
00:33:56.680 --> 00:33:58.360
I appreciate you showing up for this show.

629
00:33:58.360 --> 00:34:00.010
We definitely appreciate
our viewers out there.

630
00:34:00.010 --> 00:34:01.440
Thank you so much for watching.

631
00:34:01.440 --> 00:34:02.940
We're gonna go ahead and
close it down, though.

632
00:34:02.940 --> 00:34:05.950
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

633
00:34:05.950 --> 00:34:06.620
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

634
00:34:06.620 --> 00:34:08.150
>> And we will see you next time.

635
00:34:08.150 --> 00:34:14.320
[MUSIC].

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel cover updates and availability to your data and cloud services. They go through each of the cloud service types(IaaS/PaaS/SaaS) and explain what the customer and the provider is responsible for with regards to updates and availability. They also show you how to use the provided heath monitoring system to spot and prepare for provider issues.
episodes.title: Cloud Updates and Availability
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.591 --> 00:00:17.073
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:17.073 --> 00:00:19.741
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.741 --> 00:00:23.040
we're continuing on with our
MTA Cloud Fundamentals series.

5
00:00:23.040 --> 00:00:24.570
And joining me here in the studio yet

6
00:00:24.570 --> 00:00:27.550
again is none other than
Wes the Weatherman, Bryan.

7
00:00:27.550 --> 00:00:29.190
[LAUGH] Welcome to the studio, Wes.

8
00:00:29.190 --> 00:00:30.750
>> The weather's great today, Dan.

9
00:00:30.750 --> 00:00:33.620
And in this episode, we're gonna
be talking about cloud updates and

10
00:00:33.620 --> 00:00:34.330
availability.

11
00:00:34.330 --> 00:00:37.540
And it's gonna be important,
these concepts, when we think about it,

12
00:00:37.540 --> 00:00:38.680
because imagine this.

13
00:00:38.680 --> 00:00:41.760
They're gonna be rolling out
updates to your platforms.

14
00:00:41.760 --> 00:00:44.860
You're gonna, as a paying customer,
we've talked about availability and

15
00:00:44.860 --> 00:00:49.440
having access to that information,
your different applications, and

16
00:00:49.440 --> 00:00:52.070
there is a way that you can monitor and
maintain that.

17
00:00:52.070 --> 00:00:55.750
But, we're gonna go ahead and
take a step back and we're gonna revisit.

18
00:00:55.750 --> 00:00:59.640
When we talk about cloud services, what
do we mean when we say cloud services?

19
00:00:59.640 --> 00:01:02.809
Well, we're gonna start at the bottom
of the cloud computing stack, and

20
00:01:02.809 --> 00:01:06.040
we'll start with, remember,
the infrastructure as a service, right.

21
00:01:06.040 --> 00:01:10.432
This is where your VMs and your hardware
comes into place, as far as hey,

22
00:01:10.432 --> 00:01:13.384
I need a virtual machine,
I need it configured,

23
00:01:13.384 --> 00:01:16.128
as well as things like
platform as a service.

24
00:01:16.128 --> 00:01:19.260
Remember that platform as a service,
we need to develop things like

25
00:01:19.260 --> 00:01:21.060
applications or
your company might need to.

26
00:01:21.060 --> 00:01:24.550
And you need that run time and
execution environment in order for

27
00:01:24.550 --> 00:01:26.360
those applications to run.

28
00:01:26.360 --> 00:01:29.890
Then finally one of the top
of the cloud computing stack,

29
00:01:29.890 --> 00:01:34.140
which is what your end users most commonly
are going to be interacting with,

30
00:01:34.140 --> 00:01:35.790
is the software of the service.

31
00:01:35.790 --> 00:01:39.390
So keep in mind those three services.

32
00:01:39.390 --> 00:01:42.160
The infrastructure as a service,
platform as a service, and

33
00:01:42.160 --> 00:01:43.600
also the software as a service.

34
00:01:43.600 --> 00:01:45.170
>> Yeah, that's right,
that we have all three of those.

35
00:01:45.170 --> 00:01:48.211
You gotta make sure that you're
understanding each one of those,

36
00:01:48.211 --> 00:01:50.480
so it's a good idea
that we revisited that.

37
00:01:50.480 --> 00:01:54.450
But Wes, is there an order of operations
with which we should tackle this, or

38
00:01:54.450 --> 00:01:55.940
does anything go?

39
00:01:55.940 --> 00:01:59.530
>> Well, there really is a good
order of operations, if you will,

40
00:01:59.530 --> 00:02:01.390
because we gotta look at
a couple of concepts, right?

41
00:02:01.390 --> 00:02:03.190
We gotta look at responsibility.

42
00:02:03.190 --> 00:02:04.560
That's really what it comes down to.

43
00:02:04.560 --> 00:02:08.700
And when I say a couple of concepts
is customer responsibility,

44
00:02:08.700 --> 00:02:12.490
the person that is paying the monthly
subscription for the service versus what

45
00:02:12.490 --> 00:02:17.480
the provider's responsibility is to
the customer that you might be paying.

46
00:02:17.480 --> 00:02:21.108
So one of the first ones we gotta look
at is infrastructure as a service and

47
00:02:21.108 --> 00:02:24.677
that meaning that there are some
responsibilities that are a little bit

48
00:02:24.677 --> 00:02:27.900
different than the other services
that are provided, right?

49
00:02:27.900 --> 00:02:31.280
So if you think about
infrastructure as a service, and

50
00:02:31.280 --> 00:02:33.400
maybe I need a web server,
right, so what do I do?

51
00:02:33.400 --> 00:02:37.170
We go to something like
the Azure login page,

52
00:02:37.170 --> 00:02:40.650
your administration page, and
you spin up a virtual machine.

53
00:02:40.650 --> 00:02:43.920
Maybe you have to put,
what is it, IIS on it, or

54
00:02:43.920 --> 00:02:47.210
maybe you gotta spin up
an Apache machine out there.

55
00:02:47.210 --> 00:02:49.910
Well you do the configurations, right?

56
00:02:49.910 --> 00:02:51.540
Well what is your responsibility?

57
00:02:51.540 --> 00:02:56.420
Well when it comes to that as that
portion of the cloud computing stack,

58
00:02:56.420 --> 00:02:58.500
you have to think about it this way.

59
00:02:58.500 --> 00:03:02.340
What if you bring up a web server,
right, and

60
00:03:02.340 --> 00:03:07.020
you've provisioned it basically to support
a certain amount of performance, right?

61
00:03:07.020 --> 00:03:11.320
And then all of a sudden, you get just
a massive amount of traffic, right?

62
00:03:11.320 --> 00:03:12.680
We want success here.

63
00:03:12.680 --> 00:03:14.830
Well, imagine your success is overnight.

64
00:03:14.830 --> 00:03:19.260
Well, now I've got a web server out
there that maybe isn't performing

65
00:03:19.260 --> 00:03:20.260
the way I want it to.

66
00:03:20.260 --> 00:03:24.850
It can't service all of those individual

67
00:03:24.850 --> 00:03:27.200
requests from people
constantly visiting it.

68
00:03:27.200 --> 00:03:29.826
Well, that's my
responsibility as a customer.

69
00:03:29.826 --> 00:03:34.243
Right, the other thing that comes along
with that too, as the customer is,

70
00:03:34.243 --> 00:03:37.487
imagine the operating system
that's running on that or

71
00:03:37.487 --> 00:03:42.269
the application that's running inside of
that server or even a modular add-on.

72
00:03:42.269 --> 00:03:45.828
Maybe you've got a Windows 2012 Server R2,
and

73
00:03:45.828 --> 00:03:49.190
you've got a role that you've configured.

74
00:03:49.190 --> 00:03:51.540
Well, you need to make sure that,
as a customer,

75
00:03:51.540 --> 00:03:54.920
you're configuring that right and
that's not the provider's problem.

76
00:03:54.920 --> 00:03:58.360
Also, when updates come out, right,
you guys, probably familiar,

77
00:03:58.360 --> 00:04:02.090
that computers, operating systems,
are constantly updating.

78
00:04:02.090 --> 00:04:03.960
Well, you've gotta worry about that, too.

79
00:04:03.960 --> 00:04:09.300
That's not the provider's job to
update a certain functionality,

80
00:04:09.300 --> 00:04:11.680
or even the operating system itself.

81
00:04:11.680 --> 00:04:13.600
So, you do have other things.

82
00:04:13.600 --> 00:04:17.020
So, you gotta, for instance,
patches, right, security.

83
00:04:17.020 --> 00:04:21.240
It isn't gonna be Microsoft that is gonna
come in and run the security configuration

84
00:04:21.240 --> 00:04:23.750
wizard inside of your server
that you've just configured,

85
00:04:23.750 --> 00:04:26.810
making sure that it is secure.

86
00:04:26.810 --> 00:04:28.600
That's your responsibility.

87
00:04:28.600 --> 00:04:31.720
Now, on the provider's side,
now the provider does

88
00:04:31.720 --> 00:04:35.320
have some kinda responsibility in
infrastructure as a service, right?

89
00:04:35.320 --> 00:04:39.230
The underlying hardware that you don't
see, they have to maintain, right?

90
00:04:39.230 --> 00:04:42.310
The servers that are running
your virtualized servers,

91
00:04:42.310 --> 00:04:43.180
they need to maintain.

92
00:04:43.180 --> 00:04:45.420
They need to maintain things
like the network connection so

93
00:04:45.420 --> 00:04:46.420
that you can connect to it.

94
00:04:46.420 --> 00:04:50.210
So when we look at the infrastructure
as a service, that first one Dan,

95
00:04:50.210 --> 00:04:54.720
this is one of those types of
cloud services that, well,

96
00:04:54.720 --> 00:04:59.810
there is something, a lot of it that's
in the customer's side of the court.

97
00:04:59.810 --> 00:05:01.650
The basketball court if you will.

98
00:05:01.650 --> 00:05:02.730
At the same time,

99
00:05:02.730 --> 00:05:06.640
there's also some that's on the provider
side of the basketball court as well.

100
00:05:06.640 --> 00:05:09.530
>> Yeah, it's really interesting
how the two of us actually get to

101
00:05:09.530 --> 00:05:10.770
work together, right?

102
00:05:10.770 --> 00:05:14.620
Me as a customer or you as a customer and
then the service provider themselves.

103
00:05:14.620 --> 00:05:16.120
They have the platform, right?

104
00:05:16.120 --> 00:05:21.070
They've got that hardware, if a hard drive
goes dead, I don't have to get up at 2 AM,

105
00:05:21.070 --> 00:05:24.640
thank goodness, and
go replace a hard drive.

106
00:05:24.640 --> 00:05:27.520
And for one thing, that would be very,
very difficult cuz my server is probably

107
00:05:27.520 --> 00:05:30.890
in another state and
maybe even in another country.

108
00:05:30.890 --> 00:05:33.630
That would be a little bit difficult for
me to maintain

109
00:05:33.630 --> 00:05:37.000
some level of availability through
making sure the hardware's running.

110
00:05:37.000 --> 00:05:40.200
That's the service provider's
responsibility, right?

111
00:05:40.200 --> 00:05:41.990
That's what I'm paying for.

112
00:05:41.990 --> 00:05:46.490
And I'm getting a crack team of highly
trained, highly skilled individuals

113
00:05:46.490 --> 00:05:50.360
that are making sure that those things
remain available and up to date.

114
00:05:50.360 --> 00:05:52.330
So, if there's like, where Wes said,

115
00:05:52.330 --> 00:05:55.520
we got hypervisors that are running
all of our virtual machines.

116
00:05:55.520 --> 00:05:59.510
I might have a, so like you said,
a server 2012 R2 machine, but

117
00:05:59.510 --> 00:06:00.930
that's running on
a virtualized environment.

118
00:06:00.930 --> 00:06:03.500
That's a virtual server running
on top of a hypervisor.

119
00:06:03.500 --> 00:06:08.900
That's in a real, physical server
somewhere in this world happening.

120
00:06:08.900 --> 00:06:10.330
Who takes care of the hypervisor?

121
00:06:10.330 --> 00:06:13.220
That isn't me,
it's the service provider themself.

122
00:06:13.220 --> 00:06:14.630
So Microsoft's gonna handle that.

123
00:06:14.630 --> 00:06:16.960
Those are the things
they're responsible for.

124
00:06:16.960 --> 00:06:19.870
I am responsible though for
maintaining my software updates.

125
00:06:19.870 --> 00:06:22.540
I've installed software,
I've gotta make sure it stays up to date.

126
00:06:22.540 --> 00:06:24.150
That it runs correctly, that it's secure.

127
00:06:24.150 --> 00:06:26.010
If antivirus is needed,
that's gotta be done.

128
00:06:26.010 --> 00:06:28.180
That's on me as a customer.

129
00:06:28.180 --> 00:06:30.270
So we kind of work hand in hand with that.

130
00:06:30.270 --> 00:06:35.003
And it's a good thing cuz I don't want
them making decisions about my environment

131
00:06:35.003 --> 00:06:39.529
that I don't think is right, maybe they
have a different velocity of design or

132
00:06:39.529 --> 00:06:41.400
implementation that I don't.

133
00:06:41.400 --> 00:06:44.955
It could be different, so
it's good that you have that ability.

134
00:06:44.955 --> 00:06:48.385
But that's the whole nature of
infrastructure as a service

135
00:06:48.385 --> 00:06:51.155
that leads us into the other
platforms as well.

136
00:06:51.155 --> 00:06:52.035
>> That's right.

137
00:06:52.035 --> 00:06:55.045
The second one, the middle of the stack,
you can see, platform as a service.

138
00:06:55.045 --> 00:06:57.215
Keep in mind that we have our hardware.

139
00:06:57.215 --> 00:07:00.895
We have operating systems, but
now we have applications that need to run.

140
00:07:00.895 --> 00:07:05.090
And platform as a service is one that when
it really comes down to it, the majority

141
00:07:05.090 --> 00:07:09.920
of the problems that might happen
are really on the provider side, right?

142
00:07:09.920 --> 00:07:14.363
They need to make sure that the runtime
environment is there and available.

143
00:07:14.363 --> 00:07:16.893
But there is a small portion of it,
obviously,

144
00:07:16.893 --> 00:07:20.896
that is going to be customer driven,
and the customer has to be aware of it.

145
00:07:20.896 --> 00:07:23.248
Like for instance,
Member Platform is a service,

146
00:07:23.248 --> 00:07:25.510
helps you to develop applications, right?

147
00:07:25.510 --> 00:07:29.090
And your dev team doesn't wanna have to
spend the time in building the environment

148
00:07:29.090 --> 00:07:33.120
anytime they test an application,
only to test it to have it fail, and

149
00:07:33.120 --> 00:07:34.380
then have to rebuild it again.

150
00:07:34.380 --> 00:07:37.430
Well, that doesn't really change too much
in the cloud, the difference is you've got

151
00:07:37.430 --> 00:07:41.660
the benefit of templates and
virtualization, so you can roll it back.

152
00:07:41.660 --> 00:07:44.110
So there is some portion
of it that is the customer.

153
00:07:45.190 --> 00:07:46.374
Applications are developed wrong,

154
00:07:46.374 --> 00:07:48.289
that's not gonna be Microsoft's
problem to get in there.

155
00:07:48.289 --> 00:07:52.224
Their dev team gets in there and
figures out where your code went wrong and

156
00:07:52.224 --> 00:07:53.329
what you did wrong.

157
00:07:53.329 --> 00:07:54.629
They're not gonna troubleshoot that for
you.

158
00:07:54.629 --> 00:07:56.266
That's up to you to troubleshoot.

159
00:07:56.266 --> 00:08:00.651
On their end, what they need to manage and
maintain is to make sure that execution

160
00:08:00.651 --> 00:08:05.293
environment, regardless of the language,
you know, that their API that allows you

161
00:08:05.293 --> 00:08:10.090
to connect to that run-time environment is
available and they manage and maintain it.

162
00:08:10.090 --> 00:08:13.000
So this is one of the ones
where you look at it,

163
00:08:13.000 --> 00:08:14.700
and it starts at the bottom of the stack,
right,

164
00:08:14.700 --> 00:08:18.640
more responsibility on the customer's end,
and this starts to reduce a little bit,

165
00:08:18.640 --> 00:08:23.130
where there is some level of
customer responsibility then, but

166
00:08:23.130 --> 00:08:28.400
still the responsibility lies more with
the provider when it comes to platform.

167
00:08:28.400 --> 00:08:32.530
>> Yeah, it's a very little responsibility
when it comes to the customer with PaaS,

168
00:08:32.530 --> 00:08:35.730
right because what's provided by PaaS?

169
00:08:35.730 --> 00:08:39.170
It is the virtual machine,
the virtual environment on which

170
00:08:39.170 --> 00:08:41.940
the platform of whatever you're running,
C++ or

171
00:08:41.940 --> 00:08:46.210
Java or Ruby on Rails, or all of these
different environments that are available,

172
00:08:46.210 --> 00:08:50.570
that is provided by them so,
they're responsible for maintaining it.

173
00:08:50.570 --> 00:08:52.480
Now, this can get confusing I know.

174
00:08:52.480 --> 00:08:57.400
Because if I'm running IaaS,
I can provision a virtual machine,

175
00:08:57.400 --> 00:09:02.970
put a server on there, install Python,
and then start developing applications.

176
00:09:02.970 --> 00:09:06.280
And you're thinking, great,
now it's basically platform as a service.

177
00:09:06.280 --> 00:09:09.530
I can get them to maintain my server and,
no that's now how it works.

178
00:09:09.530 --> 00:09:11.100
So don't get confused by that.

179
00:09:11.100 --> 00:09:13.924
If you're running
infrastructure as a service,

180
00:09:13.924 --> 00:09:18.163
if you're provisioning virtual
machines and installing environments,

181
00:09:18.163 --> 00:09:22.534
like Wes said, run-time environments,
the APIs, the C++, the Javas,

182
00:09:22.534 --> 00:09:27.130
the Rubys, the Pythons, it's your job
at that point to maintain those things.

183
00:09:27.130 --> 00:09:29.330
Keep them up to date and
make sure they're operational.

184
00:09:29.330 --> 00:09:32.690
It's not Microsoft's job to do that,
at that point.

185
00:09:32.690 --> 00:09:37.664
If you choose platform as a service where
they provide you a pre-built platform,

186
00:09:37.664 --> 00:09:40.320
then it does fall on their shoulders.

187
00:09:40.320 --> 00:09:42.004
They are responsible, at that point,

188
00:09:42.004 --> 00:09:44.923
because all they do is providing you
an area and which to develop on.

189
00:09:44.923 --> 00:09:48.059
Their developers are gonna go in and
their gonna create an application.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel go over requirements and dependencies for using cloud services, specifically Office365 and InTune. They start by looking at things like planning the network, opening firewalls, client requirements, and bandwidth needs. Next they look at the service plans available and the costs involved.

We don't have a lot of money to purchase
I7 processors and stuff in our machines,

486
00:26:43.847 --> 00:26:46.146
and the graphics cards,
and the hard drives, but

487
00:26:46.146 --> 00:26:47.808
you can connect with a thin client.

488
00:26:47.808 --> 00:26:49.012
You don't need much power here,

489
00:26:49.012 --> 00:26:51.590
because everything's gonna be done
through the web browser itself.

490
00:26:51.590 --> 00:26:53.410
So, if you do use this plan,

491
00:26:53.410 --> 00:26:55.820
make sure you got a good internet
connection on whatever the device is,

492
00:26:55.820 --> 00:26:58.840
because everything is gonna be handled
through that internet connection.

493
00:27:01.010 --> 00:27:04.950
Now, the next one,
is the Office 365 Business.

494
00:27:04.950 --> 00:27:07.749
Now, there's no email in this one.

495
00:27:09.200 --> 00:27:10.560
I found that interesting.

496
00:27:10.560 --> 00:27:11.390
>> That is very interesting,

497
00:27:11.390 --> 00:27:14.850
cuz you would think that if I move up to,
you've got essentials.

498
00:27:14.850 --> 00:27:18.648
That makes sense, it's a stripped
down version of Office 365.

499
00:27:18.648 --> 00:27:21.983
And then you move to business, not
business essentials that you wouldn't lose

500
00:27:21.983 --> 00:27:24.236
things like,
the most important thing, the email.

501
00:27:24.236 --> 00:27:27.618
>> Yeah and, [LAUGH] that is confusing,
very confusing.

502
00:27:27.618 --> 00:27:33.250
So, make sure you know these plans
going into the MTA cloud fundamentals.

503
00:27:33.250 --> 00:27:36.720
Now, that doesn't mean you have
to know every single jot and

504
00:27:36.720 --> 00:27:40.191
total here in the plan itself,
but just realize something,

505
00:27:40.191 --> 00:27:44.568
if they set up with a question and
they say okay, you need email, all right.

506
00:27:44.568 --> 00:27:49.878
Know that business by itself
isn't gonna give you that.

507
00:27:49.878 --> 00:27:53.202
My only thought on that Dan
is maybe they say, okay,

508
00:27:53.202 --> 00:27:57.448
this business is managing its own
internal mail infrastructure.

509
00:27:57.448 --> 00:28:03.888
Now, they get a lot of the same
things that you get in the business,

510
00:28:03.888 --> 00:28:07.860
you still get the 300 users, right?

511
00:28:07.860 --> 00:28:12.059
But one of the differences, you could see
the price difference for instance, well,

512
00:28:12.059 --> 00:28:13.938
now you can see the price difference.

513
00:28:13.938 --> 00:28:17.254
When we look at yearly versus monthly,

514
00:28:17.254 --> 00:28:21.678
we're talking $8.25 versus $10 per user.

515
00:28:21.678 --> 00:28:25.974
But one of the big things that does
differ between these two is a full

516
00:28:25.974 --> 00:28:28.300
installation of the Office Suite.

517
00:28:28.300 --> 00:28:31.460
So, Office 2016, if you wanna
download it to your computers,

518
00:28:31.460 --> 00:28:35.240
now you have the full entire Office Suite.

519
00:28:35.240 --> 00:28:36.950
Now, is that beneficial?

520
00:28:36.950 --> 00:28:40.270
Well, maybe, I do have computers and
maybe I do have laptops, right?

521
00:28:40.270 --> 00:28:46.080
As we get to maybe a larger company, maybe
I want the ability that if the internet

522
00:28:46.080 --> 00:28:49.680
connection goes down, I don't lose all
productivity with inside of my business.

523
00:28:49.680 --> 00:28:53.140
Well, if I have the full Office Suite,
then that means it's downloaded locally,

524
00:28:53.140 --> 00:28:55.380
and I can also redirect
that information if I want.

525
00:28:55.380 --> 00:28:58.460
Not only to the cloud like
the OneDrive online, but

526
00:28:58.460 --> 00:29:01.930
we can even direct it just like we do
if we didn't even use the cloud, right?

527
00:29:01.930 --> 00:29:04.320
We can manage some of that
information on premise, too.

528
00:29:04.320 --> 00:29:08.360
So this is good also for a scenario where
maybe you have a hybrid scenario where you

529
00:29:08.360 --> 00:29:12.690
need to use on premise and
you need to use Cloud.

530
00:29:12.690 --> 00:29:17.570
One of the last ones in the Business
Premium, Dan, for this one, sums up.

531
00:29:17.570 --> 00:29:20.970
And let me just mention one more
thing on the Business plan,

532
00:29:20.970 --> 00:29:22.620
you get the mobile support.

533
00:29:22.620 --> 00:29:25.695
That's one of the things that you
don't get in the Business Essentials.

534
00:29:25.695 --> 00:29:28.215
You get tablet and
phone support and that's important.

535
00:29:28.215 --> 00:29:30.315
One of the last ones is
the Business Premium.

536
00:29:30.315 --> 00:29:33.455
It's a little bit more expensive $12.50,

537
00:29:33.455 --> 00:29:36.655
$15 if you're doing
a monthly subscription.

538
00:29:36.655 --> 00:29:37.955
And what this one does, basically,

539
00:29:37.955 --> 00:29:40.615
is combines the features
of both plans together.

540
00:29:40.615 --> 00:29:41.255
>> Awesome.

541
00:29:41.255 --> 00:29:45.705
Now, Wes I know you have a little bit
more to go over as far as some plans and

542
00:29:45.705 --> 00:29:48.200
pricings and
the differences between those.

543
00:29:48.200 --> 00:29:51.720
I'm willing to let the show go a little
long as long as we're not gonna go crazy.

544
00:29:51.720 --> 00:29:54.330
>> Well, that might be something
that we have save for a part two.

545
00:29:54.330 --> 00:29:54.940
>> Okay, we're gonna go part two,
okay that's fine.

546
00:29:54.940 --> 00:29:56.460
>> Cuz, yeah,
when you get into the enterprise stuff,

547
00:29:56.460 --> 00:29:59.370
there's a lot more than just
the basic business stuff.

548
00:29:59.370 --> 00:30:03.820
So I think it probably be better for
all of us if we save that for a part two.

549
00:30:03.820 --> 00:30:05.230
>> All right.
Well, that's what we'll do then and

550
00:30:05.230 --> 00:30:06.200
that sounds great.

551
00:30:06.200 --> 00:30:09.490
What you showed us so far is something
not only is it practical, right, but

552
00:30:09.490 --> 00:30:10.390
it's gonna be great for us.

553
00:30:10.390 --> 00:30:13.440
Say if something comes up at
the exam what would be the pricing

554
00:30:13.440 --> 00:30:14.072
plan you wanna go with?

555
00:30:14.072 --> 00:30:16.540
What kinda plan would you need if
you were this type of business?

556
00:30:16.540 --> 00:30:20.420
You can field those questions
with out much issue there.

557
00:30:20.420 --> 00:30:22.470
We're gonna continue that in part two.

558
00:30:22.470 --> 00:30:23.328
Look forward to seeing you there.

559
00:30:23.328 --> 00:30:26.600
Thanks for joining us today Wes and
thank you for joining us as well.

560
00:30:26.600 --> 00:30:27.200
We're gonna go ahead and

561
00:30:27.200 --> 00:30:30.230
sign off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

562
00:30:30.230 --> 00:30:31.000
>> And I'm Wes Bryant.

563
00:30:31.000 --> 00:30:32.166
>> Well see you next time.

564
00:30:32.166 --> 00:30:37.810
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel continue explaining the steps to enable the Office365 cloud services. Here they move forward by looking at pricing plans for the Enterprise level services, looking over things like cost and features for each of the E-level plans. Then they move on to actually creating a demo account to test for your environment. This includes setting up an administrator account and connecting a custom domain.
episodes.title: Enable Cloud Services Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.587 --> 00:00:16.530
All right, greetings, everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.530 --> 00:00:18.640
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

4
00:00:18.640 --> 00:00:21.810
we are continuing on with
our MTA cloud fundamentals.

5
00:00:21.810 --> 00:00:25.680
And joining me yet again for this part
two is my good friend and colleague, and

6
00:00:25.680 --> 00:00:29.405
the man that knows all about these pricing
plans we're gonna take a look at, is Mr.

7
00:00:29.405 --> 00:00:30.020
Wes Bryan.

8
00:00:30.020 --> 00:00:31.670
Wes, welcome back to the show,
how you doing, sir?

9
00:00:31.670 --> 00:00:33.540
>> I'm doing great and
thanks for having me back again.

10
00:00:33.540 --> 00:00:38.340
That's right, we are moving through
enabling cloud services here,

11
00:00:38.340 --> 00:00:40.630
so it looks like I'm an enabler today.

12
00:00:40.630 --> 00:00:45.379
And we get to plan the plans
that we're gonna plan here so-

13
00:00:45.379 --> 00:00:46.080
>> Plan the plan, to make a plan.

14
00:00:46.080 --> 00:00:49.378
>> To make a plan,
sounds real bureaucratic, right?

15
00:00:49.378 --> 00:00:52.049
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So, in the previous episode,

16
00:00:52.049 --> 00:00:54.020
we ended on the business plans.

17
00:00:54.020 --> 00:00:57.460
And the business plans, for
the most part, are smaller businesses.

18
00:00:57.460 --> 00:01:02.890
And remember one of the capacity, the
limitations is it scales up to 300 users.

19
00:01:02.890 --> 00:01:05.254
But maybe you are a large organization.

20
00:01:05.254 --> 00:01:07.680
Or maybe you work for
a large organization, and

21
00:01:07.680 --> 00:01:11.940
they're considering moving some of their
infrastructure into the cloud as well.

22
00:01:11.940 --> 00:01:17.200
And maybe they want to have some of
the Office 365 available to them.

23
00:01:17.200 --> 00:01:19.660
So, let's go ahead and
take a look at that.

24
00:01:19.660 --> 00:01:24.671
These Enterprise plans have
an interesting classification here.

25
00:01:24.671 --> 00:01:30.410
And I'm not really too worried about
things like your Office ProPlus here.

26
00:01:30.410 --> 00:01:33.390
And we're not really getting into some of
the other ones here like the education,

27
00:01:33.390 --> 00:01:35.560
government, nonprofit, and home.

28
00:01:35.560 --> 00:01:39.490
We're gonna look at the enterprise level
cuz I think that's gonna be more common,

29
00:01:39.490 --> 00:01:44.120
and probably most likely what
they're gonna ask you on the exam.

30
00:01:44.120 --> 00:01:48.450
The very first one that we look
at here is E1, the E1 plan.

31
00:01:48.450 --> 00:01:52.900
Now, with the E1 plan, one of the things
that you might remember, and if you don't,

32
00:01:52.900 --> 00:01:54.180

33
00:01:54.180 --> 00:01:58.340
From the first part of this episode,
is the fact that we had monthly and

34
