we had annual subscriptions.

35
00:01:59.890 --> 00:02:01.990
Notice that there's no drop-down here.

36
00:02:01.990 --> 00:02:03.850
In the enterprise level plans,

37
00:02:03.850 --> 00:02:08.150
they don't give you the option to
subscribe on a month-by-month basis.

38
00:02:08.150 --> 00:02:10.730
If you're going to move
into enterprise level

39
00:02:10.730 --> 00:02:15.240
plans then your company is gonna be
required to enter into an annual contract.

40
00:02:15.240 --> 00:02:18.590
So, that is something that you have
to consider if you want to do this,

41
00:02:18.590 --> 00:02:22.210
maybe temporarily,
maybe you're trying this out.

42
00:02:22.210 --> 00:02:25.460
Again, keep in mind that once
you enter into this contract,

43
00:02:25.460 --> 00:02:26.880
you're gonna be stuck with it for a year.

44
00:02:26.880 --> 00:02:28.950
So, whatever your business model is,

45
00:02:28.950 --> 00:02:33.100
and your pricing,
you'll have to plan accordingly for that.

46
00:02:33.100 --> 00:02:34.930
>> Yeah, Wes, and that really makes sense.

47
00:02:34.930 --> 00:02:38.990
If you've ever worked in enterprise level
and you've been a part of budget meetings,

48
00:02:38.990 --> 00:02:41.440
you'll say, well yeah,
that's just how we do things.

49
00:02:41.440 --> 00:02:43.930
Because that's how we do things
at the enterprise level.

50
00:02:43.930 --> 00:02:46.360
We have a budget meeting for
the rest of the year, or for

51
00:02:46.360 --> 00:02:47.880
the next year should I say.

52
00:02:47.880 --> 00:02:49.480
And what do you want to put in there?

53
00:02:49.480 --> 00:02:54.150
Well, we need a pricing for our
Office Suite Solution, so we go ahead and

54
00:02:54.150 --> 00:02:55.130
make that year long commitment.

55
00:02:55.130 --> 00:02:56.120
We're gonna pay that money anyway,

56
00:02:56.120 --> 00:02:59.200
might as well go ahead, and
correct me if I'm wrong here, Wesley.

57
00:02:59.200 --> 00:03:00.020
But they give you a bit of a,

58
00:03:00.020 --> 00:03:03.500
do they give you a price break on
paying for that whole year or is it

59
00:03:03.500 --> 00:03:05.940
they're just giving you the breakdown
on what it will cost you monthly?

60
00:03:05.940 --> 00:03:09.036
>> Well, in the business plans,
if you pay month-by-month,

61
00:03:09.036 --> 00:03:10.712
you have to pay a little bit more.

62
00:03:10.712 --> 00:03:14.930
If you pay the annual contract,
then you are gonna get a price break.

63
00:03:14.930 --> 00:03:17.921
Here in the enterprise level though,
you do have the option.

64
00:03:17.921 --> 00:03:21.534
You can pay month-by-month or you can pay
one lump sum and you can pay the whole

65
00:03:21.534 --> 00:03:25.173
thing for the year, but you don't really
get a price break in the Enterprise.

66
00:03:25.173 --> 00:03:27.921
So, in a smaller business, they do
kinda cut you a little bit of a break.

67
00:03:27.921 --> 00:03:31.120
In the Enterprise,
it's pretty much a fixed fee.

68
00:03:31.120 --> 00:03:34.770
And you could still pay it by the month,
or you can go ahead and

69
00:03:34.770 --> 00:03:35.280
say, you know what?

70
00:03:35.280 --> 00:03:38.110
I'm gonna fork the check over and I'll
give you a whole entire year right here.

71
00:03:38.110 --> 00:03:40.504
They don't care how much you've
budgeted for this, they want all that.

72
00:03:40.504 --> 00:03:42.546
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, they want all that, yeah.

73
00:03:42.546 --> 00:03:43.338
>> Gotcha.

74
00:03:43.338 --> 00:03:44.720
>> So, yeah, definitely keep that in mind.

75
00:03:44.720 --> 00:03:48.360
And that's another reason you
really have to consider your plan.

76
00:03:48.360 --> 00:03:53.900
Now, $8 a month here is for
the E1 level subscription here.

77
00:03:53.900 --> 00:03:59.510
You don't get the full installation
of the Office Suite here.

78
00:03:59.510 --> 00:04:04.150
But you do have unlimited users, and
that's one of the big differences between

79
00:04:04.150 --> 00:04:08.010
the business plans and
the enterprise level plans.

80
00:04:08.010 --> 00:04:13.438
Now, you also get your
50 gigs of email per

81
00:04:13.438 --> 00:04:18.879
user just like we got
in the business plans.

82
00:04:18.879 --> 00:04:21.979
Now, the other thing
that it kind of helps for

83
00:04:21.979 --> 00:04:26.970
the enterprise level is that they
don't cap you on your intranet sites.

84
00:04:26.970 --> 00:04:32.460
You get unlimited intranet sites,
you get unlimited online meeting.

85
00:04:32.460 --> 00:04:37.120
Now, one of the things that's interesting
is that you don't get access.

86
00:04:37.120 --> 00:04:38.530
Now, I've always thought that's funny.

87
00:04:38.530 --> 00:04:40.160
This is software as a service,

88
00:04:40.160 --> 00:04:43.610
you need a web browser to access
the Internet to access this service.

89
00:04:43.610 --> 00:04:47.231
And then they tell you right here at
the plan, no Access or plus Access.

90
00:04:47.231 --> 00:04:48.379
What are they talking about there?

91
00:04:48.379 --> 00:04:50.762
They're actually talking about
the application that's part of

92
00:04:50.762 --> 00:04:51.461
the Office Suite.

93
00:04:51.461 --> 00:04:55.971
They're not telling you, sign up,
give us $25 a month per user and

94
00:04:55.971 --> 00:04:57.500
we give you no access.

95
00:04:57.500 --> 00:04:59.820
So, they don't really mean it that way.

96
00:04:59.820 --> 00:05:03.950
The other that we have again,
note on the E1 level,

97
00:05:03.950 --> 00:05:08.470
there isn't any mobile support, so
you also have to keep that in mind.

98
00:05:08.470 --> 00:05:10.630
Do you have tablets,
do you have mobile phones?

99
00:05:10.630 --> 00:05:12.872
If you do and you need to support them,

100
00:05:12.872 --> 00:05:16.930
well this is not going to be or
isn't going to be the plan for you.

101
00:05:16.930 --> 00:05:22.800
The other thing that we also have to look
at is enterprise level app management.

102
00:05:22.800 --> 00:05:26.480
You don't get those features
in the E1 level either,

103
00:05:26.480 --> 00:05:27.420
so-
>> Now, Wes,

104
00:05:27.420 --> 00:05:28.640
I'm sitting here looking at the plan,

105
00:05:28.640 --> 00:05:30.760
and some of the details
that are involved with it.

106
00:05:30.760 --> 00:05:33.809
And really it strikes me that,
depending on your environment,

107
00:05:33.809 --> 00:05:35.338
you may not want to go with this.

108
00:05:35.338 --> 00:05:39.981
Because a lot of the stuff that they
offer you with this E1 plan is also

109
00:05:39.981 --> 00:05:43.921
available in the Office,
what is it, the business plan?

110
00:05:43.921 --> 00:05:44.860
>> Yeah, that's right.
>> The Business Essentials?

111
00:05:44.860 --> 00:05:47.570
>> That's right, so
why would we want one over the other?

112
00:05:47.570 --> 00:05:48.770
That's a great question.

113
00:05:48.770 --> 00:05:51.950
First of all is the cap on users,
that's one of the things that we have to

114
00:05:51.950 --> 00:05:55.480
think about, 300 users in the business
plan versus unlimited users.

115
00:05:55.480 --> 00:05:59.388
The other thing is,
as far as your SharePoint sites, I mean,

116
00:05:59.388 --> 00:06:03.010
they just blow the lid off of this one,
it's unlimited.

117
00:06:03.010 --> 00:06:07.600
You don't have a restriction or
a cap on how many sites that you can set.

118
00:06:07.600 --> 00:06:11.050
And as far as your online meetings,
think about any time you have some kinda

119
00:06:11.050 --> 00:06:14.570
high definition conferencing, your online
meetings, that's taking resources, right?

120
00:06:14.570 --> 00:06:16.720
So, in the enterprise level
they don't tell you well,

121
00:06:16.720 --> 00:06:19.970
you're limited to a certain
amount of online meetings and

122
00:06:19.970 --> 00:06:22.410
we'll cap you at that like they
do in some of the business plans.

123
00:06:22.410 --> 00:06:24.200
They say you have as many as you want.

124
00:06:24.200 --> 00:06:27.030
You need 4 or 500 of these meetings,

125
00:06:27.030 --> 00:06:31.550
well go ahead, we've got the bandwidth and
that's part of your subscription.

126
00:06:31.550 --> 00:06:36.710
So, keep in mind that
the Enterprise level 1

127
00:06:36.710 --> 00:06:40.830
does have some of its limitations, right,
I don't get the full install of Office.

128
00:06:40.830 --> 00:06:43.240
Now, just like we talked about
in some of the business plans,

129
00:06:43.240 --> 00:06:45.390
that might be a problem for my company.

130
00:06:45.390 --> 00:06:46.740
Why?
Well,

131
00:06:46.740 --> 00:06:50.260
because if you think about it, if you
don't have an Internet connection, right.

132
00:06:50.260 --> 00:06:52.140
If you don't have an internet
connection in all of this,

133
00:06:52.140 --> 00:06:55.540
you're not gonna be able
to connect to Office 365.

134
00:06:55.540 --> 00:06:58.030
But think of it from
a productivity stance, right.

135
00:06:58.030 --> 00:07:03.500
If I lose Internet connectivity, I lose
access, all access to the online web app.

136
00:07:03.500 --> 00:07:06.580
So, that's where you might want
to move into something like

137
00:07:06.580 --> 00:07:09.250
their E3 subscription or their E3 tier.

138
00:07:10.990 --> 00:07:12.870
That's funny now, now you get Access.

139
00:07:12.870 --> 00:07:14.710
You didn't get Access before,
now you get Access.

140
00:07:14.710 --> 00:07:20.250
And again, joking aside, they're talking
about a application inside of Office 365.

141
00:07:20.250 --> 00:07:23.260
This is quite pricey.

142
00:07:23.260 --> 00:07:26.800
You look at the jump here and
we're going from, on average,

143
00:07:26.800 --> 00:07:30.810
the highest price subscription in the
business plan was the Business Premium.

144
00:07:30.810 --> 00:07:34.153
And that was $15 per user if
you were doing it per month.

145
00:07:34.153 --> 00:07:41.750
This is $20, this is $5 per user,
and we don't have any breaks here.

146
00:07:41.750 --> 00:07:44.970
So, what are some of the things
that we have to look at here?

147
00:07:44.970 --> 00:07:47.830
You get all the features that
you see inside of the E1 plan.

148
00:07:47.830 --> 00:07:50.450
So, now they're starting
to compound on each other.

149
00:07:50.450 --> 00:07:52.336
You get all the features of the E1 plan.

150
00:07:52.336 --> 00:07:56.440
But now you get Access, right,
because maybe you're a larger company.

151
00:07:56.440 --> 00:07:59.780
Maybe you have some users
connecting to databases,

152
00:07:59.780 --> 00:08:05.470
you got a lot of need for
the Access application.

153
00:08:05.470 --> 00:08:09.046
Well then,
you have access to Access [LAUGH].

154
00:08:09.046 --> 00:08:12.296
The other thing is the email.

155
00:08:12.296 --> 00:08:15.960
The first one does have 50 gigs
per user when it comes to email.

156
00:08:15.960 --> 00:08:20.410
When you get into the E3 tier,
it's an unlimited, unlimited inbox size.

157
00:08:20.410 --> 00:08:24.799
So, if you've got somebody that is
hitting that 50 gigs, first of all,

158
00:08:24.799 --> 00:08:28.087
they need to clean up their
inbox if email's just text.

159
00:08:28.087 --> 00:08:29.537
But it's-
>> Good luck with that, Wes.

160
00:08:29.537 --> 00:08:31.144
>> That's right.
>> I've been down that road with people

161
00:08:31.144 --> 00:08:34.212
with large inboxes, and they just look
at you and go, I need that email.

162
00:08:34.212 --> 00:08:36.954
>> You need that email now-
>> I need those spam mails that I got that

163
00:08:36.954 --> 00:08:38.853
are sitting in my deleted [LAUGH] inbox.

164
00:08:38.853 --> 00:08:43.060
>> Yeah, that's right, and all those
PDFs from five years ago, of course.

165
00:08:43.060 --> 00:08:46.760
You never know, one day,
you're gonna need it.

166
00:08:46.760 --> 00:08:49.300
So, that'd be a good thing for you,
and that'd probably saved you a lot of

167
00:08:49.300 --> 00:08:53.590
headache too there, Dan,
is an unlimited email inbox size.

168
00:08:53.590 --> 00:08:56.650
Now, we start moving into the support for
mobile devices.

169
00:08:56.650 --> 00:08:59.850
And that's one of the things
that does set this apart here.

170
00:08:59.850 --> 00:09:04.350
You can see Office on tablets and
phones here.

171
00:09:04.350 --> 00:09:09.110
And what's really interesting here is 5
tablets and 5 phones per user, right?

172
00:09:09.110 --> 00:09:14.532
So, we're really talking about scaling up,
we're not just saying, okay, if you've

173
00:09:14.532 --> 00:09:19.254
got five phones within your network,
you get five installations of Office.

174
00:09:19.254 --> 00:09:20.760
No, we're talking per user.

175
00:09:20.760 --> 00:09:25.840
You get five different instances of the
installation based on your licensing here.

176
00:09:25.840 --> 00:09:29.890
The other thing that you start to get
too is Enterprise app management,

177
00:09:29.890 --> 00:09:32.810
a consolidated view of your applications.

178
00:09:32.810 --> 00:09:37.576
We're not just talking about logging into
Office 365 Administration Center and

179
00:09:37.576 --> 00:09:39.463
managing your infrastructure.

180
00:09:39.463 --> 00:09:44.307
But we're talking about managing the
applications themselves from an enterprise

181
00:09:44.307 --> 00:09:46.254
level, which is a nice feature.

182
00:09:46.254 --> 00:09:50.690
Now, a lot of the companies have to worry
about things like legalities, rightk,

183
00:09:50.690 --> 00:09:52.410
we've talked about that.

184
00:09:52.410 --> 00:09:55.740
Things like compliance, and
we've mentioned the compliance

185
00:09:55.740 --> 00:10:00.070
that Office 365 will meet in other
episodes, go back and check them out.

186
00:10:00.070 --> 00:10:02.547
But what if you want your
company to be protected, right?

187
00:10:02.547 --> 00:10:07.167
One of the benefits of using software as
a service is that the security team is on

188
00:10:07.167 --> 00:10:09.140
the Microsoft's side, right?

189
00:10:09.140 --> 00:10:11.070
They're the ones
researching the standards,

190
00:10:11.070 --> 00:10:14.320
they're the ones making sure
that they're up to date.

191
00:10:14.320 --> 00:10:16.620
Well, when you get into the E3 plan,

192
00:10:16.620 --> 00:10:21.455
you get the option to have your
compliance and information protection.

193
00:10:21.455 --> 00:10:22.501
They back it.

194
00:10:22.501 --> 00:10:25.795
They say okay, well we're gonna take
care and we'll monitor the compliance

195
00:10:25.795 --> 00:10:28.905
regulations and that we'll make
sure that you are in compliance.

196
00:10:28.905 --> 00:10:32.980
And if you're not, we're gonna
financially back you with that so

197
00:10:32.980 --> 00:10:34.640
that you don't have to worry about it.

198
00:10:34.640 --> 00:10:37.788
So, it's another good thing when
you use software as a service.

199
00:10:37.788 --> 00:10:40.910
Is that you're really
just alleviating yourself

200
00:10:40.910 --> 00:10:44.870
from a large compliance team that you
might have to hire in order to make sure

201
00:10:44.870 --> 00:10:49.520
that you remain legal with whatever local,
federal, state regulations, or

202
00:10:49.520 --> 00:10:54.300
even country regulations if
you're on international soil.

203
00:10:54.300 --> 00:11:00.670
That is really what kinda
makes the E3 plan stand out.

204
00:11:00.670 --> 00:11:05.640
The last one is the E5 plan, and this is a
newer plan that was set out for Microsoft.

205
00:11:05.640 --> 00:11:09.640
And this combines all the functionality
and features, just kinda like we've

206
00:11:09.640 --> 00:11:14.870
seen in the Business Premium, right,
of the E1 plan and the E3 plan.

207
00:11:14.870 --> 00:11:21.300
But now we're getting features like
advanced malware protection, right?

208
00:11:21.300 --> 00:11:25.700
We can look down here and
we've got, yep, here we go.

209
00:11:25.700 --> 00:11:28.070
So, advanced security that
helps protect your data.

210
00:11:28.070 --> 00:11:32.862
You can see they don't offer that
in the three lower tier plans.

211
00:11:32.862 --> 00:11:38.330
Zero-day viruses, malware, so you get that
threat mitigation, that threat protection.

212
00:11:38.330 --> 00:11:40.580
Which is, I mean, it's good for

213
00:11:40.580 --> 00:11:43.740
any business but now they're saying hey,
we're gonna manage this for you.

214
00:11:43.740 --> 00:11:47.390
We're gonna manage your security
infrastructure as far as malware goes and

215
00:11:47.390 --> 00:11:48.540
you don't have to worry about it.

216
00:11:48.540 --> 00:11:50.754
>> Just another thing you
can chuck onto their plates.

217
00:11:50.754 --> 00:11:51.505
>> That's right.

218
00:11:51.505 --> 00:11:52.712
>> And take it off of your own, right?

219
00:11:52.712 --> 00:11:55.178
>> Absolutely,
not having to worry about it.

220
00:11:55.178 --> 00:11:57.950
Again, if your capital,

221
00:11:57.950 --> 00:12:03.680
your finances can't really justify having
that kinda team on site, on premise.

222
00:12:03.680 --> 00:12:05.630
And you certainly don't
wanna outsource it and

223
00:12:05.630 --> 00:12:09.260
have a complete third party come in
on premise and take care of this.

224
00:12:09.260 --> 00:12:12.025
You can say, well you know what,
Microsoft, we'll go ahead and

225
00:12:12.025 --> 00:12:14.756
pay you a subscription fee, and
you can take care of that for us.

226
00:12:14.756 --> 00:12:16.932
Now, the big thing that really,

227
00:12:16.932 --> 00:12:21.069
really sets the E5 apart is
the voice over IP infrastructure.

228
00:12:23.260 --> 00:12:27.120
You get Skype Online for
Business in a lot of these plans.

229
00:12:27.120 --> 00:12:29.970
But one of the big
differences between E5 plan

230
00:12:29.970 --> 00:12:34.560
is we're talking online web
connections through the web interface.

231
00:12:34.560 --> 00:12:39.185
You probably have been a part of an online
conferencing system where you've been able

232
00:12:39.185 --> 00:12:40.550
to pull out your phone, right?

233
00:12:40.550 --> 00:12:45.210
You dial in the number and
you connect to whatever the conference is,

234
00:12:45.210 --> 00:12:47.510
whether it's mobile phone or
maybe it's land line.

235
00:12:47.510 --> 00:12:49.850
Maybe you need to pick up a land line and
you need to call and

236
00:12:49.850 --> 00:12:52.060
dial in to an online conferencing meeting.

237
00:12:52.060 --> 00:12:56.460
Well, in the lower tiers, you don't
get the dial in conferencing option.

238
00:12:56.460 --> 00:13:01.970
That is something that is strictly limited
to the E5 plan that you get that dial in.

239
00:13:01.970 --> 00:13:05.010
They call it here on their
sites there if you'll see,

240
00:13:05.010 --> 00:13:07.560
they talk about PSTN conferencing.

241
00:13:07.560 --> 00:13:09.990
But that's really what they mean there,
they mean the dial in.

242
00:13:09.990 --> 00:13:13.450
It's the fact that you can
set up a Microsoft bridge.

243
00:13:13.450 --> 00:13:17.630
They'll take care of it, they've plenty
of numbers for whatever your region is.

244
00:13:17.630 --> 00:13:21.590
You can set that number, you can call
that number, and you dial into any of

245
00:13:21.590 --> 00:13:26.470
the online conferences from any kind
of mobile phone or even land line.

246
00:13:26.470 --> 00:13:29.140
And one of the last things, again,

247
00:13:29.140 --> 00:13:33.800
that really sets this E5
support apart is the Cloud PBX.

248
00:13:33.800 --> 00:13:36.540
If you're not familiar with the term PBX,

249
00:13:36.540 --> 00:13:40.870
I would definitely recommend checking out
the acronym, checking out the definition.

250
00:13:40.870 --> 00:13:42.610
That's private branch exchange.

251
00:13:42.610 --> 00:13:47.030
As far as Cloud PBX means,
that means it's inside of the cloud,

252
00:13:47.030 --> 00:13:49.180
they're gonna manage
the private branch exchange.

253
00:13:49.180 --> 00:13:50.004
You don't have to have
all the infrastructure.

254
00:13:50.004 --> 00:13:51.895
If you're using voice over IP phones,

255
00:13:51.895 --> 00:13:55.360
you're probably familiar with
this inside of your own company.

256
00:13:55.360 --> 00:13:58.546
That SIP communications, it takes a lot,
right, we have to manage.

257
00:13:58.546 --> 00:14:02.537
I say we [LAUGH], Don Pezet here has
to manage a lot of the voice over IP

258
00:14:02.537 --> 00:14:05.337
communications that we
have on this network.

259
00:14:05.337 --> 00:14:08.640
And it can be very complex and
time consuming.

260
00:14:08.640 --> 00:14:12.720
And if you don't have that infrastructure,
you don't have the know how, or

261
00:14:12.720 --> 00:14:14.360
maybe you don't want to hire the team.

262
00:14:14.360 --> 00:14:17.609
You can say, you know what,
we're gonna let the cloud PBX,

263
00:14:17.609 --> 00:14:20.046
we'll let that part of
that go to Microsoft.

264
00:14:20.046 --> 00:14:24.690
And they'll manage routing those phone
calls as they come into your corporation.

265
00:14:24.690 --> 00:14:25.672
And we don't have to worry about it.

266
00:14:25.672 --> 00:14:29.060
And the great thing too with
cloud PBX is in general,

267
00:14:29.060 --> 00:14:32.865
as a standard you have what's
called a PBX parachute.

268
00:14:32.865 --> 00:14:35.955
Which means if the private branch
exchange that they're using goes offline,

269
00:14:35.955 --> 00:14:37.585
they've got another one that comes online.

270
00:14:37.585 --> 00:14:38.935
So you've got redundancy there,

271
00:14:38.935 --> 00:14:41.672
as we've talked about in some
of the previous episodes.

272
00:14:41.672 --> 00:14:47.572
Because as you know, you certainly don't
want to have that type of subscription.

273
00:14:47.572 --> 00:14:51.882
Call into some very important meeting
where hopefully you're gonna land the next

274
00:14:51.882 --> 00:14:56.596
big million dollar contract and,
everything's lost.

275
00:14:56.596 --> 00:14:59.231
[LAUGH] So, it's good to have
the cloud parachutes too, and

276
00:14:59.231 --> 00:15:00.911
it's all part of that infrastructure.

277
00:15:00.911 --> 00:15:03.231
>> Yeah, it's a really nice
thing to have that Skype for

278
00:15:03.231 --> 00:15:08.011
business, that PBX side of
the Office Suite there for you.

279
00:15:08.011 --> 00:15:13.111
Because, I was with Don, we were trying
to vet out what system do we wanna go to?

280
00:15:13.111 --> 00:15:16.128
Because, we wanted to A,
not have to manage the thing.

281
00:15:16.128 --> 00:15:18.696
Right, we have enough on our
plates here in the show,

282
00:15:18.696 --> 00:15:20.970
trying to just give you
guys great content.

283
00:15:20.970 --> 00:15:22.750
It's one less thing that
we have to worry about.

284
00:15:22.750 --> 00:15:24.610
This was a great solution for us, right?

285
00:15:24.610 --> 00:15:26.100
They take care of everything.

286
00:15:26.100 --> 00:15:27.900
And the phones that we already had, or

287
00:15:27.900 --> 00:15:30.870
we could get other phones,
just about any kind of phone we wanted.

288
00:15:30.870 --> 00:15:32.230
We could use that as well.

289
00:15:32.230 --> 00:15:35.340
So, that was a very great benefit for
us to go to this system.

290
00:15:35.340 --> 00:15:38.070
Then when Don started to set it up,
it was an easy setup.

291
00:15:38.070 --> 00:15:42.060
He said this thing is so butter smooth,
this is the way we're gonna go.

292
00:15:42.060 --> 00:15:45.610
And the pricing was competitive
with every other thing.

293
00:15:45.610 --> 00:15:49.146
Not to mention the fact that
we already had Office 365, and

294
00:15:49.146 --> 00:15:52.004
the tier that we were using
offered this service.

295
00:15:52.004 --> 00:15:54.505
So, we were using another provider,
we said hey,

296
00:15:54.505 --> 00:15:57.980
we're already actually paying for
this inside of what we're using.

297
00:15:57.980 --> 00:16:00.840
Might as well go ahead and
just tack this on and use all in one.

298
00:16:00.840 --> 00:16:04.370
So, it becomes a one point of contact,
right.

299
00:16:04.370 --> 00:16:06.600
I no longer have 16
vendors I gotta work with.

300
00:16:06.600 --> 00:16:08.340
I got one vendor,
Microsoft, I go with them.

301
00:16:08.340 --> 00:16:11.690
I got them for my Office suite,
now I've got them for my PBX as well.

302
00:16:11.690 --> 00:16:14.420
Consolidates all that and
makes my life as a manager or

303
00:16:14.420 --> 00:16:19.150
as an admin a whole lot easier, and
we're a big fan of the system so far.

304
00:16:19.150 --> 00:16:22.079
>> Definitely, and I remember you going
through some of the studying you had to

305
00:16:22.079 --> 00:16:23.560
do, cuz you have to do your research.

306
00:16:23.560 --> 00:16:30.220
You have to find out what's competitive,
competitive pricing, and then, what works.

307
00:16:30.220 --> 00:16:33.879
Do you have to add all these
little add-ons to make it work?

308
00:16:33.879 --> 00:16:37.126
And do you have to pay for each little
[LAUGH] add on and functionality and

309
00:16:37.126 --> 00:16:37.970
feature?

310
00:16:37.970 --> 00:16:40.810
And it's good to see here,
and thank you too for that,

311
00:16:40.810 --> 00:16:44.750
Dan, to see that you have
it all here in Office 365.

312
00:16:44.750 --> 00:16:46.880
So, you can see that,
when it comes down to it,

313
00:16:46.880 --> 00:16:50.940
if you are an organization that can
afford a price point like this,

314
00:16:50.940 --> 00:16:54.000
you really can integrate the entire
infrastructure into a single package.

315
00:16:54.000 --> 00:16:58.460
And your paying one bill instead of five
or six little, well maybe not little,

316
00:16:58.460 --> 00:17:01.870
maybe expensive modular little
bills across the board.

317
00:17:01.870 --> 00:17:06.910
So, when it comes to the plans, Dan,
I would know what's not involved

318
00:17:06.910 --> 00:17:11.712
in one plan over the other,
versus knowing everything in the plan.

319
00:17:11.712 --> 00:17:14.230
So, for instance,
just as a real quick little recap.

320
00:17:14.230 --> 00:17:18.337
Remember in the E1 you don't get email.

321
00:17:18.337 --> 00:17:20.500
Let me make sure I'm saying that right.

322
00:17:20.500 --> 00:17:25.270
No, no I apologize,
you get 50 gigs of email in the E1 plan.

323
00:17:25.270 --> 00:17:29.463
Well, if 50 gigs might seem like a cap,
know that you can't go over 50 gigs.

324
00:17:29.463 --> 00:17:34.082
And they might ask you a question that
says you have a user that, on average,

325
00:17:34.082 --> 00:17:39.410
averages about 65 gigs in their inboxes,
could the E1 plan work for them?

326
00:17:39.410 --> 00:17:42.370
Well, it wouldn't, they'd have to up
to something like the E3 where they

327
00:17:42.370 --> 00:17:44.390
bust the cap off of that and
you don't have to worry about it.

328
00:17:44.390 --> 00:17:46.140
So, know the plans.

329
00:17:46.140 --> 00:17:49.870
You don't have to know every
individual specific point, but

330
00:17:49.870 --> 00:17:51.940
definitely know some of
the highlight features and

331
00:17:51.940 --> 00:17:55.120
I think you'll be doing really good
on the MTA Cloud Fundamentals exam.

332
00:17:55.120 --> 00:17:58.380
>> Awesome, well Wes,
I know that you have more.

333
00:17:58.380 --> 00:18:00.440
Now, that we've figured out the plan,
we made a plan to make a plan.

334
00:18:00.440 --> 00:18:01.837
And now-
>> To make a plan.

335
00:18:01.837 --> 00:18:03.270
>> Now we've made a plan.

336
00:18:03.270 --> 00:18:05.090
Now, it's about time to implement
that plan, am I correct?

337
00:18:05.090 --> 00:18:05.754
>> That's right.

338
00:18:05.754 --> 00:18:10.710
>> So, that is a little more than what
time is going to allow for us today.

339
00:18:10.710 --> 00:18:13.394
So Wes, I say we make a part 3 to
this guy and we round it out and

340
00:18:13.394 --> 00:18:15.795
we actually implement our
plan that we have in place.

341
00:18:15.795 --> 00:18:16.504
>> Sounds good.

342
00:18:16.504 --> 00:18:19.310
>> All right, so
hopefully that's all gonna go smoothly.

343
00:18:19.310 --> 00:18:20.670
I know Wes is gonna be back with us.

344
00:18:20.670 --> 00:18:21.850
Hopefully you'll be back with us as well.

345
00:18:21.850 --> 00:18:22.860
Thank you for joining us today.

346
00:18:22.860 --> 00:18:23.950
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

347
00:18:23.950 --> 00:18:26.270
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

348
00:18:26.270 --> 00:18:27.000
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

349
00:18:27.000 --> 00:18:29.211
>> And we will see you next time.

350
00:18:29.211 --> 00:18:33.679

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue taking you through the necessary steps to enable cloud services, here specifically they show you how to sign-up for Office365. First they show you how to create a "tenant" account and setup your first administrator. Next they explain and demonstrate registering and verifying your domain. Finally, they help you understand the process of configuring DNS for connecting your domain to Office365.
episodes.title: Enable Cloud Services Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel finish up the topic of enabling cloud services by walking you through the setup for Microsoft Intune integration with Office365. They show you how much of the legwork is already done by having already setup Office365 and touch upon the steps necessary to integrate Intune and setup an Intune administrator.
episodes.title: Enable Cloud Services Part 4

How we can get Intune working cuz
that is something they do call out

213
00:12:00.360 --> 00:12:01.380
as an exam objective.

214
00:12:01.380 --> 00:12:05.340
So we wanted to make sure you guys
were up on and aware of that.

215
00:12:05.340 --> 00:12:07.450
It is a short and sweet episode,
but it was a good one.

216
00:12:07.450 --> 00:12:08.540
Definitely necessary.

217
00:12:08.540 --> 00:12:10.890
Thanks for joining us Wes and
thank you for watching.

218
00:12:10.890 --> 00:12:12.770
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV.

219
00:12:12.770 --> 00:12:14.220
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

220
00:12:14.220 --> 00:12:14.930
>> And I'm Wes Brian.

221
00:12:14.930 --> 00:12:16.231
>> And we'll see you next time.

222
00:12:16.231 --> 00:12:22.129
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel explore administrating Office365 and InTune. They start by looking at tasks like creating users, groups, and assigning services and licenses. They explain the differences between the different cloud identities, specifically Online identities, Synchronized identities, and Federated identities. They also cover assigning permissions and managing password policies.
episodes.title: Administering Cloud Services
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.058 --> 00:00:10.058
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.680 --> 00:00:16.590
All right greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.590 --> 00:00:17.970
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

4
00:00:17.970 --> 00:00:21.980
in today's episode we are continuing on
with out MTA cloud fundamentals series.

5
00:00:21.980 --> 00:00:26.110
And joining me yet again is the man, the
myth, the legend, that is my good friend,

6
00:00:26.110 --> 00:00:26.940
Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:26.940 --> 00:00:28.660
Wes, welcome to the show, sir.

8
00:00:28.660 --> 00:00:29.570
Glad to have you back.

9
00:00:29.570 --> 00:00:30.320
How the heck are you?

10
00:00:30.320 --> 00:00:32.620
Oh, I'm doing good, and
it's good to be here, as always.

11
00:00:32.620 --> 00:00:36.170
And we're gonna be moving into
administering cloud services.

12
00:00:36.170 --> 00:00:38.970
And one of the first things you have
to know when it comes to any kind of

13
00:00:38.970 --> 00:00:41.970
cloud service is a little
bit about the identities and

14
00:00:41.970 --> 00:00:44.000
the accounts that you can create.

15
00:00:44.000 --> 00:00:46.100
Now, Let's understand what an identity is,

16
00:00:46.100 --> 00:00:50.360
because it does mean a couple different
things across the different platforms.

17
00:00:50.360 --> 00:00:53.360
Identities for us in Office 365 and

18
00:00:53.360 --> 00:00:57.670
the Microsoft Intune really boils down to
two different types of identities, right?

19
00:00:57.670 --> 00:01:00.150
It's either going to be a user or
it's going to be a computer.

20
00:01:00.150 --> 00:01:04.730
Now if you're in Active Directory you can
also have things like services can be

21
00:01:04.730 --> 00:01:08.160
identified as like an identity if you
need to set up an account for that but

22
00:01:08.160 --> 00:01:13.130
what we're really looking at here is
users and computers, or even groups.

23
00:01:13.130 --> 00:01:15.270
I gotta include the groups there, too.

24
00:01:15.270 --> 00:01:16.970
Users, groups, and computers.

25
00:01:16.970 --> 00:01:21.770
Now there are some different types of
identities when it comes to users,

26
00:01:21.770 --> 00:01:23.350
groups, or computers.

27
00:01:23.350 --> 00:01:26.780
One of the first ones we have is what
is known as the online identity.

28
00:01:26.780 --> 00:01:28.810
Let me go ahead and
show you what I mean here.

29
00:01:28.810 --> 00:01:31.310
Online identities are ones that,
imagine this.

30
00:01:31.310 --> 00:01:32.610
You create them online.

31
00:01:32.610 --> 00:01:35.970
We've got the Office
365 platform here open.

32
00:01:35.970 --> 00:01:39.980
And you can see I have a couple
of identities ready to go.

33
00:01:39.980 --> 00:01:42.860
Now these are ones that were
created in the cloud, right.

34
00:01:42.860 --> 00:01:46.430
Software as a service is one of
the things that we've really been focused

35
00:01:46.430 --> 00:01:49.180
on more than anything out of
the cloud computing stack.

36
00:01:49.180 --> 00:01:54.120
Well, I created these right here right,
I didn't create these on premise,

37
00:01:54.120 --> 00:01:54.850
on a server and

38
00:01:54.850 --> 00:01:58.800
then, have them synchronized up to the
cloud, they started here in the cloud and

39
00:01:58.800 --> 00:02:02.890
for the most part of staying here in
the cloud and that's an online identity.

40
00:02:02.890 --> 00:02:07.380
The other type of identity we have is
what's known as a synchronized identity.

41
00:02:07.380 --> 00:02:11.750
Synchronized identities, you can
typically see here in your Azure AD.

42
00:02:11.750 --> 00:02:13.010
Synchronized identities, right?

43
00:02:13.010 --> 00:02:17.900
When we talk about a synchronization, we
can have them synchronize from on premise,

44
00:02:17.900 --> 00:02:18.660
up to the cloud, right,

45
00:02:18.660 --> 00:02:22.610
because you might have an existing Active
Directory infrastructure in place, and

46
00:02:22.610 --> 00:02:25.410
you're considering moving
to software as a service.

47
00:02:25.410 --> 00:02:28.300
Well those identities that
are already on premise

48
00:02:28.300 --> 00:02:29.980
need to make it up to the cloud, right?

49
00:02:29.980 --> 00:02:33.600
So what you do,
you connect your Active Directory

50
00:02:33.600 --> 00:02:36.820
to the cloud through an Active Directory
synchronization process and

51
00:02:36.820 --> 00:02:39.170
all those identities get
moved up into the cloud.

52
00:02:39.170 --> 00:02:42.020
Now what does that do for
the on premise IDs?

53
00:02:42.020 --> 00:02:43.010
Well, nothing.

54
00:02:43.010 --> 00:02:44.240
They're still there as well but

55
00:02:44.240 --> 00:02:47.350
now you get the ability to use
existing infrastructure or

56
00:02:47.350 --> 00:02:51.160
existing identities that you already have
on premise and synchronize them across

57
00:02:51.160 --> 00:02:53.910
all of the web platforms and
the cloud platforms that we have.

58
00:02:53.910 --> 00:02:55.900
>> Yeah, Wes,
when you synchronize identities,

59
00:02:55.900 --> 00:03:00.740
I always think of the spies on a TV
shows or the black ops guys and

60
00:03:00.740 --> 00:03:03.090
they're gonna go in and
do some sort of mission.

61
00:03:03.090 --> 00:03:03.700
And what do they do?

62
00:03:03.700 --> 00:03:06.340
They say, let's synchronize watches and
what does that mean?

63
00:03:06.340 --> 00:03:09.460
It means let's make all of our
watches on the exact same time, so

64
00:03:09.460 --> 00:03:11.980
that when I'm ready to make a move,
you're ready to make a move.

65
00:03:11.980 --> 00:03:14.970
It's the same idea when it comes
to synchronized identities.

66
00:03:14.970 --> 00:03:17.750
You have some on premise identities,
and now we want

67
00:03:17.750 --> 00:03:21.695
to have our cloud services be able to work
with those together at the same time,

68
00:03:21.695 --> 00:03:25.475
no matter where you go those
users are there, right Wes?

69
00:03:25.475 --> 00:03:26.185
>> That's exactly it.

70
00:03:26.185 --> 00:03:29.335
You know what's funny, is it kinda reminds
me of a bad 80s reference here, right?

71
00:03:29.335 --> 00:03:30.505
The synchronized Swatch watches?

72
00:03:30.505 --> 00:03:32.115
You remember the Swatch watch commercials-
>> Oh yes, I do.

73
00:03:32.115 --> 00:03:34.755
>> Where they'd all put their watches out
and that's all you'd see is the hands, and

74
00:03:34.755 --> 00:03:38.390
the synchronize Swatches, right,
Is all about time synchronization.

75
00:03:38.390 --> 00:03:41.740
And this isn't about time synchronization,
this is more like Dan said,

76
00:03:41.740 --> 00:03:45.760
that we need that synchronization
across multiple platforms here.

77
00:03:45.760 --> 00:03:50.080
Now, the other type of identity we have
is what is called a federated identity.

78
00:03:50.080 --> 00:03:52.860
Now, we're not talking about
the federation coming in and

79
00:03:52.860 --> 00:03:56.480
building a blockade, and you can't leave
your planet type federation here but

80
00:03:56.480 --> 00:04:00.100
what we're talking about is a single
identity across multiple platforms.

81
00:04:00.100 --> 00:04:02.380
Let me go ahead and
show you what I mean on that one as well.

82
00:04:02.380 --> 00:04:06.130
Notice that I'm logged in to
the Office 365 interface here and

83
00:04:06.130 --> 00:04:10.500
you could see we've old Jimmy Hendriks
here is logged in to the Office 365.

84
00:04:10.500 --> 00:04:15.530
Well what if I go over new tab here and
we're gonna go ahead and we're gonna type

85
00:04:15.530 --> 00:04:22.310
Microsoft, oh, maybe we'll type Microsoft,
something close to it, right?

86
00:04:22.310 --> 00:04:26.340
And then it's gonna be the Intune
account portal, that's what we need.

87
00:04:28.320 --> 00:04:31.650
And, remember, this is where,
as an administrator,

88
00:04:31.650 --> 00:04:35.550
I can manage the accounts that I
have inside of the Microsoft Intune.

89
00:04:35.550 --> 00:04:37.750
Notice that it tells me right away.

90
00:04:37.750 --> 00:04:40.200
If I look right here Notice that there,
Dan?

91
00:04:40.200 --> 00:04:41.790
It says I'm already signed in.

92
00:04:41.790 --> 00:04:43.660
Well, how did it recognize me?

93
00:04:43.660 --> 00:04:47.080
How does it recognize me
on two different platforms?

94
00:04:47.080 --> 00:04:49.300
Well, that is the purpose of federation,
right?

95
00:04:49.300 --> 00:04:52.220
When we talk about federation on premise,
what we typically mean is,

96
00:04:52.220 --> 00:04:55.210
you got some kind of
web-aware application, right?

97
00:04:55.210 --> 00:04:57.360
And you also have your
Active Directory interface.

98
00:04:57.360 --> 00:05:00.420
Well, wouldn't it be nice to
log into the web interface and

99
00:05:00.420 --> 00:05:03.190
not have to put in a separate
user account, right?

100
00:05:03.190 --> 00:05:08.441
It's a way we can implement something
known as SSO, Single Sign On and

101
00:05:08.441 --> 00:05:13.781
if I click this username here and
let's see if it will let me, I've been

102
00:05:13.781 --> 00:05:20.120
having trouble typing dot dot dot out here
let's see how well that goes for me today.

103
00:05:20.120 --> 00:05:22.290
Oh, see, well we'll try that again.

104
00:05:23.350 --> 00:05:25.570
>> It's a very difficult password.

105
00:05:25.570 --> 00:05:28.290
>> My grandpa used to say
when I would be fishing and

106
00:05:28.290 --> 00:05:32.140
everybody else would be catching fish,
and I would not be catching fish,

107
00:05:32.140 --> 00:05:34.400
of course he'd say, boy,
are you holding your mouth right?

108
00:05:34.400 --> 00:05:36.610
Cuz I'd be doing
everything that they were.

109
00:05:36.610 --> 00:05:38.890
And it looks like it's giving me
a hard time, we'll try it again there.

110
00:05:40.520 --> 00:05:43.780
Now with the federated identity, we should
just be able to click the link here and

111
00:05:43.780 --> 00:05:45.200
it's gonna log us in.

112
00:05:45.200 --> 00:05:50.230
And like that, now we see that one
account we logged into Office,

113
00:05:50.230 --> 00:05:52.690
well, we're already
logged into Office 365.

114
00:05:52.690 --> 00:05:55.590
I go to the Microsoft Intune and
it logs me right in.

115
00:05:55.590 --> 00:05:59.920
So that's a nice way to implement
something like a single sign on so

116
00:05:59.920 --> 00:06:03.500
that you remember one password and
you can log in to multiple services there.

117
00:06:03.500 --> 00:06:06.670
>> Yeah, now Wes, this does bring up an
interesting question, at least in my mind.

118
00:06:06.670 --> 00:06:09.860
Is we have federated identity,
which is cool, right?

119
00:06:09.860 --> 00:06:13.990
It says as a single sign on I've got
one user account, one password, and

120
00:06:13.990 --> 00:06:16.600
I can access multiple different platforms.

121
00:06:16.600 --> 00:06:19.056
And I noticed that when you clicked on it,
you went straight into Intune.

122
00:06:19.056 --> 00:06:22.370
There was, notice that If I've never set
up Intune before or I've never touched

123
00:06:22.370 --> 00:06:25.910
Intune before, and I've got a federated
ID, am I able to do the same thing?

124
00:06:25.910 --> 00:06:27.080
Can I just click on that link and

125
00:06:27.080 --> 00:06:29.730
it takes me in and
I can just start doing stuff to it?

126
00:06:29.730 --> 00:06:31.705
>> Well unfortunately, the answer is no.

127
00:06:31.705 --> 00:06:36.240
[LAUGH] What you do have to do is you
have to set up the Intune platform first.

128
00:06:36.240 --> 00:06:40.470
Once the Intune platform is already set
up, this is where the identity now becomes

129
00:06:40.470 --> 00:06:44.340
federated between your tenant
administrator across multiple services.

130
00:06:44.340 --> 00:06:48.607
Now you might say,
I'm not familiar with Office 365,

131
00:06:48.607 --> 00:06:51.741
I'm not familiar with the Intune yet, but

132
00:06:51.741 --> 00:06:56.723
do you have maybe an example that I
can see, and maybe I already use?

133
00:06:56.723 --> 00:06:59.450
Well yes, we've got what's
known as the Microsoft account.

134
00:06:59.450 --> 00:07:02.460
Now some of you guys have probably had
a Microsoft account for a long time.

135
00:07:02.460 --> 00:07:05.010
You say, I've never even
started a Microsoft account.

136
00:07:05.010 --> 00:07:07.330
Did you ever have a Windows Live ID?

137
00:07:07.330 --> 00:07:11.760
That was renamed after a certain bit of
time, a couple of years back I believe,

138
00:07:11.760 --> 00:07:14.580
where they no longer called
it the Windows Live ID.

139
00:07:14.580 --> 00:07:16.020
They called it the Microsoft account.

140
00:07:16.020 --> 00:07:20.240
And if we check that out right here,
you can see that they even

141
00:07:20.240 --> 00:07:24.370
advertise it as one account,
and you can log in to

142
00:07:24.370 --> 00:07:29.480
all of these different Microsoft
cloud-based services that we have here.

143
00:07:29.480 --> 00:07:33.540
Notice that I can use this one
account to log into Outlook.

144
00:07:33.540 --> 00:07:40.440
We can use this for OneDrive, Office,
Windows, Skype, and even Xbox Live.

145
00:07:40.440 --> 00:07:44.350
Then you, MSN, Bing, and all the different
cloud-based services that we have.

146
00:07:44.350 --> 00:07:47.957
So that's an example of a federated
service that maybe you've already seen

147
00:07:47.957 --> 00:07:51.014
before and didn't realize what's
going on in the background.

148
00:07:51.014 --> 00:07:53.593
Which if you ever pay
attention to the link,

149
00:07:53.593 --> 00:07:58.126
you can tell it's federated because
there'll be, just for a brief second,

150
00:07:58.126 --> 00:08:02.870
You'll either see federated and then a
forward slash version one or something or

151
00:08:02.870 --> 00:08:07.754
you'll see ADFS, that's the Active
Director Federated Services that Microsoft

152
00:08:07.754 --> 00:08:13.030
is running in the background, in order to
do federated services for your account.

153
00:08:13.030 --> 00:08:15.530
Whether you're in the IT environment or
not.

154
00:08:15.530 --> 00:08:17.990
So this is one that you
can see beforehand.

155
00:08:17.990 --> 00:08:21.010
So federated identities,
keep in mind as a quick recap.

156
00:08:21.010 --> 00:08:23.550
Online identities, they start in
the Cloud they stay in the Cloud.

157
00:08:23.550 --> 00:08:27.460
Synchronized can be on premise or they
can be the ones that start in the Cloud,

158
00:08:27.460 --> 00:08:28.730
stay in the Cloud, and

159
00:08:28.730 --> 00:08:31.990
they synchronize across the different
subscriptions that your company has.

160
00:08:31.990 --> 00:08:37.000
You can also see federated identities
doing the same thing as well as even

161
00:08:37.000 --> 00:08:41.390
on an individual consumer level, you could
see that your Microsoft account, the MC or

162
00:08:41.390 --> 00:08:43.860
the MSA as they sometimes abbreviate it.

163
00:08:43.860 --> 00:08:47.070
Formerly known as the Windows Live ID,
allows you to log in to

164
00:08:47.070 --> 00:08:50.740
all Microsoft's cloud based services
from the consumer standpoint as well.

165
00:08:50.740 --> 00:08:51.340
>> Awesome.

166
00:08:51.340 --> 00:08:54.690
Now, Wes, now that we know what an ID is,
and the difference between the different

167
00:08:54.690 --> 00:08:57.870
kinds of identities that are out there for
us, what do we do?

168
00:08:57.870 --> 00:08:59.210
Where do we take that information and

169
00:08:59.210 --> 00:09:01.670
how do we start administering
our Cloud services?

170
00:09:01.670 --> 00:09:02.300
>> Very good.
Now,

171
00:09:02.300 --> 00:09:04.660
one of the first things you're gonna do
is you're gonna have to create users.

172
00:09:04.660 --> 00:09:05.750
Now, I've already gone ahead and

173
00:09:05.750 --> 00:09:10.080
set up some of the users and you've
probably seen us do this in the earlier

174
00:09:10.080 --> 00:09:12.400
episodes because we needed to
set up a global administrator.

175
00:09:12.400 --> 00:09:15.340
So I do have all ready, ready to go user.

176
00:09:15.340 --> 00:09:19.360
But let's go ahead and show you how
you could do, you can create a user.

177
00:09:19.360 --> 00:09:23.040
Now it's very easy here
inside of Office 365.

178
00:09:23.040 --> 00:09:27.370
You'll see a little plus button here or
you'll see what's known as a bulk edit.

179
00:09:27.370 --> 00:09:29.220
Let me make it a little easier for
you guys to see out there.

180
00:09:29.220 --> 00:09:32.150
So the plus is gonna be single user.

181
00:09:32.150 --> 00:09:35.620
If you're in a large organization
we'll show you this button coming up,

182
00:09:35.620 --> 00:09:40.920
this is where you can do bulk importing so
if you have like a comma separated value

183
00:09:40.920 --> 00:09:46.080
file, CSV file you can just put into that
and if you have the field in Excel already

184
00:09:46.080 --> 00:09:50.860
In your columns, it'll look at that comma
separated value file or CSV file and

185
00:09:50.860 --> 00:09:54.330
it'll import all those and then you
can import basically create a whole

186
00:09:54.330 --> 00:09:59.270
bunch of end users, reduce the burden of
administration and the complexity because,

187
00:09:59.270 --> 00:10:04.210
one file could create multiple users, I
don't know how many lines Excel supports,

188
00:10:04.210 --> 00:10:06.590
but, it'll definitely be
based on your subscription so

189
00:10:06.590 --> 00:10:07.750
you can do this all at one time.

190
00:10:07.750 --> 00:10:11.193
Let's go ahead and show you how
you can create a single user here.

191
00:10:15.278 --> 00:10:18.577
All right, now the first thing it does
is it takes me into the active user,

192
00:10:18.577 --> 00:10:21.040
looks like it wanted to refresh the page,
there we go.

193
00:10:22.110 --> 00:10:25.910
All right, and
we'll just name our user here,

194
00:10:25.910 --> 00:10:29.880
and I'll keep this one relatively
easy here for Wes's typing abilities.

195
00:10:29.880 --> 00:10:33.870
User01.
We'll call this User01 as well.

196
00:10:35.710 --> 00:10:37.600
And User01 again.

197
00:10:37.600 --> 00:10:38.890
And I'm just gonna change this,

198
00:10:38.890 --> 00:10:43.050
I'm not gonna make the person change
their password when they log in.

199
00:10:43.050 --> 00:10:45.940
Now keep in mind that what happens is,

200
00:10:45.940 --> 00:10:50.830
if you set this up, you can do two
types of password generation, right?

201
00:10:50.830 --> 00:10:55.910
We can do an auto generation,
an automatically generated password,

202
00:10:55.910 --> 00:11:00.600
and what it does is it'll send to this
email address that you put in here,

203
00:11:00.600 --> 00:11:05.400
it'll send the username and then the
temporary password that's put in place.

204
00:11:05.400 --> 00:11:10.160
But if you have some kind of onboard
policy, onboarding policy you might

205
00:11:10.160 --> 00:11:15.120
have a default password that you set
all of your user names to or your user

206
00:11:15.120 --> 00:11:18.080
accounts to when they first get hired on
to the company and they can change them.

207
00:11:18.080 --> 00:11:21.000
I'm gonna go ahead and
I'm gonna say that, for instance,

208
00:11:21.000 --> 00:11:23.120
we have an onboarding process here.

209
00:11:23.120 --> 00:11:25.919
So we've got a default password

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel continue looking at Office365 and InTune administration tasks. They pick up here by exploring the Service Health dash-board monitoring service. From here you can see what Microsoft is working on in their cloud environment which allows you to prepare for possible connectivity loss. They also show you how to log service support tickets to help resolve issues.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel look at configuring Microsoft's cloud email service, Exchange Online. They start with managing recipient resources like mailboxes, shared mailboxes, contacts, and email groups. Then they look at configuring Sharepoint Online; looking at external sharing, enabling RSS, and setting storage limits.

00:25:16.090 --> 00:25:17.090

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel continue cloud service configuration by taking a look at Skype for Business. They walk you through setting up user options, external communication settings, and setting dial-in settings for meetings. Then they jump into Microsoft InTune configuration. They show you how to work with the administration console, install the InTune Agent on clients, as well as create and deploy a configuration policy. They also show you setting up InTune for mobile devices.
episodes.title: Configure Cloud Services Part 2

00:18:55.440 --> 00:18:57.990
So what this does is it kind
of bridges the gap between

358
00:18:57.990 --> 00:19:01.180
the traditional management system
that we would use on premise and

359
00:19:01.180 --> 00:19:03.740
something that we can use across
the internet to devices that

360
00:19:03.740 --> 00:19:06.910
first aren't going to be inside
of our Active Directory domain.

361
00:19:06.910 --> 00:19:07.650
Or even more so

362
00:19:07.650 --> 00:19:12.200
have a limitation that they can't join
the domain even if they are on premise.

363
00:19:12.200 --> 00:19:14.140
And great question too.

364
00:19:14.140 --> 00:19:16.500
So I can go in here and
there's different types of policies.

365
00:19:16.500 --> 00:19:19.240
Compliance policies,
I'm not going to worry about them too much

366
00:19:19.240 --> 00:19:22.830
because these are ways that you can
control things like Samsung devices.

367
00:19:22.830 --> 00:19:24.570
These aren't for your Windows devices.

368
00:19:24.570 --> 00:19:27.570
But what we want
are configuration policies.

369
00:19:27.570 --> 00:19:31.870
And the configuration policies can
configure a lot of different things and

370
00:19:31.870 --> 00:19:33.560
a lot of different devices.

371
00:19:33.560 --> 00:19:38.240
So for instance, one of the reasons
it's no longer named Windows Intune,

372
00:19:38.240 --> 00:19:41.070
because it was kind of confusing,
we got Windows Intune.

373
00:19:41.070 --> 00:19:43.320
So, it manages just windows, right?

374
00:19:44.330 --> 00:19:49.140
No, it manages a lot of different devices,
you can see even Mac is in here as well.

375
00:19:49.140 --> 00:19:51.640
So, we're going to open Windows.

376
00:19:51.640 --> 00:19:52.580
All right.

377
00:19:52.580 --> 00:19:56.150
And we're kinda reiterate on something
that I had mentioned before.

378
00:19:56.150 --> 00:19:58.600
You have to pay attention to the policies

379
00:19:58.600 --> 00:20:02.500
because the policies tell you what
operating system is supported.

380
00:20:02.500 --> 00:20:06.270
And notice that some of these
are specific to Windows 10, right,

381
00:20:06.270 --> 00:20:10.590
they don;t say Windows 8.1 or later so
you have to be careful with that.

382
00:20:10.590 --> 00:20:14.690
So the other thing I want you to know too
is pay attention to whether it's mobile

383
00:20:14.690 --> 00:20:15.230
or not, right?

384
00:20:15.230 --> 00:20:17.030
You can see that this is Windows 10.

385
00:20:17.030 --> 00:20:18.740
And you'll see it now that I zoom in here.

386
00:20:18.740 --> 00:20:21.620
Notice it says desktop and mobile.

387
00:20:21.620 --> 00:20:24.140
But notice that this says phone only,
right.

388
00:20:24.140 --> 00:20:25.490
So pay attention.

389
00:20:25.490 --> 00:20:27.032
Are you doing MDM?

390
00:20:27.032 --> 00:20:28.766
Mobile device management?

391
00:20:28.766 --> 00:20:33.720
If you're doing mobile device management,
then this'll work with the phones.

392
00:20:33.720 --> 00:20:37.330
If you're looking for
something that's desktop and mobile,

393
00:20:37.330 --> 00:20:40.330
you have to pay attention to
the policy that you're gonna implement.

394
00:20:40.330 --> 00:20:42.450
So we'll go ahead and create the policy.

395
00:20:42.450 --> 00:20:46.530
Some of the policies We'll give you
a template, and they'll say hey,

396
00:20:46.530 --> 00:20:48.520
it's kinda like a best practice analysis.

397
00:20:48.520 --> 00:20:51.730
This is some of the common settings that
we've seen, and we'll make it easier for

398
00:20:51.730 --> 00:20:53.880
you, and we'll just have a template.

399
00:20:53.880 --> 00:20:56.500
And if you want, it puts the template
in place and you can come back and

400
00:20:56.500 --> 00:20:58.470
make some modifications to it.

401
00:20:58.470 --> 00:21:01.160
This one, obviously, as you can see,
the radio button's grayed out.

402
00:21:01.160 --> 00:21:03.460
It doesn't come with a template.

403
00:21:03.460 --> 00:21:05.431
So, we'll go ahead and create this policy.

404
00:21:07.767 --> 00:21:12.260
All right, now it sets
the policy up to be configured.

405
00:21:12.260 --> 00:21:15.920
We actually haven't created it,
it's kind of like a list that says,

406
00:21:15.920 --> 00:21:20.265
all right, what type of policy
are you looking for first.

407
00:21:20.265 --> 00:21:24.915
For instance, when I find a group
policy inside of Active Directory,

408
00:21:24.915 --> 00:21:27.445
I found the policy setting, but
I still haven't configured it.

409
00:21:27.445 --> 00:21:29.745
So that's one of the things
that we have to do here.

410
00:21:29.745 --> 00:21:34.586
So we'll call this My Policy.

411
00:21:34.586 --> 00:21:37.625
And this is something kinda interesting.

412
00:21:37.625 --> 00:21:44.350
Now if I scroll here, Dan, and I keep
scrolling It looks like I'm still where?

413
00:21:44.350 --> 00:21:44.990
>> In the general.

414
00:21:44.990 --> 00:21:45.900
>> In the general location.

415
00:21:45.900 --> 00:21:50.360
Now watch this, if I scroll all the way
back up and I go to Security and

416
00:21:50.360 --> 00:21:52.530
Cloud, it's just scrolling.

417
00:21:52.530 --> 00:21:54.260
It's just taking me to
the different locations.

418
00:21:54.260 --> 00:21:56.390
So don't let that confuse
you out there guys.

419
00:21:56.390 --> 00:22:00.660
If you see me scrolling here, well,
what we got here are applications.

420
00:22:00.660 --> 00:22:03.450
And that's a category in this list.

421
00:22:03.450 --> 00:22:06.650
So I could say,
allow web browser not configured.

422
00:22:06.650 --> 00:22:10.770
I could turn this on and say, allow the
web browser, and this is for mobile only.

423
00:22:10.770 --> 00:22:14.320
And that's one of the great things I
love about the Intune platform here.

424
00:22:14.320 --> 00:22:16.740
If you're not sure what a setting does,
see the information bar here,

425
00:22:16.740 --> 00:22:19.700
our little information icon?

426
00:22:19.700 --> 00:22:23.830
It gives you, just like the explain
tab does in a group policy object,

427
00:22:23.830 --> 00:22:26.660
where if you don't know what the setting
does, you hit the explain tab,

428
00:22:26.660 --> 00:22:30.570
it gives you the dissertation, or
explanation I should say, on what it does.

429
00:22:30.570 --> 00:22:33.880
So if you're not sure,
always check it out.

430
00:22:33.880 --> 00:22:35.960
Remember that some of these,
when you turn it on,

431
00:22:35.960 --> 00:22:37.990
doesn't necessarily mean it enforces it.

432
00:22:37.990 --> 00:22:41.560
Notice it says, Require a password
to unlock devices, and I said No.

433
00:22:41.560 --> 00:22:45.756
Well, by default, if it's disabled, right,

434
00:22:45.756 --> 00:22:49.230
well then I don't care about it.

435
00:22:49.230 --> 00:22:50.470
So just be careful there.

436
00:22:50.470 --> 00:22:54.180
And what I can do is, I'll turn this
one on, and I'll save the policy.

437
00:22:56.260 --> 00:22:59.380
All right, and now this is the point
where it deploys the policy.

438
00:22:59.380 --> 00:23:03.500
And what happens here is there's a
communication between the Intune platform

439
00:23:03.500 --> 00:23:05.980
and the agent you just
seen us install there.

440
00:23:05.980 --> 00:23:09.220
And what's going to happen is at
the next update, it's gonna look for

441
00:23:09.220 --> 00:23:10.380
a couple things, the agent is.

442
00:23:10.380 --> 00:23:13.530
One of the things the agent is gonna
look for is are there any updates.

443
00:23:14.670 --> 00:23:15.700
And then it's also going to look for

444
00:23:15.700 --> 00:23:20.540
those policies, and it'll pull those
policies down, and it will configure them.

445
00:23:20.540 --> 00:23:23.970
Now inside of an on premise
Active Directory solution, right,

446
00:23:23.970 --> 00:23:27.690
we do those with something called CSEs on
the computers, the Client Side Extensions.

447
00:23:27.690 --> 00:23:30.180
They're what connect to
the domain controller and

448
00:23:30.180 --> 00:23:32.430
say hey, are those policy settings there?

449
00:23:32.430 --> 00:23:34.470
Do I need to make any
configuration changes?

450
00:23:34.470 --> 00:23:37.380
And if I do, I'm gonna go ahead and
rifle off and change all the settings

451
00:23:37.380 --> 00:23:40.030
accordingly, according to
the policy in Active Directory.

452
00:23:40.030 --> 00:23:43.560
The agent here in InTune
is what does that, right?

453
00:23:43.560 --> 00:23:46.730
Almost the same concept,
it connects to the Intune platform.

454
00:23:46.730 --> 00:23:50.760
And it says are there any new policies
that I need to look at and if they do.

455
00:23:50.760 --> 00:23:51.800
Hold on a second.

456
00:23:51.800 --> 00:23:52.550
I see a change.

457
00:23:52.550 --> 00:23:56.250
Let me go ahead and I'll apply them to
the machine, so the machine is compliant.

458
00:23:56.250 --> 00:23:57.337
We'll go ahead and deploy this.

459
00:23:57.337 --> 00:23:59.935
And it asks us, well,
what do you want to deploy this?

460
00:23:59.935 --> 00:24:03.164
What group of devices do
you want to Deploy this to.

461
00:24:03.164 --> 00:24:06.600
And I can select all
computers if I want to,

462
00:24:06.600 --> 00:24:11.480
I can choose OK, and
it will process the request for me.

463
00:24:11.480 --> 00:24:16.990
So again another one that isn't really
too difficult when it comes down to it.

464
00:24:16.990 --> 00:24:20.400
Now, I can also set up notifications
if I want as well, and

465
00:24:20.400 --> 00:24:22.380
this is through alerts here.

466
00:24:22.380 --> 00:24:24.380
And let me mention the dashboard,

467
00:24:24.380 --> 00:24:28.650
the dashboard sometimes doesn't get
some of the recognition that it should.

468
00:24:28.650 --> 00:24:31.870
Notice the dashboard is
the jump link right here and

469
00:24:31.870 --> 00:24:34.660
I can see right away I've got some alerts.

470
00:24:34.660 --> 00:24:39.840
So notice the tile interface, when I
log in, I see those alerts right away.

471
00:24:39.840 --> 00:24:43.050
Now if I click ALERTS,
notice that here on the left-hand side,

472
00:24:43.050 --> 00:24:46.350
contextual pane, takes me right
down to what I just clicked.

473
00:24:46.350 --> 00:24:49.860
And I can see some of the alerts
if I want to, I can review these,

474
00:24:49.860 --> 00:24:54.959
I can also set them to alert me
as an administrator if I want.

475
00:24:56.540 --> 00:25:00.470
All right, and then one of the last things
I think that you should really know

476
00:25:00.470 --> 00:25:03.490
are some of the different mobile
policies that you have here.

477
00:25:03.490 --> 00:25:07.778
And when it comes to the mobile policies,
again one of the things that I would pay

478
00:25:07.778 --> 00:25:10.466
attention to is when you
look at these policies and

479
00:25:10.466 --> 00:25:14.882
the policies that you wanna add, find out
which ones are based on mobile devices,

480
00:25:14.882 --> 00:25:16.808
mobile operating systems, okay?

481
00:25:16.808 --> 00:25:21.420
So with Windows you really have
to kinda look, you gotta search.

482
00:25:21.420 --> 00:25:24.080
Like we've seen one setting that was for
Windows 10 mobile only.

483
00:25:24.080 --> 00:25:26.940
One that was for Windows phone 8, right?

484
00:25:26.940 --> 00:25:30.180
So that's mix and
mingled with the desktops, right,

485
00:25:30.180 --> 00:25:34.260
the work stations as well, client based
operating systems and not just mobile.

486
00:25:34.260 --> 00:25:36.780
Well it's kinda easy to tell
if it's an Android device,

487
00:25:36.780 --> 00:25:38.490
it's gonna be some kind of mobile device,
right?

488
00:25:38.490 --> 00:25:43.022
If it happens to be iOS,
well we know that iOS is gonna be what?

489
00:25:43.022 --> 00:25:46.380
It's gonna be an iPhone or
it's gonna be an iPad.

490
00:25:46.380 --> 00:25:53.450
So we can do mobile policies for what
they call MDM, Mobile Device Management.

491
00:25:53.450 --> 00:25:58.273
See the Windows Intune software is based
on an industry wide standard out there

492
00:25:58.273 --> 00:26:01.721
that is maintain by
the Open Mobile Alliance, the OMA.

493
00:26:01.721 --> 00:26:06.511
And it's just a consortium that
manages the client server protocol

494
00:26:06.511 --> 00:26:10.881
called the Open Mobile Device
Management Infrastructure and

495
00:26:10.881 --> 00:26:12.994
this falls right under that.

496
00:26:12.994 --> 00:26:16.963
So what you have to do in order to set
these policies in place is that whatever

497
00:26:16.963 --> 00:26:18.223
that mobile device is,

498
00:26:18.223 --> 00:26:22.381
you've gotta set Windows Intune as
the mobile device management authority,

499
00:26:22.381 --> 00:26:26.431
and what you're saying is, I give you
the authority to manage this device.

500
00:26:26.431 --> 00:26:28.869
But once that's set up you
can deploy these policies,

501
00:26:28.869 --> 00:26:31.480
then you can control your
mobile devices as well.

502
00:26:31.480 --> 00:26:34.400
>> Awesome.
Well obviously there's a lot to Intune,

503
00:26:34.400 --> 00:26:38.290
but it's also, once you get it down, once
you understand all of the concepts, all

504
00:26:38.290 --> 00:26:41.730
the practical ways in which you can use
it, it can become a very powerful tool.

505
00:26:41.730 --> 00:26:45.831
And especially necessary if you're gonna
be working in a very blended environment

506
00:26:45.831 --> 00:26:48.478
with devices that are unable
to be joined to a domain.

507
00:26:48.478 --> 00:26:49.877
Or if you don't have a domain, but

508
00:26:49.877 --> 00:26:53.261
you still wanna have some control over the
computers that connect to your network,

509
00:26:53.261 --> 00:26:56.140
or devices that connect to your network,
Intune's the way to go.

510
00:26:56.140 --> 00:26:57.810
So Wes, a lot of cool information.

511
00:26:57.810 --> 00:26:58.980
>> Yeah man.
>> Is there anything else that we need to

512
00:26:58.980 --> 00:27:01.740
know about Intune, specifically for
this exam or this show?

513
00:27:01.740 --> 00:27:07.400
>> No, I would say not, but I would like
to reiterate what Dan has stated earlier.

514
00:27:07.400 --> 00:27:10.710
When it comes down to it, ultimately if
you're doing this in an enterprise level

515
00:27:10.710 --> 00:27:13.630
environment, he was right,
they do want you to integrate this console

516
00:27:13.630 --> 00:27:15.820
with the System Center
Configuration Manager.

517
00:27:15.820 --> 00:27:19.630
But it is not something that you
have to worry about on this exam.

518
00:27:19.630 --> 00:27:24.170
But keep that in mind if you're gonna go
on to more of the higher level cloud based

519
00:27:24.170 --> 00:27:26.650
certifications because you
might need to know that fact.

520
00:27:26.650 --> 00:27:29.320
But for
MTA Cloud fundamentals you should be okay.

521
00:27:29.320 --> 00:27:30.690
>> Awesome, well thank you so much for

522
00:27:30.690 --> 00:27:32.850
showing us this and
explaining this out for us.

523
00:27:32.850 --> 00:27:35.730
Intune's not so much of a mystery,
hopefully, any longer for you.

524
00:27:35.730 --> 00:27:37.890
That being said, we thank you for
joining us today.

525
00:27:37.890 --> 00:27:39.700
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV,

526
00:27:39.700 --> 00:27:41.410
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

527
00:27:41.410 --> 00:27:42.230
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

528
00:27:42.230 --> 00:27:43.606
>> And we'll see you next time.

topics.title: Use and configure Microsoft cloud services

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike look at some common issues dealing with users connecting to cloud services. They demonstrate how to use tools like ipconfig, ping, and nslookup to troubleshoot connectivity. They also talk about the importance of troubleshooting the physical side, like network adapters and networking media as well.
episodes.title: Support Cloud Users
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.953 --> 00:00:16.090
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.090 --> 00:00:20.550
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and today
we're doing our MTA Cloud Fundamentals.

4
00:00:20.550 --> 00:00:22.298
And specifically, in this episode,

5
00:00:22.298 --> 00:00:24.875
we're gonna be going over
supporting our cloud users.

6
00:00:24.875 --> 00:00:27.640
Our users are obviously
important part of our business.

7
00:00:27.640 --> 00:00:31.200
We've got to make sure that they can
access what they need to do their job,

8
00:00:31.200 --> 00:00:32.558
to make organization money.

9
00:00:32.558 --> 00:00:35.550
So we've gotta be able to help
them out when they have trouble

10
00:00:35.550 --> 00:00:37.630
accessing these cloud services we provide.

11
00:00:37.630 --> 00:00:41.350
And here to help us figure out how
to do all that is Mr. Wes Bryan.

12
00:00:41.350 --> 00:00:42.140
How's it going, Wes?

13
00:00:42.140 --> 00:00:43.080
>> Oh, it's going great, Mike.

14
00:00:43.080 --> 00:00:44.760
As always, thank you for
having me back here.

15
00:00:44.760 --> 00:00:47.930
That's right, we're gonna be talking
about how we can keep those end users

16
00:00:47.930 --> 00:00:50.040
connected and if they can't get connected,

17
00:00:50.040 --> 00:00:54.740
some of the things that we can do to
find out maybe what the issue might be.

18
00:00:54.740 --> 00:00:58.036
Remember, that when it comes to
supporting your end users, it is a very,

19
00:00:58.036 --> 00:01:00.548
very important thing,
at least from an IT stand point.

20
00:01:00.548 --> 00:01:04.610
And up until this point, we've really been
talking about, a lot of the fundamentals.

21
00:01:04.610 --> 00:01:08.599
We've shown you around things like
Exchange Online, SharePoint Online,

22
00:01:08.599 --> 00:01:09.730
Skype for Business.

23
00:01:09.730 --> 00:01:13.280
Well, each one of those has
their own communication channels

24
00:01:13.280 --> 00:01:15.410
even though it's collectively Office 365.

25
00:01:15.410 --> 00:01:18.070
And there are gonna be some
steps that you're gonna take

26
00:01:18.070 --> 00:01:21.550
to remedy some of the issues
in each Individual platform.

27
00:01:21.550 --> 00:01:24.300
One of the first things that we need
to look at is, well, the sign in right?

28
00:01:24.300 --> 00:01:26.710
Doesn't matter what service we have,
right?

29
00:01:26.710 --> 00:01:30.310
If we can't sign in,
doesn't matter if have an Exchange set up,

30
00:01:30.310 --> 00:01:33.670
doesn't matter if I have SharePoint,
certainly not Skype for business, right?

31
00:01:33.670 --> 00:01:37.924
Voice over IP, everything's gonna
revolve around a connection there, so

32
00:01:37.924 --> 00:01:40.125
we gotta start a software as a service.

33
00:01:40.125 --> 00:01:42.870
Remember that our major platform, right,

34
00:01:42.870 --> 00:01:46.960
our major connectivity application
is gonna be the web browser.

35
00:01:46.960 --> 00:01:50.980
So, we've gotta figure out,
is it basic network communications or

36
00:01:50.980 --> 00:01:53.488
is the web browser that might have issues.

37
00:01:53.488 --> 00:01:57.715
Mike, one of the things,
I know you're very security-centric there.

38
00:01:57.715 --> 00:01:59.518
I think of things like firewalls and

39
00:01:59.518 --> 00:02:03.545
we're just gonna kinda show you a way
around the Windows operating system, and

40
00:02:03.545 --> 00:02:07.227
some of the steps that you can take to
ensure that your users can connect.

41
00:02:07.227 --> 00:02:10.440
>> All right, now Wes, I would assume
that the first thing that we need to do,

42
00:02:10.440 --> 00:02:13.756
if we're going to sign in to any type of
application or a cloud based service,

43
00:02:13.756 --> 00:02:16.180
well, I need to be able to
get to the logon page, right?

44
00:02:16.180 --> 00:02:18.805
I need somewhere to type in
my username and password.

45
00:02:18.805 --> 00:02:22.430
If I can't get there, then I'm not
gonna be very successful at logging in.

46
00:02:22.430 --> 00:02:25.580
So, let's look at some of the issues
that we might have just connecting to

47
00:02:25.580 --> 00:02:26.890
the log-on page.

48
00:02:26.890 --> 00:02:28.020
>> Yeah, absolutely.

49
00:02:28.020 --> 00:02:30.560
So one of the first things that
we're gonna do is we're gonna look,

50
00:02:30.560 --> 00:02:32.900
starting very basic, right, the URL.

51
00:02:32.900 --> 00:02:34.085
Are you typing the URL right?

52
00:02:34.085 --> 00:02:37.270
