501
00:25:55.120 --> 00:25:59.670
So, if it happens to be a wired
connection, check the back of

502
00:25:59.670 --> 00:26:03.660
the computer, check the network adapter
and look for link lights, right?

503
00:26:03.660 --> 00:26:07.280
Very simply, you've got a series of link
lights, and if there's activity on them,

504
00:26:07.280 --> 00:26:09.520
then chances are,
you've got a communication.

505
00:26:09.520 --> 00:26:12.710
If you look back there I know, in fact
I've got one computer that I've had

506
00:26:12.710 --> 00:26:18.220
a problem with the driver as it's gone
through different Windows versions,

507
00:26:18.220 --> 00:26:21.100
and I honestly, I can't say that
it's the driver within Windows.

508
00:26:21.100 --> 00:26:23.878
I think the network adapter might be
failing, and I'll go back there and I'll

509
00:26:23.878 --> 00:26:28.470
plug it in, it's got a solid light, and
I can tell that there's a problem with it.

510
00:26:28.470 --> 00:26:29.530
It's not communicating.

511
00:26:29.530 --> 00:26:33.352
So that could be a telltale sign
that there's some kind of problem,

512
00:26:33.352 --> 00:26:35.220
something's problematic.

513
00:26:35.220 --> 00:26:40.336
Now, just as simple as that,
is your network adapter enabled?

514
00:26:40.336 --> 00:26:43.076
Let me show you that inside
of the operating system here.

515
00:26:43.076 --> 00:26:48.863
Now my head's kinda covering it up here,
but if you were to get into the little

516
00:26:48.863 --> 00:26:53.939
monitor icon in the lower right-hand
corner of your taskbar here,

517
00:26:53.939 --> 00:26:58.052
will allow you to open the Network and
Sharing Center.

518
00:26:58.052 --> 00:27:01.458
And this is kind of your one-stop shop
when you're troubleshooting things

519
00:27:01.458 --> 00:27:04.544
like your network connections inside
of your operating system, and

520
00:27:04.544 --> 00:27:06.165
it's a good place to know.

521
00:27:06.165 --> 00:27:10.780
And if I look right away, I can see that
I am connected to a private network.

522
00:27:10.780 --> 00:27:14.200
All right, and
I can see the connections here, Ethernet0.

523
00:27:14.200 --> 00:27:17.302
Now, I can click this task link, they've
got these little task links all over

524
00:27:17.302 --> 00:27:19.289
the place, and I have to say,
I really like them.

525
00:27:19.289 --> 00:27:20.620
At first, I was like,

526
00:27:20.620 --> 00:27:25.117
you give me a link that leads me to a door
that leads me to another closed door.

527
00:27:25.117 --> 00:27:29.369
And in Office 365, I have to tell you,
some of those jump links as much

528
00:27:29.369 --> 00:27:32.942
I'm putting my foot in my mouth here,
I actually like them.

529
00:27:32.942 --> 00:27:35.859
They take you to some of
the common locations, so

530
00:27:35.859 --> 00:27:40.845
I could go to connections here or
I could go to change adapter settings.

531
00:27:40.845 --> 00:27:41.645
And let me show you that.

532
00:27:41.645 --> 00:27:43.685
So Ethernet0 you'll see here.

533
00:27:43.685 --> 00:27:47.445
If I decide to choose Ethernet0,
it just takes me to the properties.

534
00:27:47.445 --> 00:27:52.095
Now I wanna go ahead and kinda show
you the change adapter settings, and

535
00:27:52.095 --> 00:27:56.308
notice that Ethernet0 here as well,
and I could choose the status.

536
00:27:56.308 --> 00:27:59.740
Now, it's as simple as enabling and
disabling the network adapter here, so

537
00:27:59.740 --> 00:28:03.060
let me go ahead and just disable it and
see what would you find if you

538
00:28:03.060 --> 00:28:05.730
determined that, hey,
we don't have network communications.

539
00:28:05.730 --> 00:28:09.740
I've tried the services,
I've tried ping, nothing seems to work.

540
00:28:09.740 --> 00:28:13.140
Could be quite as simple as just
right-clicking on that network icon for

541
00:28:13.140 --> 00:28:15.320
your local area connection and
choosing enable, right?

542
00:28:15.320 --> 00:28:20.310
If I've got [LAUGH] the power turned off,
or at least the communication on

543
00:28:20.310 --> 00:28:23.170
the network adapter, it doesn't matter
what your operating system knows.

544
00:28:23.170 --> 00:28:25.542
The one thing that it knows is
your network adapter's sleeping.

545
00:28:25.542 --> 00:28:29.460
>> Absolutely, and this one's bitten me
a couple of times, especially on wireless,

546
00:28:29.460 --> 00:28:33.460
on the radios, cuz a lot of these laptops
nowadays, we'll want them to go to sleep.

547
00:28:33.460 --> 00:28:37.706
We want them to reduce the power
consumption to save that battery life, so

548
00:28:37.706 --> 00:28:41.062
it will have some kind of key or
combination function key,

549
00:28:41.062 --> 00:28:45.648
or like on my Alienware, it's actually
a softkey that can turn that radio on and

550
00:28:45.648 --> 00:28:46.964
off for the wireless.

551
00:28:46.964 --> 00:28:49.301
And the problem is,
I'll hit it accidentally and

552
00:28:49.301 --> 00:28:51.637
not realize that I've
turned that radio off, and

553
00:28:51.637 --> 00:28:54.487
you'll wonder why all of
a sudden I've lost connectivity.

554
00:28:54.487 --> 00:28:56.652
You start doing some troubleshooting,

555
00:28:56.652 --> 00:29:00.036
oh, I accidentally turned
the wireless network adapter off.

556
00:29:00.036 --> 00:29:04.920
I remember an old ThinkPad that
actually had a switch on the bottom.

557
00:29:04.920 --> 00:29:08.310
So you had to flip the laptop over and
there was a little tiny switch down there,

558
00:29:08.310 --> 00:29:10.410
and I remember this person
brought me that laptop.

559
00:29:10.410 --> 00:29:13.160
And I'm troubleshooting and I'm going,
why can I not get this to work?

560
00:29:13.160 --> 00:29:17.400
Come to find out there's a physical
switch to power up that wireless adapter.

561
00:29:17.400 --> 00:29:20.276
>> Yeah, yeah, definitely, as many times
as I've fat-fingered the keyboard,

562
00:29:20.276 --> 00:29:21.811
I've done it a couple of times too myself.

563
00:29:21.811 --> 00:29:24.275
>> [LAUGH]
>> I was only trying to adjust

564
00:29:24.275 --> 00:29:26.940
the brightness, but
now apparently, I'm not so

565
00:29:26.940 --> 00:29:29.868
bright because I can't
communicate to the Internet.

566
00:29:29.868 --> 00:29:33.110
[LAUGH] All right, so good, good advice.

567
00:29:33.110 --> 00:29:36.750
The other thing that you might wanna do,
we talked about enabling or

568
00:29:36.750 --> 00:29:38.555
disabling the network adapter.

569
00:29:38.555 --> 00:29:40.320
We've talked about
the physical connection, and

570
00:29:40.320 --> 00:29:43.080
keep in mind that the physical
connection can be a physical wire,

571
00:29:43.080 --> 00:29:45.790
or just like Mike said, radiated energy.

572
00:29:45.790 --> 00:29:46.540
It doesn't matter,

573
00:29:46.540 --> 00:29:49.790
the difference in that one is,
what are you using to send the signal?

574
00:29:49.790 --> 00:29:50.730
When it comes down to it,

575
00:29:50.730 --> 00:29:53.710
the properties in your network
adapter are gonna really be the same.

576
00:29:53.710 --> 00:29:57.320
So, the next thing that we, hey, and
we've talked about link lights too.

577
00:29:57.320 --> 00:30:00.630
Let me also show where
you can manually set

578
00:30:00.630 --> 00:30:04.140
the TCP/IP properties of your network
adapter cuz it's gonna be important.

579
00:30:04.140 --> 00:30:06.775
All right, if I'm here in,
same location by the way guys,

580
00:30:06.775 --> 00:30:09.641
we're in the network connection,
we haven't gone anywhere.

581
00:30:09.641 --> 00:30:14.058
And I can choose status,
we've seen the ipconfig, right,

582
00:30:14.058 --> 00:30:17.187
and it's showed us our information here.

583
00:30:17.187 --> 00:30:21.794
And I could choose details, and I can get
the same GUI based information inside of

584
00:30:21.794 --> 00:30:25.407
the status dialogue box that
you've seen inside of ipconfig.

585
00:30:25.407 --> 00:30:29.424
But what I really want is this little
properties icon right here, right?

586
00:30:29.424 --> 00:30:31.851
See this little properties button,
and keep in mind,

587
00:30:31.851 --> 00:30:33.290
standard users can't do this.

588
00:30:33.290 --> 00:30:34.300
Notice a little shield there,

589
00:30:34.300 --> 00:30:37.020
that's directly related to something
known as the user account control,

590
00:30:37.020 --> 00:30:40.070
which means standard users
will not be able to do this.

591
00:30:40.070 --> 00:30:43.424
So if you're on a help desk ticket, you
got a standard user sitting at the desk,

592
00:30:43.424 --> 00:30:46.999
they can look at stuff all they want, but
they're not gonna be able to configure it.

593
00:30:46.999 --> 00:30:50.226
So you might need to use a remote
desktop or sneaker note at that point.

594
00:30:50.226 --> 00:30:55.460
So I'll choose properties here and
a few of the different

595
00:30:55.460 --> 00:31:00.049
network protocols that
are bound to the adaptor.

596
00:31:00.049 --> 00:31:03.841
But the one I really want is just
Internet Protocol Version 4, TCP IPV4 and

597
00:31:03.841 --> 00:31:05.389
I can choose properties here.

598
00:31:05.389 --> 00:31:09.736
And I can see that this is set up for
DHCP, which is in this case,

599
00:31:09.736 --> 00:31:12.541
from a client standpoint is what I want.

600
00:31:12.541 --> 00:31:17.097
Like I said, you might have a few handful
of work stations that maybe are gonna be

601
00:31:17.097 --> 00:31:18.462
manually configured.

602
00:31:18.462 --> 00:31:21.506
A lot of times, we save that for
things like our servers and

603
00:31:21.506 --> 00:31:24.242
devices that are providing services and
printers,

604
00:31:24.242 --> 00:31:28.423
but at least I can check this information,
I can verify that it is set up to DHCP.

605
00:31:28.423 --> 00:31:29.978
So when it comes down to it, Mike.

606
00:31:29.978 --> 00:31:30.489
>> Mm-hm.

607
00:31:30.489 --> 00:31:33.856
>> As long as know of a few different
locations, again, remember,

608
00:31:33.856 --> 00:31:37.176
check your services, DHCP and
DNS are gonna be very important.

609
00:31:37.176 --> 00:31:39.514
Routing information off
of your local network,

610
00:31:39.514 --> 00:31:41.940
that default gateway is important as well.

611
00:31:41.940 --> 00:31:44.300
And then it comes down to things
like physical connections and

612
00:31:44.300 --> 00:31:48.070
then the properties of the IP address or
the network adapter themselves.

613
00:31:48.070 --> 00:31:51.430
If you check a handful of these things
now, then we can go into more, and

614
00:31:51.430 --> 00:31:53.278
not necessarily advanced things, but

615
00:31:53.278 --> 00:31:57.256
then we can start to troubleshoot things
like software from a software standpoint.

616
00:31:57.256 --> 00:31:59.717
But looks like we're gonna have
to do that in another episode.

617
00:31:59.717 --> 00:32:03.045
>> We are, Wes, I was gonna have to cut
you off there, cuz I know you got a little

618
00:32:03.045 --> 00:32:05.905
more information to help us
troubleshooting our connectivity or

619
00:32:05.905 --> 00:32:08.141
supporting our cloud users,
but unfortunately,

620
00:32:08.141 --> 00:32:09.655
we are out of time on this episode.

621
00:32:09.655 --> 00:32:12.755
Good look at some of those
basic TCPIP troubleshooting,

622
00:32:12.755 --> 00:32:15.090
which is really where we've gotta start.

623
00:32:15.090 --> 00:32:19.380
Cloud based or not, we've gotta be able
to connect to our local area network so

624
00:32:19.380 --> 00:32:22.710
we can get out to the rest of our network
and then hopefully out to the cloud.

625
00:32:22.710 --> 00:32:23.620
So great information there.

626
00:32:23.620 --> 00:32:25.790
Thank you for that, Wes,
great demonstrations.

627
00:32:25.790 --> 00:32:27.840
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

628
00:32:27.840 --> 00:32:29.320
Signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

629
00:32:29.320 --> 00:32:29.896
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

630
00:32:29.896 --> 00:32:30.825
>> And we'll see you next time.

631
00:32:30.825 --> 00:32:37.420
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike Windows continue to look at supporting cloud users. They focus their troubleshooting on firewall issues, looking at both the Windows Firewall console and the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security. They demonstrate using Telnet to test connectivity based on port number. they also look at browser and proxy settings.
episodes.title: Support Cloud Users Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.066 --> 00:00:10.066
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.971 --> 00:00:15.000
>> Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro TV.

3
00:00:15.000 --> 00:00:16.980
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:16.980 --> 00:00:20.150
Today we're doing our
MTA cloud fundamentals.

5
00:00:20.150 --> 00:00:23.090
And in this episode we're
actually doing a continuation of

6
00:00:23.090 --> 00:00:25.230
our supporting cloud users.

7
00:00:25.230 --> 00:00:28.750
So far we've taken a look at
doing some basic troubleshooting.

8
00:00:28.750 --> 00:00:32.640
If I've got a user or users that
are having trouble connecting out there to

9
00:00:32.640 --> 00:00:35.370
these cloud services, where do we start?

10
00:00:35.370 --> 00:00:38.800
A lot of it really is basic trouble
shooting that we've learned

11
00:00:38.800 --> 00:00:40.500
in say courses like network plus.

12
00:00:40.500 --> 00:00:45.210
Looking at our TCPIP settings,
using IP config, Ping,

13
00:00:45.210 --> 00:00:50.590
NS look up, those kind of things to
verify our network connectivity.

14
00:00:50.590 --> 00:00:54.190
Whether it's a local resource, or
whether it's a cloud based resource.

15
00:00:54.190 --> 00:00:57.120
And there's still a few more things
that we need to go through to make

16
00:00:57.120 --> 00:01:01.590
sure that I can get out there to the
internet and get to those cloud services.

17
00:01:01.590 --> 00:01:04.140
And here to help us with
that as always is Wes Bryan.

18
00:01:04.140 --> 00:01:04.950
How's it going, Wes?

19
00:01:04.950 --> 00:01:05.600
>> Going great, man.

20
00:01:05.600 --> 00:01:08.500
It's great to be back here
again as always with IT ProTV.

21
00:01:08.500 --> 00:01:12.590
And that's right, a few of the extra
things that you know we just

22
00:01:12.590 --> 00:01:15.660
quite didn't get to fit
in the last episode, and

23
00:01:15.660 --> 00:01:18.910
one of the first ones we have
to think about is the firewalls.

24
00:01:18.910 --> 00:01:19.900
Firewall issues.

25
00:01:19.900 --> 00:01:21.890
Could the firewalls be
causing the problem?

26
00:01:21.890 --> 00:01:25.050
Well, we need to find find
out if that's the case.

27
00:01:25.050 --> 00:01:26.130
Now I'm gonna go ahead and

28
00:01:26.130 --> 00:01:29.420
touch base on the one that you'll have to
have administrative, well I guess you'll

29
00:01:29.420 --> 00:01:32.620
have to have administrative
access to get to either one.

30
00:01:32.620 --> 00:01:36.700
But you might not have easy access
to a network based firewall.

31
00:01:36.700 --> 00:01:40.720
So that's gonna be the one that
stands out on your network there.

32
00:01:40.720 --> 00:01:43.635
And it's screening all the traffic
that's coming into your network.

33
00:01:43.635 --> 00:01:45.990
And going to any user
inside of the network.

34
00:01:45.990 --> 00:01:50.190
And then likewise, outbound
communications are being scrutinized,

35
00:01:50.190 --> 00:01:52.780
could be allowed, or could be blocked.

36
00:01:52.780 --> 00:01:55.470
That one right there again,

37
00:01:55.470 --> 00:01:57.670
is not going to be something that's so
easy for you to tell.

38
00:01:57.670 --> 00:02:02.100
However, there are some some steps
you can take Inside of the operating

39
00:02:02.100 --> 00:02:06.150
system to ensure that it's not
a firewall that's causing your issue.

40
00:02:06.150 --> 00:02:10.120
So we just kinda wanna look around at what
is known as a software based firewall.

41
00:02:10.120 --> 00:02:14.300
The software based firewall is
also called a host based firewall.

42
00:02:14.300 --> 00:02:18.650
That is screening the traffic that's
coming to and from the workstation.

43
00:02:18.650 --> 00:02:23.080
So if you get an end user that calls up
and says, well hey, I can't communicate

44
00:02:23.080 --> 00:02:26.910
outbound, or I'm not receiving emails,
well we might have to find out

45
00:02:26.910 --> 00:02:30.080
if there's a firewall configuration
that might be causing the problem.

46
00:02:30.080 --> 00:02:32.980
Whether it's a small business or
whether it's an enterprise business,

47
00:02:32.980 --> 00:02:36.050
a lot of times you're gonna control this
through something like group policy, and

48
00:02:36.050 --> 00:02:39.760
your administrators are gonna set out
group policy objects that will configure

49
00:02:39.760 --> 00:02:40.370
those settings.

50
00:02:40.370 --> 00:02:43.045
But we want to make sure those
settings are configured.

51
00:02:43.045 --> 00:02:44.680
Cuz I can tell you what, Mike.

52
00:02:44.680 --> 00:02:46.245
>> The admins never make mistakes.

53
00:02:46.245 --> 00:02:47.080
[LAUGH] no never.

54
00:02:47.080 --> 00:02:50.320
>> And we never configure
things without our glasses.

55
00:02:50.320 --> 00:02:52.271
You know, that's not a bad thing, right?

56
00:02:52.271 --> 00:02:55.887
[LAUGH] make standard end users
enterprise administrators.

57
00:02:55.887 --> 00:02:58.070
We've never seen that happen before.

58
00:02:58.070 --> 00:02:59.020
>> Guilty as charged.

59
00:02:59.020 --> 00:03:04.120
>> [LAUGH] so you guys,
let's let you in on the joke here.

60
00:03:04.120 --> 00:03:05.660
Mike and I worked for

61
00:03:05.660 --> 00:03:10.150
a company before and I needed some
functionality I needed to perform, and

62
00:03:10.150 --> 00:03:13.160
it really wasn't something that needed
a lot of administrative functionality.

63
00:03:13.160 --> 00:03:15.530
Mike accidentally made
me the enterprise admin.

64
00:03:15.530 --> 00:03:18.329
Now I'm in charge of the whole domain and
I locked him out, right?

65
00:03:18.329 --> 00:03:21.040
[LAUGH]
>> The principle of lease privilege?

66
00:03:21.040 --> 00:03:22.850
What the heck.
>> [LAUGH] yeah, there you go.

67
00:03:22.850 --> 00:03:28.050
So, this is one of the reasons that you
might wanna be checking your firewalls.

68
00:03:28.050 --> 00:03:30.820
Hopefully your admins can
configure this for you.

69
00:03:30.820 --> 00:03:32.620
Let's go ahead and show you that.

70
00:03:32.620 --> 00:03:34.600
A couple of different ways
that you can do this.

71
00:03:34.600 --> 00:03:38.990
This is inside of Windows 10 here that
we're looking at, latest and greatest.

72
00:03:38.990 --> 00:03:40.760
And we can go the traditional way.

73
00:03:40.760 --> 00:03:44.870
One of the things to keep in
mind is that with Windows 8.1,

74
00:03:44.870 --> 00:03:49.120
Windows 8, Windows 7, the way I'm
showing you at first is gonna be one of

75
00:03:49.120 --> 00:03:52.710
the easiest ways to get there and it works
across all of those operating systems.

76
00:03:52.710 --> 00:03:53.410
And then I'll come back and

77
00:03:53.410 --> 00:03:57.940
show you one that's a little more
specific to Windows 10 and its interface.

78
00:03:57.940 --> 00:04:03.090
So starting with Windows 8,
8.1 actually it was Windows 8.

79
00:04:03.090 --> 00:04:07.260
They started with the administrative
little quicklings menu here just by right

80
00:04:07.260 --> 00:04:09.050
clicking on your little windows tile.

81
00:04:09.050 --> 00:04:12.100
And I can tell you it's
a very handy thing to have.

82
00:04:12.100 --> 00:04:15.570
And what we're gonna do is we're
gonna go to control panel here.

83
00:04:15.570 --> 00:04:17.320
We bring up the Control Panel.

84
00:04:17.320 --> 00:04:19.390
This really hasn't changed too much.

85
00:04:19.390 --> 00:04:22.860
A couple of naming conventions
have changed just slightly,

86
00:04:22.860 --> 00:04:24.190
a traditional control panel.

87
00:04:24.190 --> 00:04:30.720
So again, Windows 7, Windows 8, 8.1,
and you can see here in Windows 10.

88
00:04:30.720 --> 00:04:32.740
So good universal way to get there.

89
00:04:32.740 --> 00:04:34.390
Now we're gonna be under System and
Security.

90
00:04:35.390 --> 00:04:38.380
And then we have the Windows
firewall right here.

91
00:04:38.380 --> 00:04:39.880
Now when we look at the basic firewall,

320
00:16:19.940 --> 00:16:22.060
that it's not causing the problem too.

321
00:16:22.060 --> 00:16:24.470
So looks like we've got
our communications,

322
00:16:24.470 --> 00:16:25.890
looks like our ports are running good.

323
00:16:25.890 --> 00:16:29.460
So we move along in
the troubleshooting process.

324
00:16:29.460 --> 00:16:35.607
>> Absolutely, and notice that all
these tools we've been using to test,

325
00:16:35.607 --> 00:16:40.360
ping are a lot of stuff from
the command prompt, right?

326
00:16:40.360 --> 00:16:44.206
We did IP config, NS look up, we used
TelNet to connect to some ports, so

327
00:16:44.206 --> 00:16:45.908
all that looks really good, but

328
00:16:45.908 --> 00:16:49.333
in the end, how does my user
actually connect to Office 365?

329
00:16:49.333 --> 00:16:50.901
We use an application, right?

330
00:16:50.901 --> 00:16:54.834
They use their web browser, and then they
open up their favorite browser of choice

331
00:16:54.834 --> 00:16:57.123
and they type in that URL and
they go to connect.

332
00:16:57.123 --> 00:16:59.700
And even if all the other
settings are correct,

333
00:16:59.700 --> 00:17:03.902
my browser itself could have some
settings that cause problems, right Wes?

334
00:17:03.902 --> 00:17:07.815
>> That's exactly right because
again from a managed standpoint,

335
00:17:07.815 --> 00:17:11.880
now you might say, well Wes,
what do you mean managed standpoint?

336
00:17:11.880 --> 00:17:13.580
Isn't everything in IT managed?

337
00:17:13.580 --> 00:17:16.885
You're right, the answer's right, but what
I mean heavily managed you might have some

338
00:17:16.885 --> 00:17:20.680
kinda security compliance,
you might be under, what is it,

339
00:17:20.680 --> 00:17:25.010
the Federal Information Security Act,
FISMA, or something like that.

340
00:17:25.010 --> 00:17:27.400
You might be on foreign soils,
now I say foreign soils you guys,

341
00:17:27.400 --> 00:17:28.580
it's cuz we're here in the States.

342
00:17:28.580 --> 00:17:30.950
If you're in the UK,
we might be foreign soils to you, but

343
00:17:30.950 --> 00:17:34.300
it might be the EU model clause or
something that you're under.

344
00:17:34.300 --> 00:17:37.130
And you got some kinda security
compliance that says, hey,

345
00:17:37.130 --> 00:17:41.330
your internal workstations cannot connect
directly the the Internet, right?

346
00:17:41.330 --> 00:17:45.290
We have to screen ever process which means
that they have to go through a proxy.

347
00:17:45.290 --> 00:17:49.438
So, misconfigured proxy settings
could cause a problem as well, and

348
00:17:49.438 --> 00:17:52.380
let me show you where you can find
those inside of Internet Explorer here.

349
00:17:52.380 --> 00:17:54.980
So I just got Internet Explorer opened up.

350
00:17:54.980 --> 00:17:57.350
If it comes to the browser that you're
using, whether you're using Chrome,

351
00:17:57.350 --> 00:18:01.570
whether you're using Firefox, if you
happen to be using Microsoft's Edge,

352
00:18:01.570 --> 00:18:02.802
pay attention to those settings here.

353
00:18:02.802 --> 00:18:06.180
We're gonna look at Internet Explorer
here, cuz it's one of the most heavily

354
00:18:06.180 --> 00:18:12.310
supported web browsers when it comes
to using it to connect to Office 365,

355
00:18:12.310 --> 00:18:15.770
and it's MTA so we're going to
use Microsoft's technology here.

356
00:18:15.770 --> 00:18:18.660
But again, it does support
things like Chrome and Firefox.

357
00:18:18.660 --> 00:18:22.092
And we can go to the Internet options and
I kinda jumped around there real quick,

358
00:18:22.092 --> 00:18:23.250
let me make sure you guys see that.

359
00:18:24.300 --> 00:18:27.530
Little gear icon, there's a few
different ways you can get to this,

360
00:18:27.530 --> 00:18:31.038
if I right, oops, or you can leave it.

361
00:18:31.038 --> 00:18:34.870
If I right-click on
the little menu bar icon or

362
00:18:34.870 --> 00:18:37.230
location here, I can choose menu bar.

363
00:18:37.230 --> 00:18:41.790
And some of you maybe have been
around since IE7, 8, and 9.

364
00:18:41.790 --> 00:18:45.020
Maybe you like this little menu bar,
and I can get to Internet options here.

365
00:18:46.750 --> 00:18:50.990
I like it fast, a fast way to get
there is just a little gear icon,

366
00:18:50.990 --> 00:18:52.250
we can go to Internet options.

367
00:18:52.250 --> 00:18:55.690
And then the next thing I can do
is I can check my connections.

368
00:18:55.690 --> 00:19:00.400
All right, if I'm setting up different
types of connections for instance,

369
00:19:00.400 --> 00:19:02.400
connecting to the Internet here,
I can set this up.

370
00:19:02.400 --> 00:19:05.560
And this is no different then what you
would do in the, oop, the Setwork and

371
00:19:05.560 --> 00:19:06.260
Sharing Center.

372
00:19:07.270 --> 00:19:10.440
Let me close that down,
decided to disappear on me.

373
00:19:10.440 --> 00:19:14.880
All right, so
if you do end up having issues,

374
00:19:14.880 --> 00:19:17.990
if you have VPN connections,
you can set that here as well.

375
00:19:17.990 --> 00:19:21.820
And then you also have your LAN Settings
and LAN Settings are things

376
00:19:21.820 --> 00:19:24.630
automatic configuration under
your proxy settings here.

377
00:19:24.630 --> 00:19:27.710
Now the proxy settings
are important because

378
00:19:27.710 --> 00:19:29.980
notice that by default it says port 80.

379
00:19:29.980 --> 00:19:33.140
Well you might have multiple web
servers that I might've said

380
00:19:33.140 --> 00:19:35.670
the proxy port number might have
been a little bit different.

381
00:19:35.670 --> 00:19:37.465
Mike, I think they use
only 8080 sometimes.

382
00:19:37.465 --> 00:19:40.850
>> 8080 is a common one but a lot of
people wanna change that to something

383
00:19:40.850 --> 00:19:43.670
that's unique to their environment
just as a security reason.

384
00:19:43.670 --> 00:19:47.735
And remember, if your company
is running a proxy as Wes said,

385
00:19:47.735 --> 00:19:52.581
all traffic flows I should say,
through that proxy out to the Internet and

386
00:19:52.581 --> 00:19:54.868
back so they can do whatever it is.

387
00:19:54.868 --> 00:19:57.894
They can analyze it, they can control
what protocols are allowed, and

388
00:19:57.894 --> 00:19:58.710
things like that.

389
00:19:58.710 --> 00:20:02.273
So, if you've misconfigured your proxy
settings everything else could be working

390
00:20:02.273 --> 00:20:04.581
just fine, but
when you go to send that data outbound,

391
00:20:04.581 --> 00:20:07.208
if it doesn't go through the proxy,
it's got nowhere to go.

392
00:20:07.208 --> 00:20:09.860
So you've gotta make sure
these settings are correct.

393
00:20:09.860 --> 00:20:12.740
>> Yeah, it's setting a call-out
to a device that, well,

394
00:20:12.740 --> 00:20:16.510
it's not listening in that direction,
so no communication, so.

395
00:20:16.510 --> 00:20:19.335
Pay attention to
the Internet Explorer browser and

396
00:20:19.335 --> 00:20:23.410
again I should say the Internet
options within Internet Explorer and

397
00:20:23.410 --> 00:20:26.295
make sure that that's
not causing a problem.

398
00:20:26.295 --> 00:20:28.770
Again, if you have in a managed
environment like this,

399
00:20:28.770 --> 00:20:33.260
you might also have to worry about some of
those URLs that we were talking about, and

400
00:20:33.260 --> 00:20:38.020
I know I keep going back to
that URL list guys, a lot here.

401
00:20:38.020 --> 00:20:42.750
But it is important and let me bring
that back up so we can look at that.

402
00:20:42.750 --> 00:20:45.710
These URLs might be blocked.

403
00:20:45.710 --> 00:20:50.371
Again, some corporate security policy
might be standing, the bureaucracy,

404
00:20:50.371 --> 00:20:52.470
[LAUGH] if you will,
is standing in the way.

405
00:20:52.470 --> 00:20:55.500
Not necessarily the network communication,
so

406
00:20:55.500 --> 00:20:58.350
what we would have to do is
we'd have to get the URLs and

407
00:20:58.350 --> 00:21:01.630
we could go to a location inside
of Internet options, yet again.

408
00:21:01.630 --> 00:21:06.350
And then we would go
to our security zones.

409
00:21:06.350 --> 00:21:10.540
Our security zones, just in case that
maybe, again, you've got a very strict

410
00:21:10.540 --> 00:21:15.200
policy that's got these settings up on
high and it is blocking communications.

411
00:21:15.200 --> 00:21:21.216
Well at this point what I could do is I
could take these URLs that we have here,

412
00:21:21.216 --> 00:21:25.549
so for
instance maybe Outlook.Office365.com.

413
00:21:25.549 --> 00:21:30.596
And I can put this in my Trusted sites and
we'll go ahead and do that, and

414
00:21:30.596 --> 00:21:35.563
I'm gonna uncheck the Require server
verification, and then I can do

415
00:21:35.563 --> 00:21:40.978
something like this where I do https,
remember it does connect over HTTPS.

416
00:21:40.978 --> 00:21:47.687
And then I can I believe put
the wildcard there, office365.com.

417
00:21:47.687 --> 00:21:49.415
And once I add that,

418
00:21:49.415 --> 00:21:54.706
then what it's telling me is that
this is the parent domain and

419
00:21:54.706 --> 00:22:00.330
anything say below the parent
domain now is going to be accepted.

420
00:22:00.330 --> 00:22:06.169
Notice that I don't have to worry about
is it SMTP, Office, or .office365.com.

421
00:22:06.169 --> 00:22:11.036
I don't have to worry about is it
outllook.office365.com, cuz what I've said

422
00:22:11.036 --> 00:22:15.971
is we're using office365.com and I don't
care about the various services here,

423
00:22:15.971 --> 00:22:20.159
I just wanna make sure that that domain
is now trusted so that the browser if

424
00:22:20.159 --> 00:22:24.510
it's trying for security purposes to
block things like ActiveX controls.

425
00:22:24.510 --> 00:22:29.065
And you don't really I don't think have to
worry about things like Java Scriptlets,

426
00:22:29.065 --> 00:22:33.179
but anything that might for security
purposes be blocked or maybe even reduce

427
00:22:33.179 --> 00:22:37.840
the functionality of the experience inside
of Office 365, is no longer the case.

428
00:22:37.840 --> 00:22:41.600
And it could be one of the reasons that
you're not getting any connection,

429
00:22:41.600 --> 00:22:43.710
so pay attention to your URLs out there.

430
00:22:43.710 --> 00:22:46.480
Remember, just go out to
support.office365.com,

431
00:22:46.480 --> 00:22:52.090
they've got an entire database of
the office365 URLs, and IP addresses,

432
00:22:52.090 --> 00:22:56.040
so that if this is the case, you'll have
the ability to take that information,

433
00:22:56.040 --> 00:22:59.420
come back, put these in your
browsers in the Trusted sites.

434
00:22:59.420 --> 00:23:03.798
Now, I did this more of
a decentralized method.

435
00:23:03.798 --> 00:23:08.640
Most likely, [LAUGH] well I can't say
most likely, you will not be doing

436
00:23:08.640 --> 00:23:13.288
this 300 times, 1,000, times,
3,000, times to all the browsers.

437
00:23:13.288 --> 00:23:17.870
You're probably gonna be using some
kind of configuration technology,

438
00:23:17.870 --> 00:23:20.980
most likely it's gonna be something like
Active Directory because you can set it

439
00:23:20.980 --> 00:23:22.460
one time in the policy.

440
00:23:22.460 --> 00:23:25.150
You can divide it up according
to geographical location, and

441
00:23:25.150 --> 00:23:28.700
you can make sure and
ensure that those settings are pushed out

442
00:23:28.700 --> 00:23:32.530
to multiple end users and
you get the centralized administration.

443
00:23:32.530 --> 00:23:36.240
But at least you know where
the settings are, and for the MTA exam

444
00:23:36.240 --> 00:23:39.920
I would know the fact that maybe
the Trusted sites might come into play.

445
00:23:39.920 --> 00:23:43.990
Internet options as well as some of
the configurations via the proxy

446
00:23:43.990 --> 00:23:45.190
might come into play as well.

447
00:23:45.190 --> 00:23:49.065
I wouldn't worry too much about the Active
Directory side of it, but we wouldn't

448
00:23:49.065 --> 00:23:52.595
be doing you any justice if you thought
you had to do this 30,000 times.

449
00:23:52.595 --> 00:23:54.725
You'd be using Active Directory policy,
right?

450
00:23:54.725 --> 00:23:55.233
>> Yeah, absolutely.

451
00:23:55.233 --> 00:23:58.551
All right, Wes,
a lot of great information there,

452
00:23:58.551 --> 00:24:03.382
continuing that look at troubleshooting or
supporting those cloud users,

453
00:24:03.382 --> 00:24:07.382
making sure that from their
machine that they're sitting at,

454
00:24:07.382 --> 00:24:11.474
they can reach out and
talk to that Office 365, in this case.

455
00:24:11.474 --> 00:24:13.656
So, and I know we got a few more
things we're gonna go over,

456
00:24:13.656 --> 00:24:16.716
we gotta start looking at the applications
themselves, if they're running, and

457
00:24:16.716 --> 00:24:19.951
a few are a higher level troubleshooting
methodologies, but unfortunately we're out

458
00:24:19.951 --> 00:24:23.360
of time in this particular episode, so
we're gonna have to call it there, Wes.

459
00:24:23.360 --> 00:24:25.675
Hopefully you'll come back and
help us the rest of the way.

460
00:24:25.675 --> 00:24:28.185
Hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

461
00:24:28.185 --> 00:24:29.715
Signing off, I'm Mike Roderick.

462
00:24:29.715 --> 00:24:31.267
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

463
00:24:31.267 --> 00:24:33.634
>> And we'll see you next time.

464
00:24:33.634 --> 00:24:37.110
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike finish up their conversation on supporting cloud users. They look at issues dealing with activation and licensing, and platform support for both desktops and mobile devices. They also demonstrate doing a repair on an Office installation.
episodes.title: Support Cloud Users Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:10.008
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.138 --> 00:00:15.783
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro TV.

3
00:00:15.783 --> 00:00:17.440
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.440 --> 00:00:20.060
Today we're doing our
MTA Cloud Fundamentals and

5
00:00:20.060 --> 00:00:24.550
specifically in this episode, we're gonna
be looking at supporting our cloud users.

6
00:00:24.550 --> 00:00:26.820
Now, if you missed the other episodes,
this is a part three.

7
00:00:26.820 --> 00:00:29.700
This is a continuation
of our conversation.

8
00:00:29.700 --> 00:00:31.260
And in this one we're gonna head into,

9
00:00:31.260 --> 00:00:34.610
we've looked at some basic network
connectivity cuz, obviously, if we're

10
00:00:34.610 --> 00:00:37.980
gonna connect to cloud services, we've
gotta be able to connect to the network.

11
00:00:37.980 --> 00:00:40.360
We've gotta be able to connect
out there to the internet.

12
00:00:40.360 --> 00:00:41.820
But once we've got all that,

13
00:00:41.820 --> 00:00:44.490
there's still some more things
we need to troubleshoot, right?

14
00:00:44.490 --> 00:00:48.090
The applications themselves, whether
they're running out there in the cloud or

15
00:00:48.090 --> 00:00:51.100
whether we want to install them locally.

16
00:00:51.100 --> 00:00:56.320
And here to help us with that of course
is, the Office 365 master, Mr. Wes Brian.

17
00:00:56.320 --> 00:00:56.910
How's it going Wes?

18
00:00:56.910 --> 00:00:57.570
>> It's going great.

19
00:00:57.570 --> 00:00:58.520
And it's great to be here.

20
00:00:58.520 --> 00:01:00.250
And that's right,
we're gonna be moving on and

21
00:01:00.250 --> 00:01:03.950
we do have to make sure we're
gonna differentiate whether

22
00:01:03.950 --> 00:01:08.460
you're using the online Office apps or,
whether you're using a local installation.

23
00:01:08.460 --> 00:01:12.580
Now when we talk about the online web
interface, go back and look at the first

24
00:01:12.580 --> 00:01:16.560
couple parts of this episode here because
we talk about some of the basic connection

25
00:01:16.560 --> 00:01:19.790
issues that you have to worry about, and
even troubleshooting the web browser.

26
00:01:19.790 --> 00:01:21.950
When you're using the online apps,

27
00:01:21.950 --> 00:01:24.760
this is really where you're
troubleshooting's gonna lie.

28
00:01:24.760 --> 00:01:28.760
It's going to be basic connectivity
issues, it's gonna be the web browser.

29
00:01:28.760 --> 00:01:32.730
But it is a little bit different when
you start talking about installing

30
00:01:32.730 --> 00:01:34.230
them locally, like Mike mentioned.

31
00:01:34.230 --> 00:01:36.767
Well, what's Mike talking about
when he says local installation?

32
00:01:36.767 --> 00:01:40.353
Well, that's gonna be no different
than any traditional installation

33
00:01:40.353 --> 00:01:43.187
in the Office Suite that you
maybe you used it in the past.

34
00:01:43.187 --> 00:01:50.205
Maybe you've used the older 2003,
the 2007, 2010, 2013, and wow, now 2016.

35
00:01:50.205 --> 00:01:52.035
>> Yeah.
>> My goodness, how time flies.

36
00:01:52.035 --> 00:01:54.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> And really, this is no difference.

37
00:01:54.670 --> 00:01:59.251
Because the only difference is,
is you're gonna connect to Office

38
00:01:59.251 --> 00:02:03.390
365 to download the applications,
and that's where we have to start.

39
00:02:03.390 --> 00:02:07.017
So if we're having a problem
during the local installation,

40
00:02:07.017 --> 00:02:09.257
check connection problems, right?

41
00:02:09.257 --> 00:02:10.879
Because even though I told you,

42
00:02:10.879 --> 00:02:14.916
really your connection problems are where
the online web apps are going to lie.

43
00:02:14.916 --> 00:02:17.654
Well, you still have to make
a connection to Office 365,

44
00:02:17.654 --> 00:02:20.284
you have to log in first and
then you have to install it, and

45
00:02:20.284 --> 00:02:22.506
its going to download
locally to your computer.

46
00:02:22.506 --> 00:02:25.129
So always start with those
connection problems and

47
00:02:25.129 --> 00:02:28.606
definitely go back and check the first
part of this episode out cuz we

48
00:02:28.606 --> 00:02:31.778
really looked at some of the different
things that you could do

49
00:02:31.778 --> 00:02:35.077
that with those connection
problems to troubleshooting them.

50
00:02:35.077 --> 00:02:39.520
Now, the other thing that we have
to look at too are the media.

51
00:02:39.520 --> 00:02:42.850
We have to look at the media, and
we have to look at product keys, and

52
00:02:42.850 --> 00:02:44.050
that's gonna be important, right?

53
00:02:44.050 --> 00:02:48.980
When you install your software locally,
you typically have to activate it, right?

54
00:02:48.980 --> 00:02:51.965
Well, the first thing that we need
to do if we're gonna troubleshoot

55
00:02:51.965 --> 00:02:53.612
the installation of an application,

56
00:02:53.612 --> 00:02:56.866
we have to make sure that we have
the right installation going out the gate.

57
00:02:56.866 --> 00:03:02.200
If you have a 32-bit platform and you try
to download a 64-bit operating system,

58
00:03:02.200 --> 00:03:04.398
not operating system, excuse me.

59
00:03:04.398 --> 00:03:07.827
64-bit edition of
the Office Professional Plus,

60
00:03:07.827 --> 00:03:12.704
well the problem is it doesn't install,
64-bit isn't gonna install on

61
00:03:12.704 --> 00:03:16.758
a 32-bit operating system, so
we do have to pay attention.

62
00:03:16.758 --> 00:03:18.882
Now, it can work the other way,

63
00:03:18.882 --> 00:03:24.256
you can install a 32-bit instance of
the Office Suite on a 64-bit machine.

64
00:03:24.256 --> 00:03:28.630
And we'll look at some of the benefits and
the pros and cons of that coming up.

65
00:03:28.630 --> 00:03:31.410
So make sure that it's architectural.

66
00:03:31.410 --> 00:03:34.360
You know, or what the CPU or
the competing architecture is.

67
00:03:34.360 --> 00:03:38.790
Whether it's 32-bit or 64-bit because
that's gonna be where you have to start.

68
00:03:38.790 --> 00:03:42.480
The next thing that we have to, once we
determine what the media is we have to

69
00:03:42.480 --> 00:03:44.650
make sure that we have
the right product key.

70
00:03:44.650 --> 00:03:49.128
All right, the product key can cause
problems when it comes to activation.

71
00:03:49.128 --> 00:03:53.295
Remember that part of your license is an
ongoing activation to those applications,

72
00:03:53.295 --> 00:03:56.933
and if they're not activated they could
even go into things like a reduced

73
00:03:56.933 --> 00:03:57.827
functionality.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike take a look at some of the techniques and tools we can use to troubleshoot connecting to Exchange Online. They talk about the importance of making sure the latest updates are applied. Then they demonstrate two tools to aid in this.

00:25:50.300 --> 00:25:51.220
>> Nice.

514
00:25:51.220 --> 00:25:53.810
>> All right, so
they tell you the test steps here.

00:25:53.810 --> 00:25:55.410

Make it a little bit easier there.

All right, there we go.

00:26:39.460 --> 00:26:40.020

00:26:52.270 --> 00:26:53.810

We could turn around and

not that you can't, and

00:28:03.260 --> 00:28:04.969
But this is a great starting point.

00:28:04.969 --> 00:28:05.725
It might find.

Remember, we like to keep it simple.

00:28:07.600 --> 00:28:10.350

00:28:10.350 --> 00:28:14.420
And, they look really good, Wes, like

We've looked at some of the tools

Well, these links, I have to tell you,

The other thing that I want

It is another tool that you

00:29:17.140 --> 00:29:18.740
So check your Office,

00:29:18.740 --> 00:29:21.670

Windows 10, I believe,

And, going back to updates,

if you're keeping yourself up to date,

Now, the next thing that we wanna

00:29:47.690 --> 00:29:50.330
If I click on that link, it's gonna do

It's gonna give me,

Now on Windows 10 it's

And we have this

00:30:07.930 --> 00:30:08.600
All right.

And connectivity diagnostics you can see

I can't log In with Office Outlook.

I can type the email.

And so let's go ahead and

And email address, we'll just go ahead and

And single sign on where I could

And then what it's gonna do, you can see

It's going to automate it

So I can actually deploy this out

Rather than doing just

I'm connecting to a web-based

00:31:11.990 --> 00:31:14.130
this test is actually running

So this is something that you

instance with your Active Directory.

it would be available and be handy,

So that maybe it wouldn't

All right, so they discovered

00:32:37.952 --> 00:32:40.590
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it's my information that was wrong,

I was picking on Mike here at

And it looks like it's me that's

And the GUI, it can make

Some of those tools that

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike continue troubleshooting connecting to Exchange Online. This time they explore issues with delegating mailbox access, looking at the different permissions available. They also demonstrate using PowerShell to connect and troubleshoot connecting to Exchange Online.
episodes.title: Support Exchange Online Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:10.003
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.053 --> 00:00:15.240
Hello and welcome to another
exciting episode here at IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:15.240 --> 00:00:17.160
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.160 --> 00:00:20.440
Today, we're doing our
MTA Cloud Fundamentals and

6
00:00:24.360 --> 00:00:27.570
Now this is Part Two so
in Part One we've already looked at

00:00:27.570 --> 00:00:31.280
a couple of troubleshooting, if I can get

Including some things that we might
do on the client end as well as some

We're gonna continue on with that theme

00:00:43.033 --> 00:00:46.132

A lot of times we have to give somebody

maybe while we're out of the office or

Respond to emails while their out

00:01:05.930 --> 00:01:09.410

I mean, what would troubleshooting

To help us walk through all of that,

>> Going good and thanks for

00:01:18.140 --> 00:01:20.320
As always, great to be here with ITProTV.

00:01:20.320 --> 00:01:23.210
And that's one of the first
things we are going to look at.

And that's the delegation of access or
delegation, I should say,

00:01:27.410 --> 00:01:30.310

Now we've been really dealing with the web
interfaces, the online applications more

27
00:01:34.760 --> 00:01:37.780
than we've been dealing with
some of the local applications.

28
00:01:37.780 --> 00:01:41.720
But since we are talking about Exchange,
we're gonna have to go loco.

29
00:01:41.720 --> 00:01:42.323
Loco?
>> [LAUGH]

30
00:01:42.323 --> 00:01:44.063
>> [LAUGH] We're gonna have to go local

00:01:44.063 --> 00:01:45.170
here not loco [LAUGH].

32

>> Muy loco, muy loco.

33

>> That's right and we're gonna have to

34
00:01:49.794 --> 00:01:51.500
in this case it's gonna be Outlook.

35
00:01:51.500 --> 00:01:53.080
So let's show you what
we're talking about here.

36
00:01:53.080 --> 00:01:55.680
I've got my Outlook
already pulled up here.

37
00:01:55.680 --> 00:01:59.953
And when you are gonna delegate
access to a mailbox like Mike said,

the scenario that I've actually set up
is an IT assistant that maybe the IT

39
00:02:04.683 --> 00:02:07.223
manager is gone on vacation for a week.

40
00:02:07.223 --> 00:02:11.154
But looking for a couple of those
important emails to come in and we need to

42
00:02:15.480 --> 00:02:18.970
Now when you're troubleshooting access,
you have to know what the permissions

44
00:02:21.480 --> 00:02:25.450
And if you don't, unfortunately, when you
go on vacation the person that you've

45

given access or delegated access to that
mailbox cannot perform the actions or

46
00:02:29.750 --> 00:02:31.820
the functionalities that you

47
00:02:31.820 --> 00:02:33.850
So let's go ahead and look right here.

48

So inside of Outlook

Almost thought it was

And it's halfway down

53
00:02:48.410 --> 00:02:50.449

54
00:02:51.520 --> 00:02:52.530
All right now,

Let me go ahead and just show you here,

57
00:03:01.890 --> 00:03:03.525
We'll start from scratch and

58

59
00:03:06.235 --> 00:03:09.255
And it will also help you when it comes
to troubleshooting in showing that those

60
00:03:09.255 --> 00:03:11.835
settings are what we're
gonna show you here.

61
00:03:11.835 --> 00:03:15.355
All right, so we're gonna go ahead and
take this identity and

62
00:03:15.355 --> 00:03:16.165
we're gonna remove them.

63
00:03:17.175 --> 00:03:22.095
All right, and you might set up some kind
of shared mailbox or shared account for

00:03:22.095 --> 00:03:26.980
this, it's really gonna be how
your infrastructure's set up.

65
00:03:26.980 --> 00:03:29.130
You might have a dedicated
person username,

66
00:03:29.130 --> 00:03:30.700
and you're gonna allow that person.

67
00:03:30.700 --> 00:03:35.690
I made a generic account called

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike troubleshoot connectivity to SharePoint Online. They start by identifying the storage limits of SharePoint Online. Then they troubleshoot using the Open in Explorer option. They finish by troubleshooting synchronization issues with OneDrive.
episodes.title: Support SharePoint Online

If they're doing this in file explorer
on their local machines, yeah.

509
00:28:35.700 --> 00:28:37.550
It goes to the Recycle Bin
on their machine.

510
00:28:37.550 --> 00:28:40.040
But even if they delete it from
the Recycle Bin on their machine,

511
00:28:40.040 --> 00:28:44.640
your admins still have the ability to
come here and at least have kind of like

512
00:28:44.640 --> 00:28:49.260
that last safety mechanism, to make sure
that if you are deleting business files

513
00:28:49.260 --> 00:28:53.560
it'll be the admin that could either
restore them or do a final delete on them.

514
00:28:53.560 --> 00:28:56.940
But be careful, because if you delete them
from from here, they are gonna be gone.

515
00:28:56.940 --> 00:28:57.840
>> Gone forever.

516
00:28:57.840 --> 00:28:58.360
>> That's right.

517
00:28:58.360 --> 00:29:01.360
>> All right,
words to live by from Mr. Wes Bryan.

518
00:29:01.360 --> 00:29:04.255
All right, we appreciate that Wes,
a lot of great demonstrations again.

519
00:29:04.255 --> 00:29:05.515
A lot of great information.

520
00:29:05.515 --> 00:29:07.585
Hope everybody out there enjoyed watching.

521
00:29:07.585 --> 00:29:09.055
Signing off, I'm Mike Rodrick.

522
00:29:09.055 --> 00:29:10.155
>> And I'm West Bryan.

523
00:29:10.155 --> 00:29:11.513
>> And we'll see you next time.

524
00:29:11.513 --> 00:29:16.450
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike troubleshoot Skype for Business. They look at Skype for Business client issues and authentication issues. They also talk about network issues as well as issues related to services.
episodes.title: Support Skype for Business
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.439 --> 00:00:15.995
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:15.995 --> 00:00:20.500
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, today we're
doing our MTA cloud fundamentals.

4
00:00:20.500 --> 00:00:24.540
And specifically in this episode, we're
gonna be looking at Skype for Business,

5
00:00:24.540 --> 00:00:29.270
another important part of our enterprise
environment, something we use, and

6
00:00:29.270 --> 00:00:32.920
something that we have to be able
to support when things go wrong.

7
00:00:32.920 --> 00:00:35.120
And here to help us with
that is Mister Wes Bryan.

8
00:00:35.120 --> 00:00:35.850
How's it going Wes?

9
00:00:35.850 --> 00:00:36.750
>> Hey, it's going great, Mike.

10
00:00:36.750 --> 00:00:37.760
Thanks for having me back.

11
00:00:37.760 --> 00:00:40.850
As always, good to be here with ITProTV,
and that's right.

12
00:00:40.850 --> 00:00:43.480
We're going to be look at
supporting Skype for Business.

13
00:00:43.480 --> 00:00:48.600
This is one of the last of the services
that we really have to look at.

14
00:00:48.600 --> 00:00:53.810
This is one of the ones that we use for
voice over IP communications and

15
00:00:53.810 --> 00:00:57.010
communications are definitely going to
be important inside of our company.

16
00:00:57.010 --> 00:01:02.340
So this really could be one of those
services, out of all the services

17
00:01:02.340 --> 00:01:05.720
that we talk about, that could be one of
the major lifelines for your business.

18
00:01:05.720 --> 00:01:09.210
So it is important to know some
of the things that you can do to

19
00:01:09.210 --> 00:01:14.400
remedy the issues, and actually to even
know what potential issues might come up.

20
00:01:14.400 --> 00:01:15.040
Who does it affect,

21
00:01:15.040 --> 00:01:17.670
and then some of the things that
we can do to resolve those issues.

22
00:01:17.670 --> 00:01:19.160
So that's what we're gonna be looking at.

23
00:01:19.160 --> 00:01:20.965
We're gonna be looking at
the scope of the problem,

24
00:01:20.965 --> 00:01:23.950
w're gonna be looking at the potential
causes and then we're gonna discuss some

25
00:01:23.950 --> 00:01:27.640
of the things that you can see in
order to fix those potential problems.

26
00:01:27.640 --> 00:01:30.310
So Mike, one of the first things
that we have to look at is well,

27
00:01:30.310 --> 00:01:33.060
what is the software that
is running on the machine?

28
00:01:33.060 --> 00:01:35.880
We have what is known as the Skype for
Business client, right?

29
00:01:35.880 --> 00:01:38.860
And that's what manages the communications
between your local machine

30
00:01:38.860 --> 00:01:42.380
outbound across the internet and
connects to Skype for Business online.

31
00:01:42.380 --> 00:01:45.960
But not only just the client, the client's
running on the computer itself.

32
00:01:45.960 --> 00:01:48.010
So I also have to look at
some things that might,

33
00:01:48.010 --> 00:01:51.460
it might just be directly related to
the computer configuration itself.

34
00:01:51.460 --> 00:01:55.480
One of the first things we have to look
at is when it is a client issue, and

35
00:01:55.480 --> 00:01:57.910
when I say client issue,
let me very specific here,

36
00:01:57.910 --> 00:01:59.990
I'm talking about the Skype for
Business client, right?

37
00:01:59.990 --> 00:02:03.140
It's running on the client workstation,
so that can get a little twisty there.

38
00:02:03.140 --> 00:02:07.770
But I'm talking about the agent that
manages the communication between whatever

39
00:02:08.940 --> 00:02:12.220
conference that you gonna be a part of,
any kind of Voice over IP call that

40
00:02:12.220 --> 00:02:16.810
you might be a part of, it's important
to understand some of the things there.

41
00:02:16.810 --> 00:02:18.765
First thing, out of date client, right?

42
00:02:18.765 --> 00:02:21.420
>> Mm-hm.
>> You've gotta keep the client software

43
00:02:21.420 --> 00:02:21.990
up to date.

44
00:02:21.990 --> 00:02:26.310
It's important, right, as they add
functionality, improve functionality,

45
00:02:26.310 --> 00:02:29.460
fix known flaws, bugs with
the platform that might've been there

46
00:02:29.460 --> 00:02:31.460
in the previous version of the client,

47
00:02:31.460 --> 00:02:36.660
if you stick with an older client,
you're gonna get left behind.

48
00:02:36.660 --> 00:02:38.840
And that could be one of the first
things that you need to do.

49
00:02:38.840 --> 00:02:41.700
>> Really, like the same principle as
applying all of your updates, right,

50
00:02:41.700 --> 00:02:45.380
just making sure you've got the latest and
greatest version of that client.

51
00:02:45.380 --> 00:02:46.380
>> Yeah, that's exactly right.

52
00:02:46.380 --> 00:02:50.480
I mean, it's no different than any other
software that you're gonna have, and

53
00:02:50.480 --> 00:02:52.860
we need to apply our updates.

54
00:02:52.860 --> 00:02:56.315
The other thing that they do call
out is a missing operating system.

55
00:02:56.315 --> 00:02:59.130
>> [LAUGH]
>> I looked at some

56
00:02:59.130 --> 00:03:03.090
of the support documentation and well if
your operating system is missing, chances

57
00:03:03.090 --> 00:03:06.440
are your client went with it, so [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

58
00:03:06.440 --> 00:03:07.960
>> If I'm missing an operating system,

59
00:03:07.960 --> 00:03:10.940
I think I've got bigger issues than
troubleshooting Skype at this point.

60
00:03:10.940 --> 00:03:13.810
>> Yeah, that is-
>> That definitely is a potential problem

61
00:03:13.810 --> 00:03:14.930
>> What, what happened to my

62
00:03:14.930 --> 00:03:15.770
operating system?

63
00:03:15.770 --> 00:03:18.160
Well, we left it in front of the You
are Here sign in the mall, and

64
00:03:18.160 --> 00:03:19.208
we've never seen it again.

65
00:03:19.208 --> 00:03:23.850
[LAUGH] So you know, if you have general
problems with the operating system itself,

66
00:03:23.850 --> 00:03:28.410
if you think you have malware that might
be causing, for instance, executables,

67
00:03:28.410 --> 00:03:31.550
I've seen malware before that locks
down all legitimate executables like

68
00:03:31.550 --> 00:03:33.280
task manager, computer management,

69
00:03:33.280 --> 00:03:36.520
all these things that you use to
administer to the operating system.

70
00:03:36.520 --> 00:03:37.290
And, who knows,

71
00:03:37.290 --> 00:03:41.720
it might actually might be hindering the
communication with the application itself.

72
00:03:41.720 --> 00:03:44.080
The other thing too, and
this really could be, Mike,

73
00:03:44.080 --> 00:03:49.470
lumped into updating your client agents,
the agent that manages the communication,

74
00:03:49.470 --> 00:03:52.030
and it could also be
the operating system too.

75
00:03:52.030 --> 00:03:55.220
These are things like protocol
hotfixes and product updates, right?

76
00:03:55.220 --> 00:03:57.260
Which, like I said,
can kind of run hand in hand,

77
00:03:57.260 --> 00:04:00.030
but also remember things like
hotfixes on your machines.

78
00:04:00.030 --> 00:04:03.210
Right, when we talked about in a previous
episode, one of the things that we talked

79
00:04:03.210 --> 00:04:05.840
about is the fact that the earlier
web browsers, like for

80
00:04:05.840 --> 00:04:08.530
instance connecting into SharePoint,
aren't gonna be supported, and I mean

81
00:04:08.530 --> 00:04:13.540
specifically Internet Explorer seven,
eight, no actually eight, nine, and ten.

82
00:04:13.540 --> 00:04:15.232
There wasn't a nine that's right,
seven, eight, and ten.

83
00:04:15.232 --> 00:04:16.776
>> [LAUGH]
>> Got to get those numbers right.

84
00:04:16.776 --> 00:04:21.028
Well you know there was a hotfix that you
could apply to allow you to connect and

85
00:04:21.028 --> 00:04:23.380
perform a certain functionality.

86
00:04:23.380 --> 00:04:26.090
Well it's really no different from when
you're talking down any hotfix that comes

87
00:04:26.090 --> 00:04:30.310
out for the application or any hotfix that
might be bundled into Windows updates,

88
00:04:30.310 --> 00:04:33.220
so keep your Windows updates up to date.

89
00:04:33.220 --> 00:04:36.200
Make sure that you're updating
that client, it is important.

90
00:04:36.200 --> 00:04:39.930
Now here are two subjects,

91
00:04:39.930 --> 00:04:45.230
potential causes, that I would
definitely pay attention for the exam.

92
00:04:45.230 --> 00:04:47.850
Surely an outdated client
will be one of them.

93
00:04:47.850 --> 00:04:51.100
Here's a big one, all right, so I'm
gonna say an exam alert on this one, and

94
00:04:51.100 --> 00:04:53.320
I'm gonna wear my old Johnny Carson hat.

95
00:04:53.320 --> 00:04:55.280
Jay, can I tell what's in the test?

96
00:04:55.280 --> 00:04:57.820
No, not really, but
I can guarantee you this one might be, and

97
00:04:57.820 --> 00:04:59.680
that's clock synchronization.

98
00:04:59.680 --> 00:05:03.290
All right, remember that we're talking
about voice over IP communications.

99
00:05:03.290 --> 00:05:07.900
That is a time-sensitive delivery
mechanism that it relies on, right?

100
00:05:07.900 --> 00:05:12.800
So if you have out of sync clocks,
you might not be connecting too.

101
00:05:12.800 --> 00:05:17.260
Now the other one is
the cache credentials.

102
00:05:17.260 --> 00:05:21.670
Now if you are logging
in to a work station via

103
00:05:21.670 --> 00:05:26.060
your office, maybe you guys have
everything in the cloud, right?

104
00:05:26.060 --> 00:05:29.530
And you're using online
Microsoft accounts and

105
00:05:29.530 --> 00:05:32.150
stuff that are attached
to domain accounts, well,

106
00:05:32.150 --> 00:05:35.820
if it caches their credentials, you might
be trying to log in as somebody else,

107
00:05:35.820 --> 00:05:40.050
so you might want to clear the cache
credentials on the operating system.

108
00:05:40.050 --> 00:05:43.580
Now one of the things that I didn't
mention, I talked about potential causes,

109
00:05:43.580 --> 00:05:45.760
right, but I didn't talk about the scope.

110
00:05:45.760 --> 00:05:49.460
All right, so if it is a client issue,
who is it going to affect?

111
00:05:49.460 --> 00:05:54.680
Most likely this affects maybe a single
user, or a specific group of users, right?

112
00:05:54.680 --> 00:05:58.300
And if it's a group of users, a lot of
times it's like a small group of users

113
00:05:58.300 --> 00:06:01.260
that are sharing common configurations.

114
00:06:01.260 --> 00:06:04.130
So you have to pay attention to
those configurations as well.

115
00:06:04.130 --> 00:06:08.531
But just know that something like a client
issue itself or the computer issue

116
00:06:08.531 --> 00:06:12.465
is typically just going to be a single
user or a small group of users.

117
00:06:12.465 --> 00:06:13.785
>> Very good, very good.

118
00:06:13.785 --> 00:06:17.745
>> All right, so now they also call out
some other things that you need to be

119
00:06:17.745 --> 00:06:21.670
aware of, and that's
the authentication and provisioning.

120
00:06:21.670 --> 00:06:25.690
Now you've seen me struggle with typing
a password throughout this series, so

121
00:06:25.690 --> 00:06:28.360
you can see that it's a commonality,
right?

122
00:06:28.360 --> 00:06:31.530
It's no different than if
you're implementing things like

123
00:06:31.530 --> 00:06:33.330
password complexity, right?

124
00:06:33.330 --> 00:06:37.370
As passwords get more complex, they can
get harder to type, believe me, I know.

125
00:06:37.370 --> 00:06:43.380
So the scope of this one usually
affects a specific kind of user,

126
00:06:43.380 --> 00:06:48.000
if it isn't just the incorrect
password being typed.

127
00:06:48.000 --> 00:06:50.030
And that's, for instance,
like federated users.

128
00:06:51.560 --> 00:06:52.950
On the back end,

129
00:06:52.950 --> 00:06:57.450
sometimes what we don't see is the fact
that Active Directory Federation Services

130
00:06:57.450 --> 00:07:00.550
is running to help us
implement that single sign-on.

131
00:07:00.550 --> 00:07:03.710
Right, so I can enter my credentials, and
I can go through the different platforms,

132
00:07:03.710 --> 00:07:05.290
and I don't have to
re-enter my credentials.

133
00:07:05.290 --> 00:07:07.390
Well if the Active Directory Federation

134
00:07:07.390 --> 00:07:09.385
Services Service-
>> [LAUGH]

135
00:07:09.385 --> 00:07:11.550
>> Isn't working appropriately,

136
00:07:11.550 --> 00:07:15.380
then you might not get that federated
authentication or that single sign in, and

137
00:07:15.380 --> 00:07:18.920
that might be something
that you need to check.

138
00:07:18.920 --> 00:07:21.160
Along with the incorrect password,

139
00:07:21.160 --> 00:07:25.890
is somebody not typing in their user
email, right, the sign-in email.

140
00:07:25.890 --> 00:07:28.490
That's we use that, what is it?

141
00:07:28.490 --> 00:07:31.540
The universal principle maybe,
UPN, to log in.

142
00:07:31.540 --> 00:07:33.370
Well if that name isn't typed correctly,

143
00:07:33.370 --> 00:07:38.190
just like a password,
it might cause problems with that as well.

144
00:07:38.190 --> 00:07:41.060
Now we said specific type of users, right.

145
00:07:41.060 --> 00:07:43.760
One of them was any federated user.

146
00:07:43.760 --> 00:07:49.040
The other one would be one that
isn't licensed to use Skype, right?

147
00:07:49.040 --> 00:07:51.695
So if you have something like this you
have to check your licensing information.

148
00:07:51.695 --> 00:07:56.914
Remember, we've also talked in previous
episodes about license exhaustion,

149
00:07:56.914 --> 00:07:59.380
so definitely pay attention to that.

150
00:07:59.380 --> 00:08:02.105
All right, now other issues
that we might have, Skyping and

151
00:08:02.105 --> 00:08:04.731
online service networking
issues have to come into play.

152
00:08:04.731 --> 00:08:06.350
>> Oh, definitely, definitely.

153
00:08:06.350 --> 00:08:10.090
And when it comes to the networking
issues, we gotta pretty good episode

154
00:08:10.090 --> 00:08:14.138
talking about some of the networking
problems that would come about, and some

155
00:08:14.138 --> 00:08:18.390
of the utilities that you can use in order
to check basic network communications.

156
00:08:18.390 --> 00:08:22.126
Now with the networking communications,
I'm going to go ahead and

157
00:08:22.126 --> 00:08:24.260
tackle the scope first, right.

158
00:08:24.260 --> 00:08:27.317
With the networking issues a lot of times
which you'll see it affects a large

159
00:08:27.317 --> 00:08:28.050
group of people.

160
00:08:28.050 --> 00:08:31.814
Right, if it's a network communication
issue and it's maybe not even, we're not

161
00:08:31.814 --> 00:08:35.430
blaming Microsoft either, we're just
saying maybe even in your local subnet.

162
00:08:35.430 --> 00:08:38.830
You might see that this
is geographical centric,

163
00:08:38.830 --> 00:08:43.280
right, to a certain geographical region or
location or.

164
00:08:43.280 --> 00:08:45.680
Even more so, even affecting somebody.

165
00:08:45.680 --> 00:08:48.950
Now, on the support documentation,
they say, in a specific domain.

166
00:08:48.950 --> 00:08:50.350
Think about your tenet.

167
00:08:50.350 --> 00:08:52.989
Right?
It could be affecting everybody in that

168
00:08:52.989 --> 00:08:54.000
tenet itself.

169
00:08:54.000 --> 00:08:56.790
So it could be related
to a specific domain.

170
00:08:56.790 --> 00:08:59.600
Now what are some of the potential causes?

171
00:08:59.600 --> 00:09:03.030
I wanna talk about the DNS auto discovery.

172
00:09:03.030 --> 00:09:07.401
If you are letting Microsoft
manage your DNS, and

173
00:09:07.401 --> 00:09:12.604
we showed you how you can set
up your domain, for instance,

174
00:09:12.604 --> 00:09:16.890
to put those NS records in the zone file,
in DNS.

175
00:09:16.890 --> 00:09:21.263
And basically what you're doing is
putting those name server records,

176
00:09:21.263 --> 00:09:24.590
you're saying Microsoft,
you manage my DNS.

177
00:09:24.590 --> 00:09:28.540
I don't wanna manage it, I'll put my name
server records in my DNS zone file and

178
00:09:28.540 --> 00:09:30.720
then what it's gonna do is it's
gonna point back to you and

179
00:09:30.720 --> 00:09:32.150
you'll take care of that.

180
00:09:32.150 --> 00:09:35.560
If you set that up,
autodiscovery should work.

181
00:09:35.560 --> 00:09:39.450
However, It's when you choose
a customized domain right.

182
00:09:39.450 --> 00:09:43.940
I want to use spacerooster.net right,
well I've got a host to DNS service, and

183
00:09:43.940 --> 00:09:46.540
if I don't have the sip records,

184
00:09:46.540 --> 00:09:50.800
the SRV records the connonitical
records that need to be in there And

185
00:09:50.800 --> 00:09:54.330
the A records then the problem is
the DNS auto discovery's gonna fail.

186
00:09:54.330 --> 00:09:59.890
So check your DNS records
inside of your zone file if

187
00:09:59.890 --> 00:10:04.740
you're using your own hosted DNS service
or you're using a customized domain and

188
00:10:04.740 --> 00:10:09.300
you're not offloading that
name resolution to Microsoft.

189
00:10:09.300 --> 00:10:11.100
The other thing, network communications.

190
00:10:11.100 --> 00:10:13.800
We've also talked about this
in other episodes, proxies.

191
00:10:13.800 --> 00:10:17.018
Right, if you got a heavily
internally managed corporation,

192
00:10:17.018 --> 00:10:20.174
got some kind of contact type
security policy that says, no,

193
00:10:20.174 --> 00:10:24.667
you don't give your users direct access to
the Internet, they're gonna be redirected

194
00:10:24.667 --> 00:10:27.850
through a proxy, then you have
to check your proxy settings.

195
00:10:27.850 --> 00:10:30.660
The proxy settings might
be causing the problem.

196
00:10:30.660 --> 00:10:35.120
The other one comes back to
the commonality here as well.

197
00:10:35.120 --> 00:10:36.860
And that's the firewall issue.

198
00:10:36.860 --> 00:10:39.000
Right?
Do you have an exception?

199
00:10:39.000 --> 00:10:41.030
Are you blocking certain ports?

200
00:10:41.030 --> 00:10:42.600
Are you blocking the communication?

201
00:10:42.600 --> 00:10:45.580
So, you also have to
check the firewall too.

202
00:10:45.580 --> 00:10:48.380
Just keep in mind that
this usually affects

203
00:10:48.380 --> 00:10:51.710
a large group of people this isn't
restricted it's just a single user.

204
00:10:51.710 --> 00:10:55.680
>> Right, if it's a firewall issue every
user that's using that is going to

205
00:10:55.680 --> 00:10:57.940
most likely encounter that error.

206
00:10:57.940 --> 00:10:59.570
>> Definitely, definitely.

207
00:10:59.570 --> 00:11:02.630
Now we've talked about some
of the things that very well

208
00:11:02.630 --> 00:11:04.350
might not be Microsoft at all, right?

209
00:11:04.350 --> 00:11:09.120
Most of what we've talked about client
issues right, configuration issues,

210
00:11:09.120 --> 00:11:11.290
computer issues, network problems right.

211
00:11:12.370 --> 00:11:16.460
The last one that we wanna kinda touch
base on is something that could be related

212
00:11:16.460 --> 00:11:19.100
to Microsoft right, and
that's service related issues.

213
00:11:19.100 --> 00:11:23.120
Now service related issues
are usually tenant wide, right.

214
00:11:23.120 --> 00:11:24.940
If my company is using Skype,

215
00:11:24.940 --> 00:11:29.960
if my company using Active Directory,
Azure Active Directory right, and

216
00:11:29.960 --> 00:11:33.360
something goes wrong with those services,
it affects everybody of my tenants.

217
00:11:33.360 --> 00:11:37.340
So service related issues there,
you can go to the service center,

218
00:11:37.340 --> 00:11:42.210
rather the service health center dashboard
inside Office 365 and you can look and

219
00:11:42.210 --> 00:11:48.470
see if the services are available, if
they've been given diminished experience.

220
00:11:48.470 --> 00:11:50.800
Remember, that's all part of your SLA,
too.

221
00:11:50.800 --> 00:11:55.271
The other thing that can happen too when
there's service related telltale sign is

222
00:11:55.271 --> 00:12:00.001
that it's site specific or, for instance,
a certain geographical location usually

223
00:12:00.001 --> 00:12:04.470
divided up by region, like for instance we
might would work here in North American

224
00:12:04.470 --> 00:12:08.010
region, that's where all
of our data centers are.

225
00:12:08.010 --> 00:12:10.860
And of it's specific to the North American
region then what I can do is

226
00:12:10.860 --> 00:12:13.870
find the data centers up on
Microsoft's support site and

227
00:12:13.870 --> 00:12:18.960
find out that maybe the one out there
in Washington is a having issues.

228
00:12:18.960 --> 00:12:21.770
And maybe that's where
Skype is being held.

229
00:12:21.770 --> 00:12:25.910
Keep in mind that not every data
center holds every single service.

230
00:12:25.910 --> 00:12:28.220
In fact, we've seen that it's really,
really diverse, and

231
00:12:28.220 --> 00:12:31.150
the fact that one data center
could be holding just Yammer.

232
00:12:31.150 --> 00:12:32.450
Just the Yammer service.

233
00:12:32.450 --> 00:12:35.970
Or, this data center could be
holding just the Skype service, and

234
00:12:35.970 --> 00:12:37.790
then you have other ones
that are combinations, but

235
00:12:37.790 --> 00:12:42.660
there is no guarantee that every single
data center's gonna be holding redundant

236
00:12:42.660 --> 00:12:46.380
services there, so it might be
something that's located, for instance,

237
00:12:46.380 --> 00:12:51.040
to a specific Skype server itself,
that might be having problems.

238
00:12:51.040 --> 00:12:53.854
But just keep in mind that when it
comes to service related issues,

239
00:12:53.854 --> 00:12:57.140
they, typically, are going to affect
everybody within the tenant itself.

240
00:12:57.140 --> 00:13:00.260
>> All right, so other issues
we've gotta deal with with Skype.

00:13:00.260 --> 00:13:04.370
You know, we think of Skype as using it

00:13:04.370 --> 00:13:07.590
Sometimes we need to communicate

00:13:07.590 --> 00:13:09.270
They've got their own Skype set up, and

now we've got to troubleshoot

00:13:11.910 --> 00:13:13.821
>> That's right.
So, when it comes to this topic,

246
00:13:13.821 --> 00:13:16.702
I would tell you, start with
normal communication problems, and

00:13:16.702 --> 00:13:20.356
some of the other one's we've looked at,
you know, because if you can't sign in,

00:13:20.356 --> 00:13:23.920
right, that really doesn't have to do a,

your basic network

And eliminate those first before we figure

And that's what this

We've got the SharePoint admin center

[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

00:13:50.750 --> 00:13:52.240
>> So we've got this Skype for

one of the things we'll run

If I go over to this organization

This is where I can control external

And this is s setting that might be

Let me show you what I mean,
because by default,

00:14:16.454 --> 00:14:20.969
one of things that you're gonna notice is

00:14:39.105 --> 00:14:44.112
But it might be a little bit more

00:14:44.112 --> 00:14:46.662
All right?
So we can do this through whitelisting or

I can say,

Like for

So for instance, maybe we make toys,

00:15:23.870 --> 00:15:29.140
tenant right, he's a third party vendor

Well I might say, for Toys.com,

So how you set it up is really contingent

If you know that your users are gonna be

are communicating with a lot

However, if it's only maybe a couple

least privilege and put those companies,
those couple of companies there, and

00:16:17.550 --> 00:16:20.530
So fairly easy and then we could do,
again, if it's blocked or

allowed domains, it depends.

You can add the domains here so

spacerooster.net, right.

Now when I add that,

do I want this to be the block domain,

Notice that it leaves it there,
but it just,

00:16:42.740 --> 00:16:44.550
all I'm doing is changing the setting.

So when you put your domains there,

And again, the default is blocked

So keep that in mind.

And also for this exam,
I know I keep saying this.

Because I mean, it's really exam focused.

Know that this isn't enabled by default.

So it could, like I said, just be an

oh, I forgot to go in there and

>> Could be something that my

things like security policies as

Maybe your company, like Mike said,

Now one of the last things I'd like

And on the Skype for

And the one that I'm really,

This right here is the Skype for

Before Microsoft bought our Skype,

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike take another look at many of the tools available for troubleshooting connectivity to cloud-based services, like Office 365. They start by using basic network connectivity troubleshooting tools, like nslookup and ipconfig and tracert. They also cover the equivalent PowerShell commandlets. Then they look at the tools provided by Office 365.
episodes.title: Tools for Troubleshooting
